PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Now that even Senator Richardson is saying that the Labor Party has to have a convincing fifth term agenda, is it not time to acknowledge the failure of the Labor Government's economic management and put before the people of Australia policies to address the worst recession in 60 years? The Labor legacy will be one million Australians out of work, a $200 billion foreign debt—$11,000 for every man, woman and child in this country; a tenfold increase since the Labor Party came to government—and a massive trade deficit which is putting this country further into the red in excess of $1 billion a month.
—Perhaps Question Time should be renamed `Rhetoric Time'.
—Come on!

—There will be changes to Fightback. Senator Knowles is the John the Baptist of the changes to Fightback. She announced them on a radio program in Perth 10 days ago and totally misled the people of Western Australia about what was in Fightback. There will be other changes, of course.
—The people of Western Australia are used to being misled.

—They are by Senator Knowles, it seems. I will go through some of the rhetoric. First of all, it is very easy to describe this recession as our recession. Of course, government policy and many economists in Australia misread the signals at the time as to the depth of the recession. There is no doubt about that.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition, John Hewson, continued to misread them long after everybody else had stopped by opposing the first six interest rates cuts which we had in 1991. Senators opposite should not come in here with a whole lot of undue piety about all these issues as if they had some particular solutions and the Government has not.

The other thing I want to say to Senator Knowles—I said it last week and I will say it again—is that any new policies which the Government may or may not announce before the forthcoming election will be announced in the Government's time. They will not be announced in response to opinion polls which the Liberal Party took no notice of for a very long time, but suddenly last Monday the Liberal Party discovered that the recession was deeper than it thought and there would need to be a different response. We await that different response with interest.

As far as the employment issue is concerned, I have said on numerous occasions that employment will be alleviated when there is increased growth in the Australian economy. We are one of the few economies—I think one of only three economies—in the OECD which is actually growing at present. That growth will continue and pick up. There are no magic wands which are going to alleviate unemployment overnight. Those opposite can try to think them up as hard as they like, but they will never arrive at any magic wands which can alleviate these things overnight. I am really repeating the answers I gave to Senator Hill last week. He repeated the question; I am repeating the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Have the Government's tariff policies been developed in response to the different needs of industry sectors? Can the Minister indicate the importance of consistent economic and taxation policies that are both fair and equitable and that encourage economic growth?
—Keep a straight face on this one, John.

—I will keep a straight face. I thank Senator Macdonald for his advice; it is the first bit of any value I have received. The Government's approach to tariffs reflects the commitment of this Government to what is essentially a pragmatic approach to the problems of different industries in this country. A zero tariff approach, which was espoused at one time by the Opposition, is not one which reflects that degree of pragmatism and the differences which exist between industries.

PARA.TAB: We have announced planned and gradual phase-downs in tariff protection for manufacturing industry. We have stuck to them and we will continue to do so. For example, in the car industry we have provided a framework for continuing reform and restructure up to the year 2000. It is a policy which recognises that the automotive industry is part of a global industry in which Australia must have a niche. It is not something which is driven by ideology; it is a policy which reflects, and is reflected in, growing export performance by this industry into that global industry as a whole. Similarly, in terms of investment, we have assisted in some industries subject to restructuring with strategic assistance with investment, and we will continue to do that.

We come to this debate at an interesting time because there are all sorts of views now about industry policy, about taxation policy and so on. Senator Boswell is one who is advocating another look at tariff policy in the Opposition. The current shadow Minister does not advocate a different view of tariff policy from the one the Opposition has. The honourable member for Chisholm says the Minister is wrong. The Liberal leader in South Australia wants what he calls the `zero tariff lunacy' reviewed. David Jull wants a GST exemption for tourism packages sold overseas. Senator Knowles, as I said, has already announced her policy on the GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question did not relate at all to Opposition policy; it related to Government policy. I would ask you to enforce your previous ruling. Senator Button once again is coming into Question Time and attempting to debate Opposition policy. We will debate that any place, any time, but Question Time is not the time to do it. I ask you to bring Senator Button to order.
—I ask Senator Button not to refer to Opposition policies.

—Mr President, I was asked about the need for consistency in industry policy and, in particular, micro-industry policy. I find that the debate is being characterised at the present time by a plethora of views. Whatever policy we adopt, we now can identify who is in favour of it and who is not because of the plethora of views which exist within the Opposition.
—Yes, I am. I wrote it.
—A week before the Budget.
—If Senator Hill asks me a question I will tell him about it.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Could the Minister confirm that, despite all the social justice hand-wringing and professions of concern for the least well off; despite there being record unemployment, 420,000 families without a breadwinner and record general misery, the One Nation statement does precisely nothing for low income earners by way of tax relief or any other form of direct assistance because, as Senator Richardson, pretender to Senator Button's throne, said earlier this year, the Government has already done enough for the poor during the 1980s?

—I have not seen Senator Richardson's comment on this. Various publications of ABS have analysed household disposable incomes in Australia. Over the last few years household disposable incomes of the poorer section of the Australian community have risen significantly because of an element of social wage as well as a wages policy being in place. Both those things have happened.

PARA.TAB: Insofar as One Nation is concerned, it did not set out to address those problems. What it set out to address—and at this stage it can only be described as partially successful—was the question of employment. That is the biggest issue contributing to poverty in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister confirm that One Nation indeed proposed very substantial unfunded tax cuts directed at the middle income earners—the group that Senator Richardson said needed to be courted—and that it specifically did not propose any reduction in the lowest marginal rate? In other words, despite all the social misery and the extent to which the lower income earners in this country have been devastated over the eight or nine months since One Nation, the Government still proposes to do absolutely nothing for that group by way of tax relief.

—Senator Alston ought to have tracked the history of taxation changes in the last few years before asking that question, which is, in a sense, an ignorant question. The fact of the matter is, as I said to the honourable senator in my earlier answer, that the household disposable income of lower earning families in this country has increased significantly over the last few years. If Senator Alston has not read it, I will give him a—

—On a point of order, Mr President: pursuant to standing order 182 in relation to relevance, the question very specifically asked whether One Nation proposes any reduction in the lowest marginal tax rate. Now we have Senator Button rabbiting on about variations in income levels for low and middle income earners. It is a very specific question that requires a specific answer, and I ask you to bring him to order.
—Order! At this stage the answer is relevant.

—The One Nation tax scales were targeted on the basis of a history of improvement in household disposable income in Australia. All I am saying is that if the Opposition is about offering empty bribes, we are not. One has to look at the level of household disposable income of the families in these groups—something the Opposition did not do; something it certainly did not do when it siphoned off the bulk of its tax cuts to the mega-rich.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What response has the Australian Government made to the earthquake in Flores in Indonesia? What assistance is being provided by the Government? Is it known whether any Australians have been killed or injured?

—I am sure all Australians shared the Government's distress and concern on learning of the great loss of life, devastation and suffering which has been caused by Saturday's earthquake in Flores in eastern Indonesia. While Indonesian authorities are still assessing the full extent of the disaster, it does appear that the loss of life exceeds 1,300 people. The Prime Minister today sent a message to President Suharto, expressing sympathy on behalf of the Government and the people of Australia and indicating our willingness to assist.

PARA.TAB: There are no reports of casualties among the 12 Australian citizens who could be in the affected area. The embassy is continuing to make inquiries, including in likely tourist areas. Embassy officers travelling to the province will provide consular assistance to any Australians who may have been affected.

As to the question of Australian assistance, on learning of the devastating effects of the earthquake, Australia's Ambassador in Jakarta provided immediately to the Governor of the Province of East Nusa Tenggara an immediate grant of $A15,000 to assist in meeting very urgent food and other needs. The Australian Government's position is that we stand ready to respond quickly to any requests that we receive from the Indonesian Government for emergency assistance and also to contribute to longer term rehabilitation and reconstruction of the damaged region.

An officer of our Jakarta embassy has gone to Kupang, West Timor, today to coordinate any requests for Australian assistance. Another officer is seeking to travel to Flores on the first available flight. We are in a position to move immediately to provide an initial plane load of emergency relief supplies valued at approximately $150,000. It should not, of course, be assumed that that will be the limit of any Australian contribution, but it does depend on what we are asked to provide.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to a report in today's Age that lending for residential investment property has risen by 45 per cent in the past year. I further note the opinion of Mr Phil Roberts of the Real Estate Institute of Australia that this is `a good sign' for the economy. I ask the Minister: firstly, does he accept that increased investment in housing is in fact a bad sign for the economy because it draws funds away from productive investment; and, secondly, in view of the Prime Minister's criticism last Thursday of the failure of the Australian banks to support small- and medium-sized businesses launching new products, what economic levers remain to the Government after its wholesale deregulation and which levers will the Government use to direct investment away from speculation and towards increased productivity?

—It is certainly true to say that in Australia over many years the housing sector has usually been one of the leaders in investment after a recession. That has always been so—largely so in the past because of the lopsided structure of the productive economy in Australia and its traditional emphasis on mining and agriculture.
—Where it should be.

—Senator Panizza says, `Where it should be' because he does not know anything else. But there is nothing surprising about that. As far as the housing sector is concerned at the present time, while there have been increased signs of investment, the number of housing starts has not matched those investment intentions. Any activity in the housing sector is beneficial to an Australian economy with a lot of over-capacity in many industrial establishments and so on. So there are some benefits in a housing sector recovery. But if one looked at the economy in a detached way, one could see that it is perhaps not the most desirable form of investment. As Senator Coulter said, investment in productive activity is much more important for this country.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the Prime Minister's reference to the failure to invest by financial institutions, and particularly banks, in small- and medium-sized businesses in Australia, it is true that that is a huge problem for this country. It is a problem largely dictated by, I think, ignorance, lack of understanding and lack of knowledge in the financial sector particularly about new industries and what I would call technology intensive industries.

There are plenty of means, however, for encouraging investment in those areas, artificial though they may be. In the One Nation statement we established the so-called pooled development funds with a view to helping more high technology companies through a mechanism which would channel funds into investment in those sorts of companies. I cannot come in here and claim that it is working like a charm at this stage—it is not—but it has the capacity to do that, and these things take a little time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security explain how pensioners will benefit from last week's agreement with the States to match the Commonwealth's extension of concessions to government services from 1 April 1993?

—The decision that Senator Reynolds refers to is one that emanates from the Budget. In the Budget this year the Government decided to extend Commonwealth concessions to all pensioners, including age pensioners, disability support pensioners, sole parent pensioners and older long term unemployed beneficiaries who were 60 years and over.

PARA.TAB: The Budget also encouraged the States to follow suit by offering them some $70m to help meet the cost of extending their concessions to the same groups of people. At the Council of Australian Governments in Perth last week the States accepted the Commonwealth's $70m compensation offer. Because of that, they will be extending their concessions in line with the Commonwealth as of 1 April 1993. As a Government we have also agreed to participate in a broader review of the existing systems of concessions with the States and at the States' request.

In answer to Senator Reynolds's question about how many people will benefit, I think 370,000 pensioners and older long term unemployed people with relatively small private incomes will benefit. This will bring the total number of people who benefit and who are eligible for these concessions to some two million people.

In terms of what services will be discounted, the concessions, including transport, electricity, State health services and local government rates, will be included in addition to the already existing Commonwealth telephone allowance, hearing aid concessions, rail concessions and postal concessions. Within this decision there will also be—and Senator Tate has taken an interest in this—a capacity for pensioners to earn private income. As a consequence, they will have a double benefit.

This is an important initiative from the Government. It has brought the States into line by our offer of $70m to help meet the extension of concessions for pensioners and the long term unemployed over 60 years of age across Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell them how many people will benefit.
—Some 370,000 older Australians will benefit from this decision by the Government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. In view of the Minister's determination to override the States in industrial relations matters, does he intend to extend this intervention to workers compensation, particularly following difficulties experienced by some States in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us define our terms to begin with. There is an item of legislation before this chamber which I cannot comment on. The effect of it is not to override the States; it will open a right that exists now at law just a little further. We have foreshadowed that we intend to enact ILO conventions. Senator Baume will know that the ILO is a United Nations agency. While Australia, as a developed country, observes, for example, World Health Organisation health standards, it is our view that minimum labour standards declared for the ILO should be enacted in law in Australia to provide a safety net protection for minimum wages, equal pay and unfair dismissals and redundancy provisions.

PARA.TAB: This question relates to workers compensation. It is not our intention to extend by legislation a national workers compensation scheme or anything of that nature. We propose to have Comcare—the Commonwealth's own compensation and rehabilitation scheme—compete in the private sector in so far as public sector companies have the benefit of its services so that those private sector companies can, if they choose, have access to Comcare on the basis of providing fairness and equality. But it is not our intention to do anything about a national compensation, accident prevention or rehabilitation scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister's answer mean that the Government has no capacity to proceed against companies that fail to pay their workers' compensation insurance premiums, such as the $150,000 now subject to a statement of claim in the Supreme Court of New South Wales by New Zealand Insurance Ltd against Brown and Hatton Rural Pty Ltd—a company half-owned by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating—which is part of its total unpaid amount of $240,000 allegedly owing in premiums for which no provision was made by way of contingent liability in the latest unaudited, unsigned annual return from the company?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Baume is asking me to do—and to some extent what he has done—is comment on a case that is apparently before a court. I would, of course, ritually and rightly decline to do that because the appropriate thing is for the court to make a decision based on the evidence that is brought before it. But what Senator Baume has also done is continue with what Senator Button described as his `snail trail' all around the Senate on the question of the Prime Minister's interests in a piggery.
—Just reporting the fact that you people try to hide.

—Senator Baume may well have used this question to continue his smear campaign. He knows that it has nothing to do with workers compensation. It is simply another example of the Opposition being prepared to stoop to whatever lengths of smear and blackguardry it chooses inside the chamber, but never being prepared to step outside and repeat those accusations.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. With regard to my Question on Notice No. 2420 and the answer provided on Thursday by the Minister for Defence, I ask: firstly, what, if any, secrecy provisions still apply to present and former members of the Australian Defence Force which would prevent them from speaking about the sinking of the HMAS Sydney in World War II and the subsequent investigation of that sinking? Secondly, what, if any, secrecy provisions apply to present and former members of the Australian Public Service which would prevent them from speaking out about that sinking and the subsequent investigation?

—I understand that the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, has conveyed an answer to a question on notice from Senator Chamarette. Unfortunately, I am not familiar with either the question or the answer. In relation to the question that she directs to me, insofar as it is seeking some sort of definitive opinion as to whether any particular secrecy provision under Commonwealth legislation applies to the circumstances of any possible disclosure by those who may have some knowledge of the sinking of HMAS Sydney, I cannot offer such a definite opinion.

PARA.TAB: However, it would be wise for the persons concerned and their legal advisers—I do not say this in a threatening way; I simply refer to their willingness to adhere to the legislation of this Parliament concerning secrecy—to have regard to section 70 of the Crimes Act. This section applies to both past and present members of the Australian Public Service. It requires them to observe secrecy in relation to matters which have come to their attention or knowledge in the course of carrying out their service to the Australian community as part of that Public Service structure.

I believe that this is a matter where legal advice should certainly be sought in order that, in some sense of obligation to disclose, there is not an unwitting trespassing on the Crimes Act, such as would put these people in a vulnerable position whereby the full force of that Act might be brought to bear upon them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the burgeoning Australian telecommunications industry. This sunrise industry, which is one of the smart industries for Australia's future, had a 6.6 per cent growth rate last year. It has a potential export market of $2 billion a year and further potential to employ many thousands of Australians. With the granting of the mobile licence to Optus, and a third licence, Australia will be forced into the European digital system, GSM, for which Australian manufacturers will have to pay over $1,000 per unit to use, making the fully imported made-up unit the only viable option. I ask the Minister: why is the Government adopting a system that will introduce a monopoly for the European manufacturer and force the Australian mobile phone manufacturers into an uncompetitive position, thereby losing an Australian industry of the future, with its jobs and export earnings that Australia so desperately needs?

—That assertion is not correct. I am certainly familiar with its source. Regrettably, that assertion is as incorrect as the first assertion that was made by Voxson. Voxson is an Australian company which recently produced some full page advertisements. Among a number of statements in those full page advertisements was the statement that Voxson is a successful Australian company exporting significant amounts of technology overseas. That is correct. Voxson is a company which I and the Government would certainly like to see prosper.

PARA.TAB: Regrettably, that is the only statement made in the full page advertisements that Voxson ran that was correct.As was then pointed out to Voxson—and which the company apparently now has accepted—its assertion that Australia would be prevented from accessing the GSM technology in terms of manufacturing simply is not correct. General GATT provisions would have prevented that anyway, but a specific addendum was, in fact, included in the memorandum of understanding that was reached with Australia that specifically excludes Australia from any provisions that would have confined that technology for manufacture in Europe. Now that that has been demonstrated to be untrue, Voxson apparently is asserting that these units will cost X amount of dollars in terms of premiums that manufacturers will have to pay on them.

The fact is that the Government accepted a recommendation from Austel that GSM be the first standard adopted by Australia—and Senator Boswell might like to note that New Zealand has also accepted GSM as being the first standard. Of course, one of the reasons that Austel recommended GSM is that it enables multiple operators to access the mobile system, whereas the current analog technology confines those operators to two. Senator Boswell referred to Europe. Fifteen European companies have accepted GSM as their digital technology. I understand that so has Hong Kong and, on advice given to me, three significant countries in our region are about to adopt GSM as being their technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are those countries?

—I understand that Thailand and India are about to adopt GSM. As I said, Hong Kong has also done so. New Zealand has also adopted GSM as the technology, in accordance with the Australian Government's position of adopting that recommendation from Austel.

PARA.TAB: As I said when I began this answer, regrettably the assertions—at no doubt great expense—that Voxson made in its full page advertisements have been demonstrated to be incorrect. As to the specific amounts of money that have been asserted by Senator Boswell in Question Time today, I will have that matter checked out. I would suspect, considering that such a premium would make the units unsaleable, that that is also incorrect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate. Is the Minister aware of the difficulties encountered by some individuals when attempting to argue their case on welfare payments issues, especially when they seek to appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal against decisions of the Department of Social Security? What action is the Government taking to ensure that individuals who believe that they have a case are assisted to put that case effectively?

—Yes, I am aware of the sort of problem that Senator West speaks of. It is important that people be able to appeal against decisions of the Department of Social Security. These decisions, of course, can have an impact on their capacity to lead a life within the community, where they can participate through having access to reasonable community support in situations where they find themselves, for example, unemployed or disabled or in some such vulnerable situation.

PARA.TAB: For that reason, the Government is funding 14 welfare rights organisations throughout Australia to launch a new program to ensure that people can have access to their rights. This will be carried, really, through the community legal centre network. This is an important network which enables people in their neighbourhoods who have a real understanding of the needs of the community, whether it is perhaps specialising in tenancy law or social security law, matters which the major legal firms and even ordinary suburban practices do not much specialise in, to provide this sort of information in a way which is accessible, friendly, usually after hours, and with tremendous input from lawyers who contribute voluntarily their time to help on the rosters of these community legal centres.

I hope they survive. The Government has ensured that there is plenty of funding for the network of community legal centres throughout Australia. It is disappointing to see that the Opposition intends to strip $2.4m away from the community legal centres as part of its program to strip $10m from legal aid under the Fightback program. I regard this as extremely—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—$10m altogether, just in administration. That is what the Opposition says.
—What has that got to do with the question?

—This is important. This money supports the community legal centres. These centres are where the welfare rights organisations will help to provide information and assistance to social security beneficiaries or those who find that they have not succeeded in their social security claims.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the community legal centre network—the legal aid network—is an important part of creating a just society and a fairer Australia; one in which people have access to legal advice and representation when they are without the financial resources necessary to obtain it for themselves. I believe this ought to be supported. I certainly hope that the $10m that would be stripped away from legal aid by Dr Hewson under Fightback can be restored in the announcement on Friday, but I am not holding my breath.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. At a time when there are now more than 420,000 families without a breadwinner and almost one million people unemployed, would the Minister care to explain to the Senate what value the taxpayer has derived since May this year from Senator Richardson being present in the Senate chamber for less than one hour every week over the last seven months while he has been busily engaged in private income earning activities, including a $100,000 advance on a book that he is writing?

—I have not made any assessment of the extent to which Senator Richardson has been absent; that is a matter which he negotiates with the Whip. I think he has done that and there have been explanations of his absence. In so far as the question relates to taxpayer derived benefit, I am not sure that taxpayers are ecstatic about the existence of any of us in here, and I do not think any particular circumstance arises from his absence which is different from the rest of us.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Firstly, given the convention that close to an election governments should not take action to bind a future government, why is it so urgent that the Government legislate now for the One Nation tax cuts which will not be fully implemented until 1996? Secondly, given that we simply cannot afford these cuts, should not the Government do the responsible thing, disengage itself from an obscene tax auction with the Opposition and abandon, or at least defer, these unfair and irresponsible proposals?
—I am not in a position to comment on Government policy in the terms in which Senator Kernot has put it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make the point again, for Senator Short's sake, in case he does not understand. The Government's policy on this matter has been decided. That is all I have to say about it. The Government's policy is in existence. On this issue which Senator Kernot has asked me about, the Government's policy has been announced by the Treasurer and there is no point in me or anybody else—except, perhaps, Senator Short—commenting on that. I will direct the question of the urgency of the legislation to the Treasurer and obtain an answer from him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and relates to the transcript of Mr Keating's speech to BC Alcatel in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Growth of around four per cent or so will bring unemployment down. It is also quite achievable.
Has he also seen a transcript of Senator Richardson's meeting with Meet the Press? Senator Richardson said:
Well anyone who made a prediction of four per cent growth in the immediate future would I think be joking.

In view of the fact that I think Senator Button shares Senator Richardson's view, I ask Senator Button exactly what the forecasts of growth are and, if he has some forecasts, could he please tell Mr Keating about them.

TALK.START.PARA: —These things are very easily taken out of context, particularly by honourable senators with idle hands such as Senator Macdonald. He comes in here day after day, yet I think this is his first question for months. He has obviously been working hard on the transcripts. The Prime Minister was right when he said that a growth rate of 4 per cent would help bring down unemployment. I have made that point in Question Time on numerous occasions in the past week, but perhaps Senator Macdonald was dozing off at the time.

PARA.TAB: The current growth predictions for this Budget year are 3 per cent—at the end of the year. That is the figure which is in the Budget. The Government sees no reason to alter it. If, following the meetings of the joint economic forecasting group, there is considered to be a need for a change one way or another in that Budget forecast, then the Government will announce it, at that time.

Senator Richardson is also right in saying that, in the immediate future, as I think he said—this quarter or next quarter—there is no prospect of attaining a 4 per cent growth rate. Anybody who is realistic about that would recognise that. But the two statements are not inconsistent for the reasons I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Labor Party have any plans to try to achieve those sorts of growth rates; and does it have any plans at all to achieve any fall in unemployment, which is disastrously high at the present time and which impacts upon almost one million of our fellow Australians?

—In the medium to longer term we expect the economy to get back to growth rates of the order which this Government produced in the 1980s. The honourable senator speaks for a political party which never produced a growth rate of more than 2 per cent.
—That is not true.

—In the 1970s? What was the average growth rate? The then Government might have got a one-off year occasionally but that is the average in the 1970s. The answer to the honourable senator's supplementary question has been given by me in Question Time a dozen times in the last 10 days. I do not propose to repeat it.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations considering detonating a big bang to the Australian industrial relations system? Will the Government continue to protect the award system on which millions of Australian workers rely for a fair wage and fair conditions of work? What would happen to the people who are entering the job market for the first time or who change jobs under a deregulatory big bang approach to industrial relations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Virtually since Federation, Australia has resolved its industrial disputes by enabling the disputant parties to have access to an arbitration system which has meant that an arbitrator, in default of agreement, or in default of conciliation, has decided on the merits of the case what the basic rates of pay and conditions of work should be, and made an award to express that. We are proposing to continue with that situation because we believe it provides a fair foundation for minimum rates of wage and award conditions to apply in Australia, and a foundation that provides security for workers and employers in order that they can then go about creating an improved workplace culture, as they are doing with the now 600 enterprise agreements that have been registered, covering 15 per cent of the Australian work force, and growing.

PARA.TAB: It seems to us that to throw people out of that system, providing very little security, does not enable the productivity gains that are possible to be achieved. So we are not in favour of a big bang. Nor are we in favour, in default of an umpire being able to decide what is fair, of prescribing a rate of $3 or $3.50 an hour for young workers. Nor are we in favour, in default of an umpire being able to prescribe what is fair, of new entrants to the work force being able to be forced onto any type of individual work contract that their employer particularly wants. Nor are we in favour, in the absence of an umpire being able to prescribe what is fair, of having good employers in this country being forced to take action to reduce rates of pay where they do not want to because bad employers who are in competition with them adopt a narrow cost cutting view of simply reducing wages and increasing costs. Nor are we in favour, because we support a system that is fair, and with access to an umpire, of narrow cost cutting without training, without education for skill, and without the improvement of the workplace culture to make it more productive. That narrow cost cutting would simply make workers poorer and the living standards of Australians lower in an effort vaguely to compete with the low wage areas of Asia.

We are not in favour of the big bang approach by the Kennett Government and we are not in favour of the big bang approach by the Opposition. Of course, the Opposition and the Kennett Government are at one when it comes to industrial relations policy. It may be that some of the events in Victoria are uncomfortable for the Opposition; nevertheless they show how the Opposition's policy would work in real life were it ever imposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister inform the Senate what action the Government is taking to implement ILO conventions to protect the award system and the wages and conditions of workers who change jobs or who are entering the labour force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Monday, the Prime Minister met the Premiers in Perth and told them that the Government would consult with State Premiers about ILO conventions. I have invited all the State Ministers of labour to a meeting in Canberra this Wednesday morning so that we can begin that consultative process. The Government intends to legislate into law those ILO conventions that have been adopted by Australia and by all the States regarding minimum rates of pay and equal pay. It will also adopt the convention dealing with unfair dismissals and redundancy and legislate to bring those standards into Australian law as a further safety net and protection.

PARA.TAB: These are minimum international labour standards; they guarantee that in particular cases where coalition governments may wish to impose their version of exploitation on Australian workers, there is some fundamental, basic human rights protection against unfair dismissal, a guarantee of equal pay and of minimum wage rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Since taxation determinations are only Tax Office conclusions, contain no analysis and at times can be misleading, has the Australian Tax Office a process of further evaluating taxation determinations with a more rigorous analysis together with supporting arguments such that all determinations will ultimately become formal, public rulings?
—In part I concede the point. I am not sure that I can generalise about it, but Senator Watson's question is in the form of a suggestion which I will pass on to the Treasurer and obtain his views.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Has the Government noted the charging regime which is employed by most general practitioners? Can the Government indicate whether it supports general practice in an environment in which these charging patterns can continue?

—I have noticed that, according to the most recent available figures, around 73 per cent of all GP services are bulkbilled and around 80 per cent of all GP services are charged at or below the schedule fee. I think that shows the effect of competition and the effect of GPs choosing—in a socially just way—to make provision for bulkbilling, as they provide the primary health care for so many Australians. Of course, under the Fightback proposals, we know that only pensioners and health care cardholders would be able to get bulkbilling from their GPs. There are 17 million Australians and only four million pensioners and health care cardholders who would get bulkbilling. It would be compulsory for GPs not to offer that bulkbilling to other Australians.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the second part of the question is concerned, it is quite clear that we very much support general practice. Some $8m is being provided for practice enhancement grants to assist GPs in accredited practices to improve their patient care. That will be provided in an ongoing way in order to strengthen the provision of that primary health care to Australians. In addition, some $8m will be available for a rural incentives program to relocate GPs to rural areas and to better support those GPs already making a commitment to rural service. I think this is well epitomised in my home State where the University of Tasmania is establishing in Launceston a chair of community medicine—I think it is called primary health care and rural health care—which embraces both elements of that need to ensure that our future generations of doctors are well trained in the provision of that type of medical service.

I believe it is extremely important that we support those GPs who wish to continue the practice of bulkbilling their patients. Bulkbilling has led to an enormous number of services being dealt with that way by the community under the Medicare principles. It is extremely important that those Australians who support Medicare, and seven out of 10 do, understand that the provision of that sort of choice for their doctors will continue under Medicare but it will not continue under Fightback.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. The Minister will recall that the week before last Senator Crowley asked him about the possibility of a connection between private insurance and the rate of caesarean section. Is the Minister aware that for the last six years the rebate for caesarean section has been the same as for natural delivery and that there is no financial incentive for any private obstetrician to perform a caesarean section? Does he agree with Senator Crowley, who said on the Daybreak program the following day that public hospitals such as Crown Street Hospital in Sydney provide `state of the art excellent quality obstetric care'?

—I am aware, in relation to the provision of care by gynaecologists and obstetricians to their female patients who are expecting the birth of a child, that carrying out a caesarean is a matter very much for medical judgment. Nevertheless, figures available from those who compiled these statistics in an absolutely objective way did show a correlation between an above average incidence of the provision of this particular method of assisting a woman to give birth and the taking out of private health insurance by the woman concerned. That led the doctor in charge of that particular college within New South Wales, whose name I cannot recall, to say that amongst other things the question of financial incentive would be a matter of concern which would need to be examined. I simply said that I believe it is important that all such temptations be removed from the field.
—That is not so.

—That was not apparent to the doctor who commented, and it was not Dr Crowley. This doctor was from the relevant college of obstetricians or gynaecologists in New South Wales and he indicated that he thought that could be an incentive which could tempt a doctor to make a decision which would otherwise not be justified. For that reason I certainly shared that concern. I believe it is a matter which any government or any community should be concerned about and I believe that—
—Dr Refshauge?

—It was not Dr Refshauge. It was a doctor whose name I will provide at the end of Question Time if the honourable senator wishes. I believe it is a matter of concern which needs to be further attended to in the light of the figures, which were objectively assessed by a national institute of reputation.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I also asked about Senator Crowley's statement that Crown Street Hospital in Sydney provided `state of the art excellent quality obstetric care'. Is the Minister aware that Crown Street Hospital in Sydney closed five years ago.
—What I am aware of is that on 6 July 1945 a particularly important Australian was born at the Crown Street Hospital and he is standing here in the Senate at this moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and relates to the wine industry. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the recent Australian and European Commission agreement to facilitate and promote the wine trade? Will this agreement improve access for Australian wines to the discerning markets of Europe? If so what is the potential for increased exports from this very important value adding industry for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a briefing from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, who announced on 6 December that an agreement had been reached with the European Commission to improve access for Australian wines to Europe. The agreement includes the phasing out of the use of European geographical names. Names such as hock and white bordeaux will be phased out in the next few years. It is expected that others, such as champagne and chablis, will be phased out over a much longer period—possibly well into the next century—so that producers and consumers have time to adjust to the changes.

PARA.TAB: Many Australian wine names in future will be identified with Australian geographical regions. There will be a drop in the number of tests on Australian wines by Europeans from the current eight to three, and there will be an acceptance of the Australian winemaking practice of blending wines from different regions and different grape varieties.

The wine industry target for annual exports by the year 2000 is valued at $1 billion, with more than half of these exports going to Europe. Exports of Australian wines for the year 1990-91 were valued at $243m, of which $104m went to Europe. Imports were valued at $46m.

Under the workplace reform program a grant of $100,000 was made on Thursday 10 December for the Winemakers Federation of Australia and four participating companies: Hardy's, Penfolds, Orlando-Wyndham and Petaluma. The purpose of the grant is to assist their drive for world competitiveness through organisational change, benchmarking, consultation and quality assurance. The changes introduced by these companies will be used as models to assist other companies planning to introduce workplace change. In other words, under Labor there is some assistance to the winemaking industry to help it become the world's best. Unfortunately, if the Opposition came to power, those policies would be abolished and that assistance would be removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the fact that the official unemployment rate is now a record 11.4 per cent. In the light of the Government's Budget forecast of an average unemployment rate during 1992-93 of 10.5 per cent, how far must the official unemployment rate drop between now and June 1993 for this forecast to be attained? Given that unemployment continues to rise even before the advent of this year's school leavers, does the Government have the courage to stop misleading the Australian public by releasing a revised version of its totally unrealistic and wildly inaccurate Budget unemployment forecasts?

—Senator Patterson will already be aware that the Treasurer has made some public comment on the employment forecasts and has said that by the middle of this year—I do not remember the precise figure he mentioned, but he thought that the figure mentioned in the Budget was on the low side—it would probably be higher than that. I will check that figure for Senator Patterson and provide her with that information as soon as I can.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I ask whether the Minister has seen today's Sydney Morning Herald editorial, which says:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there is nothing inherently radical about changing the actual words of the Oath.

That is, the oath of allegiance. In the light of uncertainty about the heirs and successors to Queen Elizabeth II following recent circumstances, will the Government consider proposing the new `true-blue Allegiance Oath', to quote the title of today's Sydney Morning Herald editorial?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all senators would agree that it is a sad occasion when apparently irreconcilable differences have led Prince Charles and Princess Diana to announce their separation, but I believe there are more fundamental matters at stake as far as the rules of succession are concerned than determining who the possible heir to Queen Elizabeth might be. In fact, apparently that will not be a great problem unless Charles divorces and remarries.

PARA.TAB: But, putting that to one side, there are more fundamental matters at stake about the discriminatory nature of the rules relating to succession based on discrimination on the grounds of sex and discrimination on the grounds of religion. But, in relation to the question of an oath of allegiance, it must be the case that if we can simply have an oath of allegiance which includes a pledge of loyalty to Australia and its people, which recognises our common sharing of democratic values, and which includes a pledge to respect the rights and liberties of our fellow Australians and to obey the laws of Australia, I think that would be such an expression of loyalty to this country, its democratic values and its people as would then put any expression of allegiance to the Crown in its proper perspective.

There is room for a proposal such as this. Dr Hewson hinted at some elements of it in a recent speech, taking up a theme that had been put forward to the people by the Prime Minister in a speech to the book publishers, I think, about halfway through the winter. There is room for the proposal that Senator Crowley speaks of—a new oath of allegiance being fashioned for the people of Australia, in relation to citizenship, in particular. All senators are very well aware of the great emotion that is involved when people change their allegiance and become citizens of Australia. If we can find a more appropriate form of words which embodies that particular commitment to the people of Australia, I think that would be a worthwhile project and enterprise and Senator Crowley would certainly give consideration to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister in a position to be able to comment publicly on the negotiations for the ADF component for Somalia? If those negotiations are in train, will some consideration be given to putting an infantry component into that contingent, particularly from 3rd Brigade, subject, of course, to advice from DIO on that matter? Would the Minister consider putting together some sort of composite reserve unit because, apart from observer status, the reserves have no opportunity to serve on UN peacekeeping forces?

—Whatever the Government has in mind with regard to Somalia, of course it will take the advice of DIO. That can be taken as a matter of fact. As Senator Evans indicated in the Senate some days ago, the Government has under consideration what sort of contribution we will make to Somalia. The issue is somewhat complicated by the fact that there are really two distinct areas of concentration. The first one is Operation Restore Hope and the second one is UNOSOM. Many countries around the globe will have to consider whether they subscribe to both, to one or to none. This Government has a responsibility to make sure that whatever contribution is made is a balanced one. These matters are under consideration and will be finalised at Cabinet tomorrow.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the light of the attack over the weekend by the Khmer Rouge on the UN installation in Cambodia, is the Cambodian peace plan still on track, as the Minister calls it? Is the Minister still optimistic as to the outcome of that plan?

—The incident reported by today's media actually occurred some time ago on 6 December, at which time a UN camp in a village near the provincial capital of Kompong Thom did come under direct attack by the KR. The camp was occupied by UN electoral supervisors and military personnel. No casualties are reported. This is the first time that UNTAC personnel have come under direct attack from the KR. According to a UN spokesman, the Khmer Rouge maintains that it will not guarantee safety for UNTAC personnel in areas it claims until the UN abides by Khmer Rouge conditions for the implementation of the peace settlement. Following, as it did, only two days after the release of six military observers detained by the Khmer Rouge for a number of days, this attack represents a further expression of Khmer Rouge policy which directly contravenes its obligations as a signatory to the Paris accords. It is a particularly unacceptable violation of those obligations.

PARA.TAB: The Khmer Rouge continues to repeat its unacceptable statement of conditions for cooperation. It has to be assumed, as I have said previously, that the Khmer Rouge will continue not to cooperate in the political phase—the electoral phase—of the peace plan. Of course, UN resolution No. 792 was recently passed in that knowledge and with that expectation. We have to anticipate low level cease-fire violations and interference by the Khmer Rouge with the peace process continuing. We will certainly continue to monitor that for any evidence that the Khmer Rouge is increasing its activity towards the kind of full scale military action which, alone, would require re-examination of the peace process.

Might I say in passing that the reports concerning a possible attack on Angkor Wat, which I have seen in the press in the last day or two, are not supported by any information that we have at this stage. But we are seeking further information on that.

We have never sought to deny the risks that are associated with this kind of peacekeeping operation. It has to be anticipated that there will be cease-fire violations and sporadic episodes of violence. I repeat that there is no ground for believing at this stage, for all the reasons I have previously spelt out, that there will be any more substantial military challenge to the basic elements of the UN peace plan. If there is such a challenge, that will be the time for the international community, including Australia, to consider whether to continue with this operation or, alternatively—if that cannot be continued within its present form—to change the UN's mandate.

I remain generally confident that the peace process is on track—the repatriation continues, the registration of voters continues and the operation of the UN administration in Phnom Penh continues. We can only hope that that situation will prevail into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the attacks upon UN helicopters, to which the Minister referred a week or so ago, and now attacks such as the one upon UN installations, and the presumption that one must make that attacks during the election process itself are therefore likely to occur, when will the Minister or the Prime Minister make a statement to the Parliament about the changed role of the Australian force in Cambodia to that of protecting the electoral process, which was not the purpose for which it was sent in the first instance?

—There is no change in the role of the UN contingent or the Australian component of it. It is a peacekeeping mission that is designed to monitor, supervise and verify the Paris peace settle-ment. It always has to be assumed in peacekeeping—
—It is based on a national—

—I know that Senator Hill loves sitting like Madame Defarge beside the guillotine waiting for the next head to roll in order that he can derive some little frisson of pleasure from something which he can then claim to be a failure of international policy or Australian policy. I have no sympathy for that approach. I know that the Australian troops in Cambodia are there in the knowledge that there is a job to be done. They are very proud of the job that they are doing, and Australia is very proud of them.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—During Question Time today, in response to a question from Senator Boswell about the GSM technology, I stated that we had discovered that statements made by Voxson in full page advertisements in Australian newspapers that Australia would be prevented completely from manufacturing GSM technology were incorrect. I have sought further advice from Austel as to the claims made today that a premium of $1,000 per unit would have to be paid. I have discovered, on advice from Austel, that those claims are also profoundly incorrect.

PARA.TAB: Austel has advised me that the intellectual property rights to the A5 algorithm belong to France Telecom. The A5 algorithm is the mathematical confidentiality key that is manufactured as a chip in which the intellectual property rights for this technology are based. The algorithm will be released royalty free to all approved A5 countries. Australia is such a country.

A manufacturer could produce GSM equipment with the A5 algorithm subject to its signing a confidentiality agreement with a GSM operator, such as AOTC or Optus. Once the manufacturer has signed the agreement, it will be supplied with a copy of the algorithm in mathematical form. It can then manufacture the chips itself or purchase them from other companies.
Voxson claims to have received a quote of over $1,000 for the purchase of a chip.
Opposition senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the advice that Austel has provided me with. Any manufacturer which continues to charge such amounts will be unable to compete. As the number of endorsed manufacturers grows, the cost of the encrypted chips will fall through the simple mechanism of market competition. I reiterate that the manufacturer can manufacture these chips royalty free, if it chooses to do so, rather than buy them from a manufacturer. I have been further advised by Austel that in France it is now possible to buy a complete handset for $A1,100. Obviously, someone is selling chips for a great deal less than $1,000.
—I ask that further questions be placed on notice.
—Mr President, I seek leave to ask you a question in relation to the broadcast of Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been raised with me by constituents that the live broadcast of Question Time is being cut off at 3 o'clock, notwithstanding the fact that Question Time may not have concluded. I understand that the program that follows is a very important educational program, but I also understand that if Question Time were to continue being televised past 3 o'clock it would be contrary to the arrangements or the understanding that was had by the Presiding Officers. I wonder whether you would be kind enough to inquire into this matter and report back to the chamber?
—Senator O'Chee did raise this matter with me. I have not had time to find out the answers, but I will investigate it as soon as I can and give him a reply as soon as possible.
—Pursuant to standing order 190, I seek leave to make a personal explanation arising from Senator Button's response to my question during Question Time today.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter does not particularly worry me but Senator Button quite often uses a grubby little trick when the television cameras are on this segment of Parliament. Senator Button said to me today, `This is the first question you have asked for months' or he says `You never ask a question about your portfolio'. He has made these types of comments on many occasions to many of my colleagues.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, with respect, I think it behoves you to do something about this. We do not have the opportunity of responding to those types of comments on television, as Senator Button well knows. I find his comments quite offensive. Senator Button knows, as do we all, that the only reason we on this side can never get questions up is that the Government takes an inordinate time to answer questions. It deliberately wastes time so that we are restricted in the number of questions we can ask.

Senator Button well knows that I, and most of my colleagues, try to get questions up every day, but the system simply does not allow for it. I find it quite offensive when Senator Button comes in with grubby asides such as, `This is the first question you have asked for months'.

Mr President, I give notice that, if that sort of thing is allowed to occur, I will preface all my questions in future with this comment: `Senator Button, are you sober enough'—because he is usually drunk—`to understand the sort of question that I am going to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Macdonald, you know that is unparliamentary. I ask you to withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still a reflection.

—I will withdraw it but, in doing so, it makes the exact point that I am making to you: Senator Button is allowed to get away with making those very offensive comments to me, yet if I call him a drunk, you make me withdraw it—quite rightly, too. If it applies to me it should apply to him, particularly when he knows it is not my fault that I cannot get questions up every day. Mr President, I ask that you do something about that; I ask you to call this grubby little tactic into account every time it happens, because if something is not done about it, he is going to get it back the way we give it.
—Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Do you seek leave to take note of what has just been said? I spoke to the Leader of the Opposition and I have a statement to make before I ask whether there are any motions to take note of answers.
—I seek leave to make a brief statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the Crown or Crown Street?

—The clever Opposition does appreciate that my remarks are to do with the Crown Street Hospital and the clear implication from Senator Herron's question that I did not know Crown Street Hospital had been closed for five years. As a point of clarification, and quite contrary to the misrepresentation Senator Herron gave in this place, the point I was making at the time was that Crown Street had earned a reputation in the days that it was open and functioning.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is exactly what is going to happen to the Queen Victoria Hospital in my own State—it is about to close. Public obstetrics has enjoyed a fantastic reputation across this country. One of the hospitals that helped establish that reputation is Crown Street. It is very well known; it is very famous with an international reputation. I am sorry to disappoint the Opposition. I think it is important to make clear that I certainly knew what I was talking about—
—Mr President, I rise to a point of order. This is now a debate on obstetric hospitals and their record in Australian medical—

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No. That was a personal explanation. There is no doubt about that at all. The point of order is that this has gone beyond the terms allowed for a personal explanation. If Senator Crowley wants to take note and take up part of the limited time that the Labor Party conspired with the Democrats to impose upon us, that is the appropriate time to do so and not now.

—I was under the impression that Senator Crowley asked permission to make a statement. I will check that, but I thought she asked to make a statement. I am glad some other senators say that too. But if it was a personal explanation—

—I will conclude my remarks. The point is that there was a very clear intent and implication from Senator Herron's question that I did not know what I was talking about when I mentioned Crown Street Hospital. The Opposition would want to conclude that at the best of times and that is now its consensus implication. Those opposite are now collectively committing the same intent to deceive the population.

PARA.TAB: I say for the record that I certainly did know that Crown Street had closed. I merely used that hospital's record to establish the reputation of public hospital medicine in this country.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Opposition cannot cope, I would at least like to make it clear that I can.
—I seek leave to make a statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts are on this tape, which I obtained from the Parliamentary Library, of the interview Senator Crowley gave to the Daybreak program. I seek leave to table it and let the facts speak for themselves.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bunch of hyenas.
—Order! Senator Crowley, I ask you to withdraw that comment.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —After Question Time on Thursday, 10 December, I undertook to respond to matters raised by Senator Crane and Senator Bishop relating to unparliamentary language.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane referred to my statement on Wednesday, 9 December in which I indicated that I intended to uphold the rule against unparliamentary language, particularly in relation to statements which accuse a senator of lying or of deliberately making statements which a senator knows to be untrue which have always been held to be contrary to standing order 193. Senator Crane indicated that, during an answer to a question by Senator Baume, Senator Button twice used the expression `demonstrably untrue'. I stated that I did not think that Senator Button was referring directly to statements made by a senator, but that I would check the Hansard transcript.

Having looked at the Hansard transcript, I find that Senator Button stated that an allegation made by Senator Baume was `quite wrong—a demonstrable untruth'. It was this form of words which gave me the impression that Senator Button was not referring directly to statements made by Senator Baume. Senator Button went on to say:

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Baume tried it again with a second demonstrable untruth.
Had I distinctly heard this expression, I would have regarded it as unparliamentary, as it does imply that a senator has deliberately made a statement knowing it to be untrue.

PARA.TAB: It is very difficult, however, to distinctly hear everything said and to make a judgment as to whether it is unparliamentary or contains an offensive imputation while there is a great deal of noise in the chamber as there has been in Question Time, particularly last week. If senators wish to have the rule against unparliamentary language consistently enforced, they should maintain a proper level of decorum in the chamber so that the Chair can hear what is being said.

Senator Bishop suggested that the statement which I have repeatedly made—that it is not a matter for the Chair to determine whether statements made by Ministers are accurate or truthful and the rule against accusing a senator of lying—in some way prevents senators challenging statements which they believe to be untrue. This conclusion does not in any way follow from these principles. If a senator believes that a statement made by another senator is not true, the statement can be rebutted in subsequent debate. This can be done without accusing a senator of lying, that is, deliberately making a statement which the senator knows to be untrue.

If a senator actually wishes to take the serious step of accusing another senator of deliberately making a statement which the other senator knows to be untrue, that can be done only by way of a substantive motion, for example, a motion of censure or a motion asking the Senate to find a senator guilty of contempt. Such a motion would be subject to the normal procedural limitations relating to notice or leave.

This leads to the second point raised by Senator Bishop, which is the principle referred to at page 1004 of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, that making a deliberately misleading statement may be treated as a contempt of the Senate. It is not, however, for the Chair to determine whether a senator has been guilty of such a contempt. That is a matter that can be determined only by the Senate itself on a substantive motion being moved.

I point out that the precedent for the principle that a deliberately misleading statement is a contempt is the Profumo case, in which the House of Commons declared that Mr Profumo was guilty of a contempt in making statements to the House which he knew not to be true. It is important to note that the only way in which the House was able to establish that Mr Profumo knew that his statements were untrue was that he admitted lying to the House. I suggest that, short of that extreme circumstance, it would be inadvisable for senators to raise allegations of contempt against each other. When they believe that incorrect statements have been made, they should make rebuttals in debate without using offensive language.

I also point out that in the course of her remarks Senator Bishop stated that `there are many instances in this place where Ministers and others on the other side of the chamber deliberately tell untruths', and that `members of the Government front bench repeatedly tell fibs'. These remarks were also unparliamentary, but again, due to the noise in the chamber at the time, I was not able to hear them distinctly. During Question Time today, knowing that I was making a statement, I ignored two such interjections, as I have done on some other occasions.
It is up to all senators to maintain proper standards of language and behaviour in the chamber, and once again I appeal to all senators to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the President's statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, whilst your dissertation in that statement is interesting and deals with the question of contempt in an interesting historical context, it leaves unresolved the problem which faces the Senate. We have the position where statements are frequently made on the other side of the chamber—you are probably going to tell me I am being unparliamentary again—which are simply not true. You are placing us on this side of the House in the position of being unable to say that such statements are untrue either at the time they are made or in debate subsequently.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you say in your statement that we are able to rebut. If somebody stands up on the other side of the House and says, `Black is white', how is one to refute that except to say, `What you say is not true.'? You are leaving us in a quandary which is simply unacceptable. There is no way that you are leaving open to people an absolute and confrontationist rebuttal of any statement that is made by a Minister or a member sitting on the other side of the chamber.

I would ask you again, Mr President, for some sort of workable ruling which makes it possible for members to make quite plain at the time that, in the consideration of a member, a statement being made is not a truthful statement. Again, you will probably tell me I am being unparliamentary, yet how is that meaning and argument to be put if we are to be denied the use of straightforward English language?

With regard to the point I raised on contempt, I was using Odgers simply to illustrate the seriousness with which the problem of untruths being used in the Parliament to mislead the Parliament is indeed considered. Yet we are in the position of basically being gagged from making a rebuttal of a statement which I know, which any of my colleagues know or which people in the wider world may know, is simply not true. How are we to rebut?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am formally supporting the motion to take note of your statement although I do not support anything said up to now in support of that motion. That which you have said is important today. I think the Parliament gets itself into some of these convoluted situations because, frankly, we are altogether too precious about what we allow to be said in this place.
—You are precious.
—I have never ever objected to anything anybody said about me in here.
—On the contrary, I can show you plenty of times.
—I have never sought to have anything withdrawn on any occasion.
—That is a different question. You are being quite precious now.

—I have disagreed with it in debate.That is entirely proper, and that is exactly the point to which I wish to come. We are all too precious about that which can be said in this place. I have the general view that those things which can be said legally in public should legally be able to be said in here, and those things which we can say in the street should be able to be said in the Parliament. That means that language which is not lawful—
—What about in the gutter?

—Some expertise on the gutter is being expressed. I can only say that I do not believe that we should protect ourselves from things from which we do not protect others. We can say things in this Parliament about other people that we cannot say about members of parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is to the credit of the Senate that we have introduced some protection of people through the privileges resolution. That is a distinct plus for this House compared to some other Houses of parliament. Nevertheless, the protection of members of parliament who do have the capacity to respond is greater than the protection of others who do not have an equal capacity to respond—although they now have some, and I welcome that.

We have to look more carefully at those things which we deem to be unparliamentary. But, Mr President, you cannot do that unilaterally. This is not a call for you unilaterally to change the long tradition of the Senate about what constitutes unparliamentary language. I regard your statement as consistent with that tradition.

Probably the period just before an election is not a very good time to do it because feelings tend to run a bit high, but after the election we should review the attitudes and the Standing Orders relating to unparliamentary language to see whether we can liberalise that somewhat. That does not altogether solve the problem which Senator Bishop has. It would go some part of the way if we opened the language up somewhat more so that people in here were freer—to use Senator Bishop's language—to use the ordinary language of the street. That may not be an absolutely accurate quote, but it was the sense of what she was saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said straightforward language.

—I do not think that is what Senator Bishop said, but it is the sense of what we are both saying. I accept that if people were freer to use more robust language they may be freer to respond to things which are said. It would not, however, open up the possibility for people to deal with the truth or otherwise of an allegation by way of the Standing Orders. That is where the problem seems to have arisen.

PARA.TAB: People have sought rulings from you, Mr President, concerning whether or not things are true. That is an impossible position for the President to be put in—this President or any other President. It seems inconceivable that we can proceed by way of presidential fiat as to the truth or otherwise of statements. We could all perhaps have a bit of fun using that sort of procedure but I do not think it would enhance the debate one bit. Nor would the debate be enhanced by wandering off into obscure pursuits about whether or not contempt proceedings were relevant. It is an interesting point that arises in extreme cases, but it does not enhance the consideration of this issue.

In the long term the answer lies in the fundamental nature of democratic debate. That is the capacity of individuals to make assertions, of others to make a rebuttal and of interested citizens to judge between them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't do that at Question Time.

—I understand that, but both sides can make assertions in questions and in responses. If someone is being particularly precious and considers something offensive in Question Time, there is the motion to take note, which is used extensively. It is a question of how best to deal with unparliamentary language. I should like to see some review of that, but I do not think we will get anywhere by pretending that we can use the Standing Orders to debate questions of the accuracy or otherwise of the statements that people make. It would make an absolute farce of the role of the Standing Orders. However, I think we need to look at allowing the debate to proceed with more ordinary language rather than within some of the artificial constraints which we impose upon ourselves at the moment.

—I would like to respond to something Senator McMullan has said about the difficulties we have with the forms of the House and that perhaps we should be looking at how we best enforce our will as a Senate. When television was introduced to this chamber we recognised that it probably would change behaviour. We have tried to set down guidelines as to how television coverage would be given to this Parliament. This has now made the question of deliberately false information being purveyed on one side or the other a greater problem than ever. Even when putting down guidelines for television coverage, we have not been able to deal with this issue.

PARA.TAB: I will give honourable senators an example of what happened to me last week in the debate on the sex discrimination legislation. Senator Crowley claimed that I had no interest in women's affairs until a year ago. When that debate concluded I gave, as is normal, a personal explanation. That has always been an acceptable way for all of us to behave. Unfortunately, Order in the House on Saturday night covered some of the debate and the allegation, but did not mention that there was a personal explanation that denied the claim by Senator Crowley. I am left in the same position as somebody in Question Time: the word has gone out by the electronic media; the lie, the misinformation, call it what you will, has become the accepted fact in the minds of however many people see that television broadcast.

I think the Senate needs to address this matter.
