It appears to me that our guidelines for that debate have not been followed by the ABC in compiling the Order in the House program, but that is another issue. It demonstrates the very problem the Opposition is now facing with misinformation being purveyed at Question Time and going over on the TV coverage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very pleased to hear your explanation, Mr President. I listened very carefully to it and also to what Senator Bishop had to say. Senator Bishop failed to recognise one very important element of what you were saying: the element of intention or purpose behind a remark. Senator Bishop used the example of a member of the Government, say, Senator Evans, saying that black is white. Senator Evans may well believe that black is white. The point at issue is not whether a statement is true or false but whether the person who is making the statement believes one thing and says something different. Mr President, as I understand your explanation, that is the definition that you are giving to the term `lie'. It seems to me that it is not appropriate for members in this chamber to accuse other people of something which reflects adversely on their integrity.

PARA.TAB: It may well be—I will use the example of Order in the House—that Senator Macdonald, who was on the program the week before, really does believe, as he asserted on that program, that the Australian Democrats give their preferences to Labor. Again, that particular program did not pick up my correction and left the viewers of that program with a view that that may be the truth. He may believe that to be the truth, and it would be inappropriate therefore—unless I can somehow get inside his head to establish that he believes that to be false—to accuse him of being a liar. Mr President, I think, therefore, your explanation is perfectly adequate.

The issue in relation to these accusations that might be made across the chamber is whether they reflect on the integrity of the person who has made a statement which may well be objectively untrue or inaccurate but may well be believed by the person who made the original statement. I think your example of Profumo is an excellent one because, as you indicated in your explanation, it was not until Mr Profumo actually admitted that he had misled the House of Commons that it became quite clear that that was the case. I strongly support the statement that you have made and the conclusion that you draw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you made a not dissimilar statement a few days ago and I did not respond to that, so I will refer to both statements. I do not dispute what you say, but my concern is that there has been a change in this place in that in recent times Ministers have used Question Time to make statements about Opposition policy which one can only presume they know to be untrue. The statements go far beyond any debatable point and Ministers clearly could not hold that interpretation if they read the document. If it happened once or twice, perhaps one could put that down to carelessness, recklessness or whatever. But in recent weeks it has been happening continually. We can only, therefore, assume that it is a deliberate political tactic to take up the opportunity in Question Time, when we do not have an opportunity to respond in debate, as you mentioned, Mr President, to make statements about Opposition policy—which Ministers should not be making at all under the rules of Question Time, but that is another matter—which can only be said to be untrue.

PARA.TAB: How is the Opposition to respond to a tactical move such as that? Unfortunately, Mr President, from your statement there is no satisfactory answer in political terms. Personal explanations are made after the television broadcasting finishes. We cannot respond by debate during Question Time. We cannot interject and say, `That is not the truth; you're telling a lie' because that is unparliamentary. Therefore, if Ministers are going to abuse the process—which is what I put to you, Mr President, is occurring during Question Time—the Opposition is being put in an impossible situation. That is an issue which needs to be addressed.

I do not think it is crossing the line that you put in your interpretation of the rules in relation to unparliamentary comments, but it does mean that there is a major deficiency somewhere in the system. Normally it would not matter because we would not expect Ministers to abuse the process in the way that these Ministers have been in recent times. But if Ministers are going to abuse the process in that way, the system has to be reformed in a way in which it can be properly answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add briefly to the remarks made by Senator Newman and Senator Hill. Clearly, with the advent of television, Question Time has attracted more interest and has become a forum in which governments and oppositions make various tactical moves to get their message out to the wider public. It is quite an effective way to do that.

PARA.TAB: Part of the problem, which Senator Hill alluded to, is that quite contrary to Standing Orders, the Government believes that Question Time should be a time in which it can outline particular objections it may have to Opposition policy. Part of the problem that I think you have, Mr President—I do not believe this has been your intention, but nonetheless this has been the effect of your rulings—is that the guidelines on Question Time and President's rulings have in some way given some sanction to Government Ministers attacking the policies of the Opposition.

It has always been out of order for a Minister to deal with matters outside his portfolio and outside his direct responsibility in response to an answer. If Senator Ray were in the chamber he would undoubtedly stand up and say, `This happened when you were in government'. My response is twofold: it happened from time to time; nonetheless, it was clear that when that occurred it was outside the Standing Orders of the time and if a point of order was taken, it should have been ruled out of order.

With the advent of TV and with the fact that the Government is determined to use Question Time as a launching pad to effectively attack the Opposition, rather than as a time to account for its own actions and the responsibilities that it has, it has placed you, Mr President, in a very difficult position. It is impossible for us to sit here when Question Time is on national TV and Ministers are constantly and deliberately misrepresenting our policies. The way to deal with this, at least in relation to Question Time, is to go back to the traditional rulings of Presidents—rulings which have existed since Federation—that Ministers have to answer questions relating to their responsibilities.

Mr President, I ask you to rethink the ruling you gave which, in a sense, codified and to a certain degree made it permissible for a Minister, provided the question was constructed in a certain way, to attack and debate the policies of the Opposition. I put it to you that a big issue has arisen here. If we cannot use the words `untruth' or `lie', I do not know what recourse we have when Question Time is being broadcast on the national media. I believe Ministers are, quite improperly, going outside their portfolios to debate and misrepresent the policies of the Opposition.

My request to you, Mr President, is to look closely at your rulings—I know that you have done that recently, but I believe this is the way to solve the dilemma—reinforce the rulings of those who came before you, and make sure that Ministers deal with matters relating to their responsibilities rather than intruding into policy debates of Opposition policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the innocent subject of Senator Button's improper remarks, for which I am still awaiting a withdrawal—and I presume, Mr President, that you will be asking him for such a withdrawal—I am concerned about this matter on another level: the deliberate pattern of personal abuse when questions are asked on a particular subject—for example, the Prime Minister's piggery. Whenever I ask such a question I am subjected to personal insults not simply on a one-off basis but as a permanent pattern.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the Government has no substantive answer to the matters I raise, which all come either from the Australian Securities Commission returns—which I would have thought would have been of some substance, despite their being called `unsubstantiated'—or, in today's case, from the register of the Supreme Court of New South Wales. Whenever I raise these matters, instead of a matter of substance in response, there is personal abuse.

Mr President, if such a pattern continues, the only capacity you appear to have is to ask people to withdraw—even though it may well be long after the event. Surely you must have the power, if you wish to exercise it, to call an end to that deliberate pattern of behaviour. We saw it again today when Senator McMullan responded almost on cue. He said that he thought we should be able to call each other here what we would call each other on the street. I interjected `and in the gutter?' and he said, `Here is our expert in the gutter'.

I must admit that it was probably indiscreet of me to incite him to that, but when his Leader accuses me of setting snail trails and when Senator Schacht then proceeds to attack me personally on a totally false basis, there is a pattern of behaviour—clear and distinct—which is aimed not at responding in substance but at using the opportunity of televised Question Time to engage in personal insults which those opposite are then required to withdraw. This pattern of personal insults certainly does not enhance the standing of this chamber.

I suppose I should assure you, Mr President, that those personal insults will not prevent me raising matters relating to the Prime Minister's piggery or to the returns with the Australian Securities Commission. I am not seeking any special protection from you. All I am saying is that it would be appropriate for you to address this pattern of behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my comment will be very brief, because most of it has been said. In view of the fact that I raised this matter as a point of order at the end of Question Time last Thursday, I want to put a question to you. Senator Baume alluded to this fact. In terms of the ruling which you gave, I think, last Wednesday, or the middle of last week, and in view of what you have said today, will you be calling Senator Button back to this chamber, particularly as he is the Leader of the Government in the Senate? To make the statement that you made last week really effective, will you call Senator Button back to this chamber and ask him to withdraw the remarks that he made last week about my colleague Senator Baume?
—Order! It has not been the practice, in a situation such as the one to which Senator Crane refers, to call somebody back to make an apology when a significant amount of time has gone by.

PARA.TAB: Let me correct one statement that was made today. It is in order to say that a statement is not true, but since 1901 it has been ruled that a senator cannot imply that another senator is lying or telling a deliberate untruth. I have heard what senators have said today. I will look carefully at what has been said. I also ask senators to read the statement that I have made very carefully. The question is that the Senate take note of the statement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of two answers given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), in response to questions without notice asked by Senators Hill and Alston this day, relating to unemployment and the taxation of low income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be but brief—and I have only five minutes anyway. It is important to demonstrate that despite all the rhetoric to the contrary, the claim of social justice that the Keating Labor Government so often makes, when it relates to the poor and the unemployed, is simply not substantiated by the facts.

PARA.TAB: I start by referring to a document of the Uniting Church issued last month. Honourable senators will remember that in Question Time the Government attacked the coalition in relation to that document. The Government said that the Uniting Church was critical of certain aspects of the coalition's GST policy as it related to a tax on food and that in the view of the church the coalition would discriminate against low income earners. What the Government did not say, however, was that the document said:

SPEECH.PARA: Under ten years of Labor Government we have experienced an enormous widening of the gap between the rich and the poor, and between the high and low income earners in Australia; and the policies have led to, or at least not succeeding in preventing, massive unemployment and a depressed economy.

What the church did was to call upon both major parties to review their policies. There is one side of politics in Australia that has listened to the churches and at least said that it would look at its policies. Notwithstanding that there is full compensation for the GST on food for pensioners—over-compensation actually—the coalition has nevertheless said that it would look at these policies again and review them.

PARA.TAB: Is the Government prepared to review its policies that have resulted in such tragedy for so many of the unemployed and low income earners in Australia? The answer, of course, is no. Here we have a situation where, as a result of Government policies, practically one million Australians are out of work. That is the highest level of unemployment in this country since the Great Depression. Will the Government look at its policies that have resulted in that tragedy? The answer is no. Every day we ask Senator Button: `Will the Government examine the deficiencies in its program and look to apply policies that can give hope to these Australians who are suffering so much?'—and his answer is no.

When we look at taxation scales for low income earners in Australia, we find that under the Government's One Nation statement the tax for low income earners will not be reduced. Alternatively, if we look at the coalition's policy, tax for low income earners will be reduced. Of course, the Government thought that it could get away with not touching its tax on low income earners because of the issue of the GST. So here we find a situation of the Government standing out there with taxation policies which relatively discriminate against low income earners whilst at the same time having the gall to claim that it is the party of social justice.

That position simply will not stand analysis. The unemployed will not have any chance of getting a job again in this country until growth rates improve. In other words, we need economic policies that work. Yet, in the last few months Mr Keating has continued saying that growth of 4 per cent—that is, growth which is needed to create employment—is achievable. In fact, growth in this country is about 2 per cent. Over the weekend Senator Richardson, the king-maker, went on television and said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well anyone who made a prediction of four per cent growth in the immediate future would I think be joking.
It is about time that Mr Keating told the Australian people the truth on this important matter.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crowley this day, relating to the oath or affirmation of allegiance.

SPEECH.PARA: Had I been able to move to take note when the answer was given, I would have done so in hot anger. Although I have now moved my motion as a matter of reflection, my anger is still as strong as it was.

PARA.TAB: We have seen the most opportunistic use of the fact that there is unhappiness and a breakdown in the marriage between the Prince and Princess of Wales. This has resulted in those who would propound the republican cause leaping and dancing on the grave of a marriage which has, apparently, ended. It is simply not acceptable to answer that opportunistic question by saying, `Two hoots, we can't now say who is going to be the heir'. That is a nonsense. Everybody knows, and logic tells us, that the heir is not known until the moment of the death of the monarch. It is simply unacceptable to use a change in the relationship of a marriage as an excuse to promote the republican cause and change the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't hear my answer.

—I heard the answer only too well. Senator Tate got up and said, `Isn't this a good chance for us to change the oath of allegiance?'. The opportunity was given to him by Senator Crowley, who used the words, `Now that this marriage has broken down'. Senator Tate answered in terms of determining who is the heir. He went on to say, `Yes, it's a good idea for us to change the oath of allegiance'. There is a unilateral determinatio among some senators on the other side to foist a republic upon us. They want to have a debate on changes to the Constitution foisted upon a nation that does not want such a debate. They will divide the nation and put Australian against Australian.

PARA.TAB: Under our Constitution, the Queen is part of this Parliament. The Queen, the Senate and the House of Representatives make up the Parliament. The Queen of Australia is the Queen of this land and the head of state. Senator Tate is saying that he thinks this is a good time to change the oath of allegiance so that people no longer will have to give that oath of allegiance to Her Majesty the Queen of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said.
—I will be delighted to read Senator Tate's answer because, as I heard him, he said that he would like to see the nature of the oath changed so that all reference to the Queen is deleted.
—I didn't say that.

—I will be delighted to see that the reference to the Queen remains. I take it that Senator Tate will rise and say, in reply to what I have said, that in his answer he said that the Queen of Australia would remain the person to whom allegiance is sworn. I will be interested to see whether that is the answer he gives, bearing in mind the real intent of the question that was asked by Senator Crowley.

—I want to make it very clear that when Senator Crowley asked that question I did not use it as an opportunity to dance on the grave of the separation of Prince Charles and Princess Diana. I said that it was sad that irreconcilable differences had apparently led to that situation. I said that the question of who the heir might be was not very important, that there were more fundamental matters at stake in relation to the rules of succession to do with, for example, discrimination on the grounds of sex and religion. I made that very clear. In so far as a new oath of allegiance for, say, a new citizen of Australia is concerned, its democratic values and its people, I said that once that is given pre-eminence the question of an oath of allegiance to the sovereign would be seen in perspective.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Baume this day, relating to workers compensation and Plueron Pty Ltd.

I noted that in the response, and by way of interjection, the Government was saying that I was not prepared to make such statements outside the chamber, in particular my comment that no provision was made in the latest annual return for any contingent liability in respect of that alleged debt.

To establish my bona fides, which I do not think this Government has ever succeeded in diminishing—in fact it has probably been enhanced by the personal nature of the vicious personal attacks on me—I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the press release I issued yesterday, without the protection of parliamentary privilege.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 13 December 1992
KEATING PIGGERY GROUP SUBSIDIARY REQUIRED TO CORRECT ASC RETURN BY $802,410

Further major corrections to incorrect company returns by Prime Minister Keating's half-owned piggery group have been released by the Australian Securities Commission, Liberal front bencher, Senator Michael Baume said today.

Senator Baume said the corrections were unaudited and not signed by the directors, in continuing breach of ASC requirements, but he had been assured by the ASC that audited and signed returns were due to be filed by the group on Friday 18 December.

"The ASC has informed me it has required the Prime Minister's Euphron-Brown and Hatton group of companies to file corrected annual returns as part of its inquiries into the group following evidence in the Senate of widespread breaches by the group of Corporations Law and ASC reporting requirements.

"Corrections filed by the group and released at the weekend for the Olympia Refrigeration (Sales) Pty Ltd subsidiary show that the annual return for the Year to June 1990, filed belatedly on May 29 1992, overstated the financial strength of the group by $802,410.
(Mr Keating became a half owner of the group on May 15 1991, but is not a director of any group companies).

"The return, which is still unaudited and not signed by directors in breach of ASC requirements, reveals that instead of having a shareholders equity, as claimed in its original return of $167,582, the company had a negative shareholders equity of $634,828 after suffering an operating loss for the year of $634,830.

When the intangible asset of $308,706 in goodwill is deducted, the total liabilities of the company exceeded its tangible assets by $943,534, double the net tangible assets deficit of $476,289 indicated in the uncorrected return.

"Detailed unaudited, unsigned accounts for the Year to June 1991, also released by the ASC, show the company suffered a further loss of $343,548 after slashing its sales revenue by more than one third from $6.9 million to $4.5 million.
"This further worsened stated shareholders' equity to a negative $978,376 and meant that the company's total liabilities exceeded its tangible assets at June 30 last year by $1,287,082.

"These unsigned, unaudited corrections follow last week's similar corrected return for the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, which revealed a re-valuation of assets and re-classification of liabilities that had converted Mr Keating's $430,100 investment on May 15 1991, into $4.2 million of shareholders equity within six weeks.
"The previous week, Euphron Pty Ltd's corrected return confirmed Mr Keating's investment at $430,100, instead of the originally stated $43,100.
"Many more major corrections to the groups' accounts are still in the pipeline", Senator Baume said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite anyone concerned to sue on the basis of that release. I say to the chamber that I will not be terrorised by the sorts of nonsensical interjections or the personal abuse that I get. The returns now being received by these companies demonstrate the accuracy of my continual concerns about the inaccurate reports filed with the Australian Securities Commission.

PARA.TAB: The corrected reports are now being released by the Australian Securities Commission. I might say that these corrections were required only because of my drawing to its attention the inaccurate and false nature of the returns that had been submitted—and exposed to public view by the ASC. These returns clearly demonstrate the false nature of the returns filed by the Keating half-owned piggery companies.

I have acknowledged continually that Mr Keating is only a half owner and is not a director. He has his nominees on the boards of these companies. But I think I should point out today that, apart from the points made in that press release I put out yesterday referring to incorrect returns by Olympia Refrigeration (Sales) Pty Ltd—where I said it had to make a correction because of its overstating the worth of the company by $802,400—further returns have been released today. They show, for example, that the corrected consolidated accounts of Brown and Hatton—still unsigned and still unaudited, of course—which were filed on 26 November 1992, show goodwill of $4.76m. They then converted an offsetting loan of $4.45m into a phoney shareholders equity.

However, the subsequent corrected—still unaudited and unsigned—accounts for each company making up that group, the last of which I received this morning, do not show any such goodwill or any offsetting debt. Which accounts do we believe? According to one set of accounts, it is only a contingent liability. The one I have for Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd unconsolidated this morning says:

SPEECH.PARA: The company has not recorded in its financial statements a potential liability of $4,000,000 relating to the purchase price associated with its acquisition of the wholesale pig business and associated naming rights of Brown and Hatton Pty Limited.

Unless things are put in this chamber, the press is too terrorised by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to print them. The facts I put out yesterday, all from the Australian Securities Commission, were unquestionable facts—but they could not be printed.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to private health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the fact that Senator Tate was born at Crown Street Hospital, I am sure there was no connection with his other answer in relation to the Crown. The Government obviously fails to understand about caesarean section rates, and I want to put this on the record. Private caesarean section rates have always been higher than public caesarean section rates because there are two distinct groups of patients who attend for obstetrics.

PARA.TAB: Private obstetric sector patients are, in general terms, older when they deliver the first child. They have a far higher median age for the first delivery. There are fewer low risk, multiparous pregnancies in the private sector—they tend to be among public patients. Higher educational levels with more questioning attitudes put greater pressure on the obstetrician to achieve perfect outcomes in the private sector.

The peri-natal mortality rate has halved between 1972 and 1992. Currently, approximately 13 babies per thousand die between 20 weeks of pregnancy and six weeks of delivery. Obstetricians have contributed significantly to this decrease in the death rate.

The implication that somehow or other this is related to insurance is completely untrue because in 1986 the Labor Government unilaterally introduced a global fee for obstetrics whereby the obstetrician received a set rebate no matter what the mode of delivery was. For six years there has been absolutely no financial incentive for any private obstetrician to perform a caesarean section.

The private caesarean section rate has risen each year since 1986, despite the lack of financial incentive. The most important reason for this rise is the medico-legal threat of litigation—everybody wants a perfect baby. In the private sector, all medico-legal responsibility rests with the individual obstetrician. In the public sector it is devolved between hospitals, midwifery staff, junior medical staff and the senior consultant. In the last six years, medico-legal pressure has been the single largest contributing factor to the rise in private caesarean section rates.

The presence of health insurance is merely acting as a marker for a totally different group of patients. The private obstetric sector patient is very different from one treated in the public sector, as I have mentioned in my previous comments. So I think it is time that Senator Crowley stopped this doctor bashing—I am pleased that Senator Tate did not go to that extent. Senator Crowley sees some sort of figure and says, `Ergo, it is related to insurance rates'. I think I have adequately demonstrated that it has no association and could not have any association. I think this matter should now rest where it quite rightfully belongs in terms of the clinical outcomes for the baby and the mother.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to acknowledge Senator Herron's contribution to this important debate on the care of mothers and their children. I acknowledge the points that he has made. I want to indicate that in my answer I inadvertently deceived the Senate. Certainly it was done without any memory of the matter and therefore it cannot be said that I deliberately misled the Senate. I was phoned by my father after Question Time to say that I was not born at Crown Street after all. I was born at King George Hospital in Camperdown.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1. Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nations national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.
2. We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship continue to be tenable at the Institute of Advanced Studies of ANU and CSIRO.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans-Tasman Travel Agreements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows:

We, the undersigned, express our concerns at current Australian Government Policy towards New Zealand (The Trans Tasman Travel Agreements) which allows New Zealand visitors to gain employment at the expense of Australian workers.
Accordingly, in view of the growing differences between Australia and New Zealand with regard to:

PARA.TAB: Currency exchange rates;
Taxation systems;
Industrial Relations law;
Industry/Award wages and conditions;

PETITION.PARA: we call on the Federal government to implement a work permit system on New Zealand visitors intending to work in Australia, similar to the work permit system that applies to any other foreign national in Australia intending to work. We also call for a non discriminatory standard policy on immigration towards all foreign sovereign nations including New Zealand.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia is to draw your attention that abortion, as practised in Australia, is against the Almighty God. We are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ, and the Holy Bible as many references that support our petition namely:-

PARA.TAB: 1. "Thus saith the Lord that made thee, and formed thee from the womb" (Isaiah 44v2)

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: THE HON LAURIE BRERETON MP
PARLIAMENTARY SECRETARY
TO THE PRIME MINISTER
Senator B Cooney
Chairperson
Senate Standing Committee on Legal
and Constitutional Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney

I refer to the Committee's Report on the Scrutiny of Annual Reports No 1 of 1992 (June 1992) which recommended "that future ASIO annual reports be referred for consideration to the Joint Statutory Committee on ASIO" (JSC).

I would point out that the ASIO Act 1979 (the Act) already makes provision for ASIO Annual Reports to be presented to the Parliament. However, the Act gives the Attorney-General the authority to make such deletions as he considers necessary (after obtaining advice from the Director-General of Security) in order to avoid prejudice to Australia's security, defence, foreign relations, or the privacy of individuals.

The Act also states that the JSC is not to consider matters that are operationally sensitive (including those relating to intelligence collection methods or sources of information), matters that relate to the obtaining or communicating by ASIO of foreign intelligence, or aspects of ASIO activities that do not affect any person who is an Australian citizen or permanent resident.
As the ASIO Annual Report does contain such sensitive information, it would clearly be inappropriate for the entire Report to be presented to the JSC.

This is not to say, however, that ASIO's annual reports should not be referred to the JSC once tabled in the Parliament after appropriate deletions in accordance with section 94(4) of the Act. It should also be noted that the JSC on ASIO does, in fact, scrutinise those aspects of ASIO annual reports that are relevant to its inquiries under the Act.
Yours sincerely
LAURIE BRERETON
THE HON LAURIE BRERETON MP
