TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General—Auditor-General's Report No. 11 of 1992-93 Efficiency Audit—Department of Administrative Services—Procedures for dealing with fraud on the Commonwealth

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet again the Auditor-General has done an excellent job in drawing attention to what is potentially a very serious matter. The Department of Administrative Services contains many of the commercial operations of government. These are operations that really are peripheral to the core of government, but they represent the provision of goods and services to the public sector.

PARA.TAB: Some years ago, this was done automatically in that any work required by the public sector was carried out by these arms of government. However, in the past four to five years there have been changes, mainly instigated by the Department of Finance, to commercialise those operations.

That means that they have been put on some sort of competitive footing. In other words, the Department has introduced, with the support of the Opposition, accrual accounting procedures—balance sheets, profit and loss accounts, notes to accounts and so on. This action was taken in an attempt to make these business enterprises more competitive. There has also been an untying of the clients. In other words, under the financial management improvement program, other public sector departments have been entitled to go out and seek quotations from the private sector in order to get services provided.

This has introduced an element of competition to the public sector, although not entirely. That element of competition has caused a lot of pain within the private sector because the public sector does have—even though it might like to argue otherwise—a lot of benefits compared with the private sector. For instance, the public sector does not pay sales tax on anything; it does not pay the fuel excise levy; and it does not pay the normal State charges that would occur when it operates within the State. Be that as it may, the commercial operations carried out by the Department of Administrative Services include things such as building construction, building maintenance, removals, transportation, printing, purchasing, valuations, renting and fitout of buildings. A fairly large part of the operations is associated with large volumes of money. More importantly, it is big slabs of Government money and therefore taxpayers' money.

The Audit Office has pointed out that, in 1991, the Department of Administrative Services was responsible for expenditure in excess of $3 billion in taxpayers' money. The Department, quoting from private sector consultants, indicated that fraud in an organisation like DAS could well be in the region of 2 per cent to 5 per cent of turnover. In the case of the Department, this suggests a loss from fraud of somewhere between $60m to $300m a year for the year 1990-91. If those losses do occur, they are in the same league as the losses of failed entrepreneurs who quite properly took a beating in the late 1980s.

What is worse is that the Audit Office has found that no-one knows for sure whether there has been fraud of $60m or $300m. It is the sort of lackadaisical approach we have come to expect from this Government and from the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, who was responsible for this. When I say that no-one knows for sure, the Auditor-General does point out that the figures should be treated with caution in the absence of a more solid base for estimates and that they should be used for planning purposes. That is quite correct. But it is of great concern that no-one knows. We are talking about taxpayers' money. Although one can say nothing of any praise about those paper entrepreneurs, at least they were not using taxpayers' money; whereas in this instance taxpayers' money was used.

In 1989 the fraud control unit was set up in response to the intention of the Minister—I am not sure whether it was Senator Bolkus at that time; it probably was not—that the Department would have a small investigation unit which:

SPEECH.PARA: would . . . take a far more pro-active role in detecting, investigating and obtaining evidence of fraud. It would also actively encourage the expeditious processing of allegations by the AFP and the regular reporting of progress to me.

PARA.TAB: The Audit Office general findings are that the fraud control plan introduced by DAS covered only programs which the related risk assessment had identified as highly attractive to fraud. So it was limited. One has to ask the question whether this was really a genuine attempt to tackle fraud or whether it was just a show pony. From the rest of the Auditor-General's report one would have to come to the conclusion that a lot of it was for show, like so much of the stuff we have propounded to us by the Minister, Senator Bolkus, and all the other programs which really have not achieved a lot, but which have been good for show and public display. I can give other examples of this.
The comment made by the Auditor-General was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The independence of a fraud control unit in its investigation role must not only be real, but must be seen to be real.
That is absolutely vital. The Auditor-General continues:

For that reason it is considered that fraud control activities in a department must not be, and must not be seen to be, controlled by management other than those specifically designated to be responsible for the control of fraud.

It is a ludicrous situation to be investigating fraud and then having people who are actually responsible for a particular department having some involvement in that investigation. The Auditor-General goes on to say:

The officer in charge of fraud control should have the clear authority of the Secretary. . . to conduct investigations and refer matters for police investigation or for prosecution as considered appropriate.

The general findings go on in a way that indicates that this is very sloppy indeed. It is indicative of what is wrong with the Australian economy, because the Government is preoccupied with the political process and not really particularly interested in the management process. That is reflected in the fact that we now have one million people out of work. Over the weekend I heard people from within the business sector predicting that if this Government is allowed to continue next year, there will be about 1 1/2 million people out of work.

PARA.TAB: The reason I raise this matter is that it is clearly a management issue. The fact that we have the worst recession in 60 years is clearly mismanagement by a government which really does not care. All it thinks it can do is solve the problems by playing politics—and very shallow politics. The Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: DAS records were such that in a number of instances DAS had to rely upon the availability and the memories of individuals within DAS management as the basis for management and accountability.

Madam Acting Deputy President, have you ever heard anything more absurd? I could not help but note the comments made the other day by the Auditor-General on DAS itself and its accrual accounting procedures that if this had occurred in the private sector and this was a public company, the Stock Exchange would not continue to list those shares until it was sorted out. That is the sort of irresponsibility we have. If an efficiency audit of this sort had come out in the private sector, the shareholders would be asking questions and there is a good chance that the whole board of management would have to go.

PARA.TAB: The response of DAS to the Auditor-General refers to the time in 1987 when the Department was created and the problems that it has experienced. It goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: This process impacts very directly on the nature and extent of the Department's exposure to the risk of fraud; on the structure of the Department and the implications this has had for planning process; and on the development of an appropriate management response to fraud.
Honourable senators should listen very carefully to the response from the Department to the findings of the Auditor-General, which was as follows:

The Department recognises the extent of its exposure to potential fraud and is determined to remain vigilant in its response to that risk and to develop and change its fraud prevention capability in response to the changing nature of the situation in which it finds itself.
I have heard that so many times on Yes, Minister. This is typical Yes, Minister stuff.

PARA.TAB: The other point I made earlier was in relation to the level of fraud. The Auditor-General raised the question of the level of fraud. This is a reflection not on the Auditor-General but on the maladministration of a very important department in the Commonwealth which looks after all commercial operations. It is a reflection on this Government's mismanagement of this economy. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not possible to quantify accurately the level of fraud perpetrated against DAS, or any other organisation. The primary difficulty, of course, is the problem of estimating the level of fraud which is not detected.

That was the purpose of the Fraud Control Unit: to go in there and find the fraud in an area which is most likely to have fraud. The reason for the Fraud Control Unit is the volume of dollars involved. For example, the Department has responsibility for government purchasing. Purchasing in any sector of the economy is always an area where one has to be vigilant at all times because it is open to corruption. It is open to vendors to give bribes to people who are buying things for somebody else. I am not making this statement to reflect on the Department; it is a general comment.

PARA.TAB: This Department is involved in the renting and fitting out of buildings. When there is an incredible recession—a recession we had to have and the greatest recession since the Depression 60 years ago—there is a temptation for slings to be offered and for under-the-counter moneys to be passed. The area of transportation is a very competitive one in a recessed economy, as is the area of removals. This is where goods are moved from place to place with the movement of defence staff, public servants and so on. Of course, there is also the highly competitive area of building construction and building maintenance. What concerned me more than anything was this. The Audit Office pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: When faced with the prospect of an investigation under the disciplinary provisions of the Public Service Act in relation to a matter in the nature of fraud, some DAS staff have elected to resign. Such resignations preclude finalisation of the disciplinary process.
What an extraordinary situation. If people are caught with their hands in the till pinching money from the taxpayer, they just resign and that is the end of it. The report states:

The ANAO is concerned that such circumstances should not and should not appear to leave departmental staff who may have engaged in inappropriate activity in a preferred position relative to others in the community who are in a similar position.
From a taxpayer point of view this is absolutely intolerable. The report further states:

DAS records indicated that in a number of cases staff left the Department when they were confronted with the prospect of disciplinary proceedings. From an administrative viewpoint this can be an efficient means of the organisation being rid of the management problem posed by the staff.

What a way out. That is most negligent. Again, I am not reflecting upon the Auditor-General: he is the one who picked up all of this. If someone in the Department is caught—which can be an embarrassment to any supervisor—they are taken quietly aside and told, `If you leave, nothing will happen to you. There will be no public report made; we will not have any skin off our nose. So just disappear and everything will be all right'. And that is what they have done.

PARA.TAB: Really, a loophole exists which enables a person who has defrauded the Commonwealth, and thus the taxpayer, to get off tax free. I found the Department's response curious and quaint. The Department said that it had considerable difficulty with the reasoning and conclusions in this section that relate to resignation. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: DAS procedures are totally in accord with Service wide practices and procedures as set out in the Personnel Manual and Chapter 13 of the Discipline Handbook.
DAS notes—
and if this is the case, the situation is much more serious and extensive—
that public servants—whether in DAS or elsewhere—are in no different situation to their private sector counterparts in that
. their liability to employer disciplinary arrangements cease with their resignation; and
. the handling of criminal matters is, and should be, completely independent of employer disciplinary processes.

I agree with the latter but the report does not say what happens. Bear in mind what I said earlier: the losses from fraud in this Department alone are estimated to be of the order of $60m to $300m a year. It seems to me that the case is closed. There seems to be no reference at all as to where the case goes from there.

PARA.TAB: The comment that `this is no different to the private sector', is quite untrue. If anyone in the private sector is tracked down and picked up for committing fraud in respect of a company's assets, the matter is immediately put in the hands of the police. Irrespective of whether that person left or stayed, if he is found to have done something illegal he would be charged and, if found guilty, convicted. If that has happened, it has been kept very quiet. I do not think anyone in this chamber has ever heard of that sort of thing happening. Yet, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: DAS records indicate that, from the formation of the Fraud Control Unit (FCU) in late 1989 until the end of 1991, 96 cases of possible fraud were referred to that unit. No value was recorded for many of the cases and the FCU advised that it could not estimate the value of cases handled.

This is a disgrace. It is an absolute disgrace that there has to be a Fraud Control Unit. As I said earlier, this body gives all the impressions of being a showpiece and nothing else—there is no depth to it.

PARA.TAB: To its credit, the Department has said that it will take up something like 12 or 13 of the Auditor-General's recommendations. But why is a report from the Auditor-General needed before anything is done in an organisation? This is typical of this Government. I believe that it is an intolerable situation. It is something that the taxpayers of this country should be appalled about. It is an absolute disgrace, not only for this Government but also for the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments about the Auditor-General's report No. 11 of 1992-93 into the Department of Administrative Services. As Senator Parer said, this report has revealed a situation that is an absolute disgrace for this Government. But it is not the only area of fraud this Government has chosen to overlook.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Parer stated, there is no formal statement of the role and function which, in practice, the Fraud Control Unit in the Department of Administrative Services has been performing. In the middle of 1992, the Department was, in a formal sense, still relying on the description of the Fraud Control Unit which was set down in May 1989.

Taxpayers' money can vanish with absolutely no controls whatsoever in place. This just goes on and on. Last week I asked the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) a question concerning the Department of Administrative Services. That question related to the misuse of parliamentary offices.

I have provided the information to the Minister, Senator Bolkus, about the use of Mr Ron Edwards's parliamentary office by a private individual running his own business out of that office. Clearly, the Minister was not going to do anything about that until I provided him with the detail. There were two or three days gap when the Minister could have come back and said, `I have made an investigation', but he did not choose to do so. He has not answered my question following Question Time today, so another day has gone by. Yet we have the misuse of parliamentary offices continuing in such a way that people can use the resources in those offices without any check.

The point that I made last week, and I will make it again today, is: how can we have someone such as Mr Edwards, who is the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives and therefore meant to be the keeper of parliamentary standards within the House of Representatives, the second most senior person in charge of the keeping of parliamentary standards, quite clearly flouting his parliamentary entitlements and not being accountable? His answer to a lot of the journalists about that little piece of information has been, `This man, Mr Clohessy, works on a part time basis out of my office'. I am not querying that. That has absolutely nothing to do with the serious questions I raised last week about the misuse of parliamentary offices, which comes under the Department of Administrative Services. The questions I asked last week remain unanswered. They were: how can a private individual, running a private union advocacy business, be using a parliamentary office as a point of contact, and be using the fax machines and the telephones out of that office—to say nothing of what else, of which I am aware, but one need not have a particularly vivid imagination to think what—and yet we still cannot get an answer out of the Minister?

Today we have the Auditor-General's report coming out and saying that there has been no check on fraud in recent years. Yet we can have the Minister just let that go through to the keeper as well. As a nation we cannot afford to constantly have taxpayers' money going walkabout and have this Government do absolutely nothing about it.

Some months ago I asked for a report on medical fraud to be released because there was a clear problem that the Government had chosen to do nothing about it. The Government chose not to release that report. In the end it became an order of the Senate that the Minister had to release that departmental report on medical fraud. We had a situation then similar to that which we experienced last week, where an order of the Senate was made that the document on the goods and services tax in New Zealand be released. On both occasions, in relation to the medical fraud document and the goods and services tax document last week, both Ministers in effect said to the Senate, `Get lost. We are not going to release those reports', even though they had been ordered to do so. The weak, limp excuse that they used about Medicare fraud was that it might teach someone how to commit Medicare fraud. Fortunately the time expired last Friday for that document to be issued ultimately on a confidential basis and the Government said that there would be an Auditor-General's report put down on that issue last week as well. We still have not seen that report. Yet today we have an Auditor-General's report on the question of fraud in the Department of Administrative Services which is absolutely and utterly damning. Presumably this year, next year, some time, never, we will get an Auditor-General's report on Medicare fraud—when the Government chooses to release it; it has got nothing to do with the Auditor-General.

In 1982 it was suggested that Medicare fraud amounted to about $100m. By 1984 it was suggested that it was about $200m. Since then, this Government has continually trumpeted the benefits and the wonders of bulkbilling, yet it has done absolutely nothing about stopping the level of Medicare fraud. All it does is go around and doctor bash, pharmacist bash and pathologist bash. Yet where is that report? Here we have the Auditor-General's report on the Department of Administrative Services, which is absolutely damning of this Government's inactivity and carelessness with taxpayers' money. How can the Government sit in this place and say that the loss of millions upon millions of taxpayers' money matters not, whether it is the Department of Administrative Services or the Health Insurance Commission that has chosen not to exercise any control whatsoever over fraud?

I would be interested to find out whether the Minister will ever answer the questions about the misuse of Mr Edwards's office. The evidence in itself is damning. The testimony given by so many employers who have been contacted by Mr Clohessy is that they have been pressured to extreme lengths to re-employ people who have been dismissed, even though he is not a judge of whether the dismissal has been fair or otherwise. On all occasions of which I have been given examples, he has used Mr Edwards's office as the contact point. He has followed up with all the supplementary information to the Chamber of Commerce in Western Australia, the Industrial Relations Commission in Western Australia and other parties utilising Mr Edwards's fax machine, telephone and office. If that is not fraud against the Commonwealth under the Department of Administrative Services, what is? Our offices are not supplied to do that. Our offices are purely and simply supplied for the use of parliamentary and electorate work in serving our constituents.

I await to see what the Minister will say about the question that I raised. I am not surprised to see the Auditor-General's report today saying that the Government has yet again sat on its hands and treated taxpayers' money with absolute and total disregard. I ceased being amazed with that when I read the Harvey Bates report on Medicare fraud, which I had to struggle to get released a few months ago. Therefore, to see this report today does not amaze me one iota.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on the Auditor-General's report on the Department of Administrative Services. At the outset I wish to make two points. Firstly, it would be of great use to debate in this Senate, in this Parliament and in the gallery if people were to read the reports about which they are talking. To have an informed debate it is a pretty all-important pre-condition that people are aware of the report.
—Pretty important to get it more than an hour before the debate.

—Senator Calvert says that it would be useful if the report were given to him. I actually got this report 15 minutes ago. It did not take me long to go to it. I had some advance briefing on it. The second point I want to make is directed very much to—

PARA.TAB: Senator Knowles interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave Senator Knowles a free go; I could have made all sorts of comments. I am asking her to let me be heard for a few minutes in silence. I wish to make the second point to the press gallery. Time and time again I have seen the AAP, in particular, come in here, take off an allegation that has been made and give it a big run without checking the source, the facts and the reality. I say to members of the AAP this time that it may be to their benefit if they were to pause at the end of what I say and assess the allegations that have been made in the context, not of what has been asserted so far but in terms of some of the points I wish to make in respect of the Auditor-General's report.

PARA.TAB: I say to those in the press gallery that, if they are honest and balanced in their journalistic approach to this issue, they will not run off immediately and write histrionic stories about what has been alleged in the Auditor-General's report. Contrary to the assertions that have been made by those opposite, the report goes through the history in one department—the Department of Administrative Services—of an attempt to oversee the detection of fraud in that department. A special mechanism was put in place. We did not leave it to the AFP or to toothless committees or whatever. The Fraud Control Unit was set up before I took over the portfolio. It was given responsibility, as is documented in the Auditor-General's report, to investigate fraud within the Department. We felt that, in essence, a department such as this, within the process that was going on there and even at the end of the process, would need a special focus within it to detect practices and instances which would be assessed as a fraud on the taxpayer. As a consequence, my predecessor, Mr Stuart West, set up the Fraud Control Unit.

Consistently in the last 2 1/2 years since I have had the portfolio, I have made it very clear to the departmental Secretary and to those that have been charge of the Fraud Control Unit that if they ever needed any more resources they would have them. Not only did I make it clear myself, but Mr Tanzer also made that very clear to those running the unit. From day one the staff of the unit have had access to me and the departmental Secretary, and from day one they have been told that resources would not be a limitation; they would be made available to them—and that has been the case.

Some two months ago, in discussions with Mr Tanzer I suggested that we set up a review of the Fraud Control Unit and that it should be set in place within a short period. The review would be conducted by outside people to look not just at the things that the Auditor-General looked at but also at other practices, and to make comparisons with similar organisations and similar departments within Australia and elsewhere. It was to look at the concept of white collar crime, or an aspect of it, to see whether we could enhance the FCU in the way it needs.

The Auditor-General's report looks at the history of this organisation and whether in its history, its conception and its practice it conforms to certain standards. I am concerned to do more than that. I am concerned to see whether we have the appropriate unit for a department such as this—whether we need to have a different sort of unit, a broader one or a more limited one; and, in setting up the appropriate institution, to see what resources it may need. In my approach to this I am not limited by the parameters that the Auditor-General felt necessary when he and his organisation made an assessment of the FCU.

Let me turn to some of the recommendations. I think the most important one mentioned by Senator Parer was an aspect of the report which is geared, I suppose, to invoke the attention of those in the gallery; that is, that something like $60m to $300m is the level of fraud in this Department. Let me read the actual reference in the report of the Auditor-General from which this bald assertion or allegation was supposed to have come. It is worth putting this on the record not just for the Senate but just in case some misguided undergraduate journalist decides to run with it.

I turn to section 1.4 on page 2 of the report, headed `The level of fraud in the Department of Administrative Services'. I will read all of that section because it is important, it is instructive, it clarifies the situation, and it takes the air of the sort of false assertion that was made early in this debate. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not possible to quantify accurately the level of fraud perpetrated against DAS, or any other organisation. The primary difficulty, of course, is the—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a dreadful admission, you have not read it. You just don't know.
—Just listen, Senator Parer. If you have read it, you have perpetrated a great act of dishonesty in the Senate this afternoon, for which you ought to be condemned—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Bolkus!

TALK.START.PARA: —If you have read this, you ought to be condemned. What you have—
—Minister! It is not satisfactory for you to allege that a member of this chamber has perpetrated an act of dishonesty. You were here at Question Time and, I presume, thereafter, when the President—
—I withdraw.
—Order!
—I withdraw.
—Thank you.
—I will go on—
—If I may finish the point that I was making—
—Do you want to waste my time?
—No, I do not want to waste your time.
—Well, keep quiet.
—If you will flagrantly disregard orders of the Chair that have been made earlier in the day, it should be pointed out to you.
—I will go on, then. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The primary difficulty, of—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Madam Deputy President, I ask you to direct Senator Bolkus to withdraw that remark he made when you were continuing your remarks when he asked you to keep quiet.
—Order! Senator Parer, Senator Bolkus is entitled to make some off-the-cuff remark. I did not hear him ask the Chair to be quiet. If I had, I would have brought him to order for doing so.
—I will go on. In fact, I will start again. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not possible to quantify accurately the level of fraud perpetrated against DAS, or any other organisation. The primary difficulty, of course, is the problem of estimating the level of fraud which is not detected.
That is understood as well. The report continues:

Another problem is determining how the value should be measured. For example, whether the amount quoted is to be the amount which the offenders sought to obtain, the amount the offenders received, the amount quoted in an allegation or the amount relating to which a conviction is recorded.

That is a general statement. It is a general statement about any organisation—DAS or any organisation. It has no direct relevance to DAS. It is in no way at all telling the world that this is the level of fraud in DAS. It is in no way telling the world what the situation is in DAS. It talks conceptually of any organisation. As honourable senators will see in the next chapter, that organisation could be in the private or public sector. Paragraph 1.4.2 of the report states:
DAS quoted private sector consultants as indicating that fraud in an organisation was likely to be in the region of 2 per cent to 5 per cent of turnover.

Private sector consultants were not asked to look at DAS and to make an assessment of what the fraud level was in DAS. They were asked to make an assessment of what one could reasonably expect to be a fraud level in any organisation, private or public—not just DAS. The point I am making here is that that sentence, damning though it might sound, has to be assessed in the context that what we have is the Department itself asking private consultants what would be a theoretical level of fraud in an organisation, private or public, and they say 2 per cent to 5 per cent. The report then goes on to say:

In the case of DAS this suggests a loss to fraud of $60m to $300m for the 1990-91 financial year. Such figures must obviously be treated with extreme caution, however, in the absence of a more solid base for estimates they could be used for planning purposes.

The point is that the Auditor-General has not found $60m to $300m worth of fraud in this Department. The point is that the Auditor-General himself, or his organisation, did not come up with that figure. It is the planners within DAS, the managers within DAS who, in anticipation of problems, have taken steps and measures and advice as to how to plan for those problems. There is not claimed to be $60m to $300m worth of fraud in this Department. Anyone who comes in here and makes that assertion is wrong, and they know they are wrong. As the Auditor-General says, that is just an estimate that should be used for planning purposes.

PARA.TAB: We are having a theoretical discussion about organisations and the level of fraud within them, private or public. The next paragraph is also very instructive in terms of what is actually happening within DAS and in terms of what has been detected. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: DAS records indicate that, from the formation of the Fraud Control Unit (FCU) in late 1989 to the end of 1991, 96 cases of possible fraud were referred to that unit. No value was recorded for many of the cases and the FCU advised that it could not estimate the value of cases handled.

That is the actual reflection of the level of fraud that has been detected so far. As I have said, I have not been happy with the FCU. My departmental Secretary has acknowledged the need for review, and that is precisely what we are going to do. It is a broader review than has been conducted by the Auditor-General. Let me say that anyone who comes in here and asserts that that is the level of fraud, anyone who writes that, is perpetrating a great fraud on the electorate.

PARA.TAB: Any organisation as big as DAS, which has some 11,000 staff and a budget of $2 billion or $3 billion, has to take measures to respond to, plan for and anticipate any level of fraud. We have done that. What the Auditor-General's report has done is quite valuable. Of the 11 recommendations put forward by the Auditor-General, the Department will pick up and implement 10. We will go further than that and have an overall review of the FCU, which I think is necessary. The Auditor-General's Department, in its press release issued today, has acknowledged that we have responded favourably to 10 of its recommendations.

The eleventh recommendation goes to the question that needs to be resolved between the ANAO and the Department. This recommendation, which was not accepted, relates to the fact that the National Audit Office disagrees with the DAS decision to supplement the Public Service Commission guidelines on official conduct with a departmental code of ethics. It is not a matter of reducing them; it is a matter of putting in other guidelines on which ethics can be assessed. The ANAO—quite rightly, in its mind—believes that the Public Service Commission code should be amended and extended to cover the circumstances of all departments. DAS believes that a conduct specific code for DAS is beneficial, considering the fact that we are talking of a commercialised and commercialising institution.

I think I have dealt sufficiently with the Auditor-General's report, so I will speak more on my last point about a commercialised and commercialising institution. We are talking of an institution which over the last five years has gone from being a Public Service department to one which, by the end of this financial year, will have to compete on the open market for some 95 per cent of its work. No longer will other departments be bound by any dictate that they have to go to DAS if they want work done; 95 per cent of our functions will be untied and open to competition.

Over recent years that has meant that DAS has been reduced from a department with some 18,000 staff to one with some 11,200 staff. It has meant savings per annum for the Commonwealth of approximately $200m. All this has been done with hardly a day lost through strike. All this has been done through consultation. We have reached this part of the process, having commercialised, restructured and refitted this organisation into a commercially orientated one, without blood spilt on the floor and with the cooperation of everyone involved. As a direct result of this, the Commonwealth and the taxpayer are paying $200m a year less for services provided by DAS. That is not a bad outcome. If I had had more time, I would have been able to bring in quotations from Estimates committees. Senator Parer, in the darkness of closed, smaller rooms, would acknowledge that the process has been run successfully.

One exercise that this Department has been responsible for is Comcar. I had not been satisfied with the way it had been running, and nor should I have been. About 18 months ago I brought in Price Waterhouse to look at Comcar as an organisation and to look at its management structures. It gave us a proposal for the restructure of Comcar. At that stage, it was losing $11m, $12m, $13m, $15m, $20m—escalating into the future. Price Waterhouse Urwick came to us with a draft management plan and proposals to restructure the organisation.

We actually got in the business consultant from Price Waterhouse Urwick to take over the organisation of Comcar, to run it for some time. I think Rob Pocknee did a great job—and that has been acknowledged in Estimates committees as well—to the extent that at the end of this financial year the savings that will have been achieved in Comcar will be greater than those projected to be achieved by Dr Hewson and his `Knockback' package. By the end of this financial year, we will have achieved $11 1/2m or so in savings. Dr Hewson anticipated saving $10m by cutting the guts out of the organisation.

That has been a remarkable transformation, one which Senator Parer has acknowledged in the Estimates Committee. If honourable senators opposite want to come in here and invoke some professional competence, they should not do so until they have done their homework. That is what happened this afternoon. We have had a proposal from the Opposition that has been running for 54 weeks—the Fightback package. To show how widely off the mark the Opposition is today, in looking at Administrative Services, the Opposition is $500m out over a three-year period.

The Opposition can say `wrong'. It can abuse the critics. We have achieved the savings; we have documented those savings; we have budgeted for them. How are we wrong when honourable senators on the other side claim a $20m saving out of a part of a budget of only $3m? We are not wrong. The Opposition has it totally wrong. This week in particular it is appropriate to say something about Australia's media—they have got it wrong. The trouble with Australia's media is that they report politics the way they report one-day cricket games. At the end of the day they go to bed and they think the scores are up on the board and either Hewson has won or Keating has won. The reality of politics in any country is that it lasts more than one day per game. This is a long test match. They will go away this week and say that Dr Hewson has discovered a new spirit of concern and humanity.

The punters out there think quite differently. The cynicism about the Opposition is reminiscent of swimming in a quagmire, in a swamp. They can see it out there; the gallery upstairs does not see it. It is about time that gallery looked at the figures that came out last year and looked at the assertion that we make that the Opposition is $500m wrong in its Fightback assessment. The gallery should not cop the response that it is wrong and that it is rubbish without that assertion being documented and substantiated. Not once have the members of the gallery taken to task one of the Opposition front benchers and said, `Your figures might be wrong'. The starting point for this week ought not to be a glassy eyed view of the Fightback package. They ought to do their homework before Friday, and they ought to do it here—because there is $500m for a start and then another $800m at least because the Opposition has not factored in the costs of redundancies and superannuation. Let me then go back to the initial point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell us about Ron Edwards instead.

—I will come to Ron Edwards. I want to finish with that. I want to get the other stuff on the record first. The basic point is that if any of them runs off today and writes, `$60m to $80m fraud in Administrative Services', I think they would be letting down their profession.

PARA.TAB: Coming to Ron Edwards, a question was asked of me last week about Ron Edwards. I volunteered in Question Time, and after Question Time, that, once I was given the information, the documents, on which the question was based, I would do something about it. I had received nothing by way of information last Friday. I had received nothing first thing this morning. So I wrote to Senator Knowles this morning and later in the morning I got a letter from her giving me the information that I needed. I will not make a judgment about whether that information was posted to me—

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that letter dated?

—I do not care when it was dated; I know when it was received in my office. People can backdate—I am not suggesting that Senator Knowles did, but I am going on to make the point that it may very well have been that by Friday afternoon, or Friday some time, Senator Knowles sent that information to me. The other point was that I had not received it this morning. I wrote to her this morning asking for it; I have got it now and I will proceed with it, as I said I would. I also made the point last week that this question of misuse and abuse of government and parliamentary resources is not an isolated one. I made mention of the fact that it had been brought to my attention that someone in Dr Hewson's office was there as an abuse of taxpayers' resources.
—Why don't you withdraw the statement? It is an unemployed person.

—Senator Knowles continues the assertion that it was an unemployed young person. That happens quite often. At the time I did not know the name of or the facts about the person working in Dr Hewson's office. But I now know that person was not unemployed and was not a youngster. That person was a paid employee of the Liberal Party of Australia. That person worked full time out of that office and is also listed in the internal parliamentary directory as being on the staff of Dr Hewson. That person was employed by Dr Hewson and the employment was terminated some few months ago. That person now is a full time paid employee of the Liberal Party. The point I make in raising the matter is that those opposite assert that there has been an abuse of resources on the part of Mr Edwards—something that has not as yet been established—
—Are you saying it is in any way comparable with Mr Edwards's arrangements?
—No. I am saying that in my position I have to investigate all instances of abuse of government and taxpayers' resources. In this case—
—You're a fraud, just a fraud.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! Senator Newman, withdraw that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that unparliamentary?
—Yes.
—If it is unparliamentary, I withdraw it. But I still think he is just a fraud.
—No, Senator, I do not think that you understand. You must make an unqualified withdrawal. You must indicate that you are withdrawing that accusation.
—I withdraw the accusation and I say that it is an unsatisfactory description by the Minister.
—Order! That is sufficient, you have apologised.

—The point I make is that when cases of abuse of taxpayers' resources are brought to my attention, no matter who they come from, I have a responsibility to investigate them, which I fulfil. But I will not pre-judge any person, as Opposition senators may have done, and I will not come in here and condemn someone for not acting on information when that information has not been provided. The point of this afternoon's debate is the Auditor-General's report and it is a report that we welcome in a constructive way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) attacked the media for not reporting the running of the Department of Administrative Services in the way that he would like it to be reported. I take note of the fact that, in the computer and communications section of the Canberra Times this morning, there was a reasonably critical article of DAS apropos the computer system that is to be installed in Comcars. I think we were told in Estimates hearings that this system would cost about $4m. I have now heard that it will cost approximately $7m. It was designed to be similar to the F-F-fast Trax system, which was developed by a Sydney-based company.

PARA.TAB: The Department found that the particular system it had been using—the IBM RISC system—was not suitable and it had to be amended. After 15 months or so, the Department got the system working very well. The Government obviously looked at this system—as did Air New Zealand and the Federal Airports Corporation—yet the Minister's Department turned around and went ahead with a system that had been found to be faulty. As this article in the Canberra Times says:

SPEECH.PARA: Now any problem can be solved if you are willing to stand back and throw money and resources at it, and this is what DAS has done.

That is the sort of thing that the Auditor-General is raising: the waste of money by this Department. The Minister stood up here today and said that his Department had saved $200m. Well done, congratulations! But that does not mean that other systems cannot be looked at. Here we see the same sorts of mistakes being made again.

PARA.TAB: Senator Zakharov, a few other senators and I were victims of that system in South Australia in the first week it operated. None of us received cars, but we accepted the fact that a new system has teething problems. When one reads this article it seems that the system it was based on had teething problems and that the Department took no notice of those problems and went ahead and put in exactly the same system, with the same sorts of problems. It seems that the Australian Audit Office has announced that it is going to use the same system.

I think some of these people should start looking again at the whole system of computer purchasing. Not long ago I raised the matter of some $270,000 being spent on bringing computer experts from the UK to advise on the purchase of a computer system for the Attorney-General's Department. That project has still not got off the ground. I believe the Canadian-based software in the computer system called LOIS, which was put in place for the Attorney-General's Office, has been found unsuitable and millions of dollars have been wasted. It seems that the Government's whole program of computerising everything has broken down just as the Government has.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Auditor-General's report on the procedures for dealing with fraud on the Commonwealth, I will pick up on an issue that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) tried to make capital out of a few minutes ago. Mr Acting Deputy President, you, no doubt rightly, asked me to withdraw my claim that the Minister was a fraud. I suppose fraud was on my mind. I am concerned, however, that the Minister has, in a quite disgraceful way, tried to draw a parallel between the employment, of which I know nothing, I might add, of somebody in Dr Hewson's office who is not paid by the Commonwealth but apparently paid by the Liberal Party and somebody working in Mr Ron Edwards's office who is running a business and using Commonwealth provided facilities to run that business.

PARA.TAB: I remember full well that when Senator Knowles last week asked a question of the Minister about the use of Mr Edwards's office, the Minister said he would undertake to investigate the matter. He clearly did not investigate it. He is now suggesting that he was totally dependent upon Senator Knowles providing him with information before he would investigate the matter.

That seems to be a pretty inadequate response from a Minister whose Department has already had to answer to the Auditor-General on its failure in dealing with fraud against the Department. It is an indication that the question of fraud against the Commonwealth is not exactly a burning issue with either the Department or, particularly as we see in this case, the Minister. I find that totally unsatisfactory.

It is wrong for the Minister to then try to suggest that Dr Hewson, as the Leader of the Opposition, has somebody working in his office whose salary is paid by the Liberal Party. If it is true, it is an unsatisfactory comparison. There is nothing dishonest, illegal or improper about that at all. TALK.START.PARA: —Why doesn't he chip Senator Richardson for coming in for one hour a week.

PARA.TAB: I would be very glad if I saw more of a sense of commitment from this Minister in regard to administering his portfolio. In almost any dealing I have had with the Minister over the last two or three years, I have found that the Department seems to run on and the Minister does not seem to know much about what is going on in his Department. So perhaps he will try to suggest to us that any attempt to chase up fraud in his Department is something which he knows not much about. DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1992SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Sherry, I present the fourth report of the Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Super—fiscal and social links: Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation Bill) 1992: the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992: Divisions 16-19 (inclusive) and related terms of reference, together with the transcript of evidence relating to the two Bills and submissions received by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate Senator Sherry's tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: I present the fourth report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, entitled Super—Fiscal and Social Links. As the title suggests, our report looks at two of the most important links with retirement incomes policy: how taxation affects it and how it meshes with social security.

On 12 and 15 November 1992 the Senate referred to the Committee the provisions and then the actual contents of Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992 and Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No.3) 1992, Divisions 16—19 (inclusive). Pursuant to that referral, the Committee received an additional 36 written submissions and held a public hearing on Thursday, 26 November 1992.
In tandem with the Bills referred, the Committee tackles in this Report the terms of reference dealing with taxation, social security and vesting and preservation of benefits.

Honourable Senators may care to note that, as part of its ongoing inquiry, the Committee has received over 300 written submissions and filled over 2500 pages of Hansard with transcripts of its public hearings. The topicality and importance of superannuation, both to the individual and to the economy, have ensured that our labours have attracted considerable attention. Indeed, the Committee has been at the centre of change while simultaneously pursuing its enquiries.

The work of the Committee has been well received and has led to fundamental changes in the regulation of superannuation. This is evidenced by the Strengthening Super Security Statement of the Treasurer. Similarly, the changes announced in the Treasurer's Statement Security in Retirement largely reflected the quality of the evidence that the Committee received.
So at times the Committee has followed Government action and at times it has prompted Government action.

The Committee had originally intended to report on the links between superannuation and taxation and social security in early December and the referral of the Bills to us was, thus, timely. However, it also put the Secretariat of the Committee under further pressure. As such, before moving to the substantive aspects of the Report, I would like to express my appreciation of the dedication and skill of the staff of the Committee secretariat. Since its inception, the Committee has had ten staff members at various times. The staff members who have worked on this Report are Mr Richard Gilbert (Secretary), Mr Michael Game, Mr Gary Bauer and Miss Heather Hibbitt. In addition, I wish to acknowledge the dedication of the Senate Print Room and the interest that the Usher of the Black Rod has shown in our work.

In addition, I have found that the Committee members have worked well together. We have had over 70 meetings since our inception and the sense of purpose that has surrounded our endeavours has been enthusing.

Of course, due to the subject matter of the Committee being in the political spotlight, and due to the wide-ranging nature of our inquiry, differences have arisen from time to time. But where such differences have arisen, I found that they were dealt with amicably by members.
I turn now to the reforms introduced by Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1992

Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992 substantially alters the current taxation arrangements applying to superannuation. The modifications it makes largely reflect and, I wish to add, were prompted by, the thorough and detailed evidence that the Committee received in its 300 written submissions and heard in its many days of public hearings.

The Bill substantially implements the changes foreshadowed by the Treasurer in his Security in Retirement Statement of 30 June 1992. Significant changes are made to the contributions phase of the superannuation flow. These changes include:

.replacing the confusing deduction and rebate regime for member contributions with a simple rebate. It should be noted that this rebate is intended to complement the Superannuation Guarantee Charge scheme which requires employer contributions for the benefit of nearly all employees.
.replacing the complicated limits on employer and self-employed contributions with a simple age-based scale.

These changes have excited the press and the community recently. There have been claims that the changes are unfair. Unfortunately, many commentators seemed to have missed the point that a generous voluntary scheme is not compatible with the Government's compulsory scheme. It was established earlier this year that a compulsory system is preferable to a voluntary system. Many commentators seem to also miss the point that tax expenditures—like government expenditure—need to be carefully targeted and that there are competing claims for Government attention.

As far as the benefit phase is concerned, the Bill makes important and overdue reforms. Most sweeping of these are the RBL changes. From July 1994, administration of RBLs will be undertaken by the Tax Office. In addition, the inequitable and extremely complicated RBL formula will be replaced by a flat $400,000 lump sum RBL and an $800 000 pension RBL. During the course of our inquiry there was an overwhelming call for a flat dollar RBL.

Important changes are also made to the tax treatment of pensions and roll-over annuities. These include: introducing a new 15 per cent rebate for super pensions and roll-over annuities; amendments to the definitions of undeducted purchase price and unused undeducted purchase price; and extension of the meaning of `pension' and `annuity' to ensure appropriate tax treatment for allocated pensions. As with RBLs, the Committee had heard clear calls from the community for many of these changes. It is hoped that such changes will increase the attractiveness of income-stream products and help wean people off lump sums.

Changes are also made to the rules surrounding the rolling over and taxation treatment of the concessional component of ETPs. These changes largely strengthen the integrity of the superannuation system and make sure conspicuous rorting is curtailed. The message coming from all of our reports is clear: superannuation is a means of securing a retirement income, not a means of amassing tax-free or tax-assisted wealth. Just as the Committee recommended strong controls on fund trustees in its first report, the Committee is keen to see a responsible attitude taken by beneficiaries.
Amendments are made to the Income Tax Assessment Act to achieve the above and, where necessary, supplementary amendments are made to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act.
Finally, amendments are made to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 to allow certain flat-dollar contributions made by employers to satisfy the requirements of the Act.
SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO 3) 1992
The Senate referred Divisions 16 to 19 of this Bill to the Committee, all of which deal with proposed changes to the means tests for social security benefits.

Division 16 deals with the treatment of managed investments. The changes will considerably simplify and clarify the rather complex rules in this area and also enable losses to be offset against gains on other managed investments in the same period. The basis of assessment will be the actual performance over the previous 12 months.

Division 17 exempts from the means tests money in a qualifying fund until pension age or until an annuity or pension becomes payable. This removes an inequity whereby unemployed people had their benefits reduced on account of their unpreserved benefits in such funds. Some were forced to access these funds for short-term income support rather than preserving them until retirement.

Division 18 extends to listed shares the provisions applying to managed investments. Hitherto, only dividends were brought to account, but these amendments will include the capital growth. As with managed investments, losses incurred in the same period will be offset against gains.

Division 19 deals with allocated pensions, which are a recently developed hybrid investment vehicle with some of the characteristics of annuities and others making them similar in many respects to managed investments. The amendments will remove the uncertainties which have hitherto surrounded these investments.

The ability of the recipient to vary the income stream and to withdraw the capital sum justifies their inclusion in both the income and assets tests, notwithstanding the strong representations put to us that these investments should enjoy the same privileges as conventional annuities.
CONCLUSION

However, the work of the Select Committee is not yet complete. We will now turn to an emerging issue for all fund trustees—the superannuation supervisory levy. In addition, our Report on Fees, Commissions and Disclosures will shortly be handed down. That Report will address the issues raised by the Committee's earlier options paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports of the Committee: report No. 13, Development of RAAF Base Scherger at Peppan, Cape York Peninsula, Queensland; report No. 14, Construction of an Australian embassy complex in Suva, Republic of Fiji; report No. 15, Construction of Australian embassy staff apartments at Attakarn Prasit, Bangkok, Thailand; report No. 16, Redevelopment of Lavarack army barracks in Townsville, stage 1; and report No. 17, Storage/display facility for the Australian War Memorial at Mitchell, ACT. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the reports.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: I also seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard and make a couple of remarks on that.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Development of RAAF Base Scherger at Peppan, Cape York Peninsula (Committee's 13th Report of 1992)
Construction of an Australian Embassy Complex in Suva, Republic of Fiji (Committee's 14th Report of 1992)
Construction of Australian Embassy staff apartments at Attakarn Prasit, Bangkok, Thailand (Committee's 15th Report of 1992)
Redevelopment of Lavarack Army Barracks in Townsville,
Stage 1 (Committee's 16th Report of 1992)
Construction of a storage/display facility for the Australian War Memorial at Mitchell, ACT (Committee's 17th Report of 1992)

The first report which I have just tabled relates to the development of RAAF Base Scherger at Peppan, Cape York Peninsula. The scope of the works, estimated to cost 166.65 million dollars at December 1991 prices, involves the construction of aircraft pavements, flight strips, shelters, as well as operational and technical support, accommodation, engineering and support services. Development of the RAAF Base Scherger will complete the chain of RAAF airfields across Australia's north. In peacetime the primary purpose of the airfield will be for exercises and deployments.

In recommending that the work should proceed, the Committee has concluded that whilst the scope of the proposed work is extensive, it agrees that in order for the airfield to function as a facility for exercises and deployments, it can be justified on the basis of operational requirements and experience which has been gained from the design, construction and operation of a similar facility at RAAF Base Curtin and the airfield at RAAF Base Tindal.

Selection of the site at Peppan, near Weipa, followed an extensive site selection process and the Committee has concluded that the Peppan site offers considerable advantages over the other sites examined. Furthermore, the Committee concluded that the Peppan site would not be incompatible with, and could be complementary to, any future spaceport developments on Cape York.

The Committee's inquiry focused on a number of matters and recommendations about them are in the report. They cover such things as the energy efficiency of the facilities and structures to be provided, a bush fire plan, the need for the environmental management plan to continue the process of environmental sensitivity, the haulage of rock from a quarry located 170 kilometres from the construction site, the use of the local workforce at Weipa, the process of consultation during the construction and post construction phases.

One significant feature of the construction of RAAF Base Scherger will be the use which will be made of Army engineers on selected works. This will comprise bulk earth works and heavy civil engineering construction. The Committee was advised that Army engineers have undertaken this type of work before but not on a project as large as is proposed. The Committee concluded that the use of Army engineers for construction will result in cost savings as well as providing an ideal opportunity for Army personnel to be involved in a large-scale construction project.
The second report relates to the Construction of an Australian Embassy Complex in Suva, Republic of Fiji.

The Committee was advised at the public hearing that the present Chancery is located on two floors of a high-rise building in Suva. It is in a dilapidated state and services such as lifts and airconditioning are run down. The landlord has advised he will not renew the lease on the premises which will expire in November 1994.

In February 1991 the Australian Government purchased a block of land about 3 km from the Central Business District. It is proposed to construct a Chancery, Head of Mission residence, staff accommodation and recreational facilities on this site.

The Committee was advised that although the proposal was referred to the Minister for Finance in January 1992 it was not referred to the Public Works Committee until September 1992. This has resulted in the estimated cost increasing from 7.335 million dollars to 9.368 million dollars.

Although agreeing that a need exists in Suva to construct an Australian Embassy Complex, the Committee draws attention to the continuing problems associated with overseas projects. Under present legislation the Public Works Committee is unable to meet outside Australia or its external territories. Until this legislation is amended, to enable site inspections to be carried out overseas, the Committee continues to reluctantly give approval for construction of projects which, in its view, it has been unable to properly assess.

Taking into account these reservations, the Committee recommends the Construction of an Australian Embassy Complex in Suva, Republic of Fiji at an estimated cost of 9.368 million dollars at July 1992 prices.

The third report relates to the construction of Australian Embassy staff apartments at Attakarn Prasit, Bangkok, Thailand. The Committee was advised that there has been a long-standing problem in Bangkok associated with finding suitable staff accommodation within easy reach of the Chancery.
It is proposed to build 51 apartments on a block of land owned by the Australian Government fronting Soi Attakarn Prasit.

At present eight townhouses occupy the site. These townhouses will be demolished to enable the 51 apartments to be constructed. This will optimise the use of this prime site which is presently underdeveloped. The apartments will be constructed in two blocks of six levels and will be located away from the main road. The site will be surrounded by a perimeter fence and the main gate controlled from a guardpost.

The Committee was advised that there will be an option for an Australian officer to lease an apartment to an officer of another nationality, should the officer decide to live elsewhere. The Committee however, recommends that once an apartment is leased to an officer of another nationality, that lease should be linked to the Australian officer's term of duty and should expire once that officer's posting to Bangkok is terminated.

Once again the Committee draws attention to the continuing problems associated with overseas projects. Until legislation is amended to enable site inspections to be carried out overseas, the Committee continues to reluctantly give approval for construction of projects which, in its view, it has been unable to properly assess.
It is anticipated that the work will be completed by August 1994. The limit of cost estimate of the proposed works is 16 million dollars at August 1992 prices.
The Committee recommends the Construction of Australian Embassy staff apartments at Attakarn Prasit, Bangkok.

The fourth report which I have tabled concerns the Stage 1 redevelopment of Lavarack Army Barracks in Townsville. The preliminary estimate for the works is 20.96 million dollars. The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed.

The scope of the works is generally to rectify deficiencies in the working accommodation occupied by a number of disparate elements of No. 3 Brigade, the Ready Deployment Force, which is based at Lavarack encompassing:
new permanent purpose built accommodation for 162 Reconnaissance Squadron
new accommodation for elements of No 3 Brigade Administrative Support Battalion
a new Lavarack Barracks Medical Centre
a kerbside refuelling facility.
In all instances the existing accommodation which these new facilities will replace are sub-standard and the Committee concluded that there is a need for them to be replaced.

The Committee's inquiry into this proposal focussed on a number of issues relating to the siting of the new facilities, fire protection measures, energy management and conservation and security. In all instances matters which were addressed by the Committee at the public hearing were addressed satisfactorily by the Department of Defence
The fifth report relates to the Construction of a Storage/Display facility for the Australian War Memorial at Mitchell, ACT.

The Australian War Memorial presently occupies sites at Campbell, Duntroon and Mitchell. The store at Duntroon houses large relics of war including aircraft, tanks, boats and large guns. The store has deteriorated rapidly in recent years. Flooding, vermin, lack of security and poor environmental conditions are increasing the risk of damage and destruction to very important and historically irreplaceable relics. The Duntroon store is totally unsuitable for visitors to view the objects, thus denying public access to a significant part of Australia's national cultural heritage. This storage facility will no longer be available to the War Memorial after the end of 1993, when the Army will reclaim the land for the redevelopment of the Royal Military College Logistics Complex planned for construction in financial year 1994/1995.

It is proposed to construct a building on the corner of Lysaght, Vicars and Callan Streets, Mitchell ACT. The site is already partly occupied by the Memorial's existing relic warehouse, immediately adjacent to where the proposed building will be constructed and is directly opposite the Memorial's Conservation Annex.

Public access within the building will be limited to a mezzanine level. This will ensure visitor safety as well as security for the collection. Special access for groups will be provided by prior arrangement with curatorial staff.

The building is estimated to cost 6.5 million dollars at September 1992 prices. Construction is planned to commence no later that the end of February 1993 with the building taking approximately one year to complete.
The Committee recommends the Construction of a Storage/Display facility for the Australian War Memorial at Mitchell ACT.
I commend the reports to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rather than delay the Senate by reading the tabling speech, I would like to comment on two matters. The second report relates to the construction of the Australian Embassy complex in Suva, Republic of Fiji. I am not arguing that this should not happen. In fact, the present complex is rather dilapidated and the lease arrangement has been terminated. I am concerned that the Public Works Committee discovered that this matter was referred to the Minister for Finance and approved in January 1992, but it was not referred to the Public Works Committee until September 1992 and, as a result of that delay, the estimated cost of the project has increased by just over $2m. That is a terrible waste of taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: This follows on from the sorts of things that were brought to the notice of the Senate today by Senator Parer and Senator Knowles. As Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, I assure the Senate that I will be looking at this. I am pleased to see that Senator Bolkus is in the chamber because the other concern that the Committee has—as we have said on many occasions—is that when we have to approve these overseas projects, it is always on the premise that we do not view them. We have site visits to all projects that we approve in Australia, wherever they are, and we are able to understand the situation at first hand. Yet, because of the provisions in the Public Works Committee Act 1969, which have been in place for many years, the Public Works Committee is unable to meet outside of Australia or its external territories. Each and every member of this Committee believes that that hinders our parliamentary process.

The fifth report relates to the construction of a storage-display facility for the Australian War Memorial at Mitchell. We were most concerned to see the way in which a lot of our war artefacts, which are a part of our national and cultural heritage, are being stored at the moment. We are very pleased to see that the Government has put forward this project of some $6.5m to allow what is a priceless collection of artefacts from all theatres of war in which this country has been involved to be now kept in some sort of order.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 10, page 5, subclause (1), lines 10 to 26, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(1)Section 76 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from subsection (1) `$50,000 in the case of a person not being a body corporate, or $250,000 in the case of a body corporate' and substituting `$500,000 in the case of a person not being a body corporate, or $10 million in the case of a body corporate'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment basically brings trade unions into line with the rest of the community under the secondary boycott provisions. I developed the argument during the second reading debate. I trust that the Australian Democrats will recognise the importance of treating all Australians equally, be they trade unionists or otherwise, and will therefore see the need to provide for equity within these penalties and thus support our amendment to provide penalties that are commensurate with those that will have to be paid for by bodies corporate. I do not think it necessary for me to add anything further.

PARA.TAB: As I said, we presented the argument during the second reading stage. The Democrats have had a few days to think about it. I hope that they will now recognise the merit of the argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment. We have examined it carefully. Part IV of the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 is directed towards advancing unhindered competition. Certainly, substantial penalties are required for that. We believe that section 45D and section 45E are essentially a different kind of provision and are directed towards preventing damage to employers in an industrial relations context.

PARA.TAB: The overriding reason why we believe this clause should not be amended at this stage is that it has been referred to a committee for inquiry. We believe that the whole question of section 45D and section 45E and related issues needs to be examined by that committee. We believe that these actions should be removed from the Trade Practices Act and placed in industrial relations legislation, which also provides for a labour court or for increased powers of the Industrial Relations Commission to deal with breaches of section 45D and section 45E. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing the amendments regarding penalties for breaches of sections 45D and 45E that have been moved by the Opposition. Whilst the sections are sometimes presented rhetorically in terms of union provisions, they also cover activities of business firms. We believe that when one looks at the practical application of this provision, the breaches of sections 45D and 45E have been consistently and effectively dealt with by mechanisms other than pecuniary penalties.

PARA.TAB: To move to an increase in the penalties for breaches of the sections seems unnecessary because compliance with the sections has been very largely achieved through the use of injunctions to prevent persons from continuing to breach the provisions. Following the granting of an injunction there is usually a period of negotiation and arbitration in the industrial relations area. Given the fact that no penalties have ever been sought by the Minister or the Commissioner, and they are the only ones who can bring an action for penalties, these sections do not warrant the attention which they have been paid by the Opposition.

As far as this particular amendment which the Opposition has brought forward is concerned, as Senator Spindler says, what may emerge from consideration in the Committee may be different. We can see whether the current treatment of secondary boycotts by means of this mechanism is as appropriate as it was thought to be when these sections were inserted some time ago. We believe, along with the Australian Democrats, that the matter should be left to further consideration and deliberation by the Government and by parties in this chamber after the Senate Committee reports.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 11, page 5, subclause (a), line 32, omit "$40,000", substitute "$100,000".
2.Clause 11, page 5, subclause (b), line 34, omit "$200,000", substitute "$1,000,000".

These amendments propose to amend section 79 of the Act to increase the maximum pecuniary penalties for breaches of the consumer protection provisions in part V to $1m for a body corporate and $100,000 for a natural person. At present, the maximum penalties under section 79 of the Act are $100,000 for a body corporate and $20,000 for a natural person. The Government proposes, under clause 11 of this Bill, to merely double these penalties.

PARA.TAB: However, by way of contrast, the Government has proposed to amend section 76 of the Act so that the maximum pecuniary penalty for most breaches under the competition provisions in part IV is increased from $250,000 to $10m for a body corporate and from $50,000 to $500,000 for a natural person—a 40 times increase and a 10 times increase, respectively.

It really seems as though the Government has merely plucked these figures from the air. Hence the changes to section 79 as suggested in our amendments are clearly more realistic and better proportioned with the proposed Government amendments to section 76. In addition, the Democrat amendments will reduce the temptation for body corporates to treat breaches of the consumer protection provisions like parking tickets because they will see that there is still a financial gain to be derived from a breach which attracts a relatively low penalty. For these reasons, I hope both the Government and the Opposition will support these Democrat amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —In opposing these amendments, I would not want to give an impression that the Government is not concerned with the sorts of penalties that are to apply in this area. Given the fact that, at the moment, we are very close to providing a term of reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission on issues relating to enforcement of the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act—including the question of whether penalty levels were appropriate—until we get that particular response we are not, in a fully considered way, in a position to deal with the sorts of amendments that have been brought forward by the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: There has been no consultation with the various parties. I am not even sure that I have seen—and I am not Minister for Consumer Affairs now—a great deal of material from the consumer lobby groups in relation to this matter. I may have seen one or two general letters of support for the Democrat amendment, but to my knowledge there has not been the sort of consultation that will take place when the Australian Law Reform Commission considers matters under its terms of reference. We would be able to make a better determination on this matter in light of the ALRC report and, for that reason, the Government will await that fact and not support the amendments that have been moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say very briefly that we are not supporting the further increase. Doubling seems to be reasonable at this time.

—I would like to comment briefly on one thing the Minister said. We have had representations from consumer organisations, as well as from people close to the Trade Practices Commission. I believe very strongly that the Government is showing a remarkable lack of interest in protecting the interests of consumers. I would like to press the point and again ask the Minister to respond positively.

—Mr Chairman, I do not take this cheap rhetorical politicking by Senator Spindler too seriously. The fact is that this Government, more than any other in recent times, has taken the view that the concerns of consumers are an extremely important factor in decision making.

PARA.TAB: We are simply saying that we would be better placed to respond on the question of the level of penalties in this area of the Trade Practices Act when we have the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission.
