That seems to me to be a sensible way to go. It is not simply putting the matter off. It is not simply trying, by some sort of subterfuge, to hide behind the skirts of the Australian Law Reform Commission. We believe that the report will be worth while. As I say, if it makes a recommendation in this area, we will be responding to the recommendation in a more considered way than we can this afternoon.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.After clause 12, page 5, insert the following clause:

TAB.TAB: "12A. Section 87 of the Principal Act is amended by:

PARA.TAB: (a)inserting in subsection (1A) "IV or" before "V";
(b)inserting in subsection (1B) "IV or" before "V"; and
(c)inserting in subsection (1C) "IV or" before "V".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment proposes to allow the Trade Practices Commission to enter into representative actions on behalf of one or more persons who have suffered, or are likely to suffer, loss or damage caused by someone contravening part IV of the Act. That part deals with restrictive agreements, misuse of market power, resale price maintenance and the section 50 provisions regarding mergers.

PARA.TAB: The Trade Practices Commission can already bring representative actions on behalf of one or more persons who have suffered, or are likely to suffer, loss or damage caused by someone contravening part V, the consumer protection section of the Act. This additional amendment proposes to fill a perceived gap which currently exists in the Act because the Trade Practices Commission cannot bring a representative action under part IV of the Act as it can under part V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, whilst the Government opposes the amendment moved by the Democrats, we do not want to give an impression that this matter is being ruled out of court. Whilst the Cooney Committee, when dealing with remedies, considered the question of extending the right of representative actions to part IV, it recommended that the Attorney-General give consideration to introducing a range of appropriate remedies for contraventions of part IV, and that recommendation was accepted by the Government.

PARA.TAB: But we are not in a position now in this mergers and acquisitions context, which is what this Bill is primarily about, to move to the question of remedies in the way suggested by Senator Spindler. We believe that that question—and, in the broader context, remedies generally—needs to be the subject of adequate consideration by the Government in consultation with industry and professional bodies. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has commenced consideration of the appropriateness of the remedies in the Act. I believe that that will be a sufficiently considered review of the matter to allow us to deal with this at an appropriate time, but not in the context of this Bill.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: RURAL ADJUSTMENT BILL 1992STATES GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT BILL 1992INCOME EQUALISATION DEPOSITS LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 December, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Rural Adjustment Bill 1992, the States Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Farm Household Support Bill 1992 are a package of Bills to restructure the rural adjustment scheme. The rural adjustment scheme evolved from the rural reconstruction scheme which operated from 1971 to 1977. Its original purpose was to provide Commonwealth funding for low interest, long term loans for farmers facing financial difficulties, to allow them to either become viable or be assisted out of farming. It also recognised that the criteria which governed the welfare safety net for the wage and salary work force is unsuitable for Australia's high capital self-employed farmers.

PARA.TAB: Since then, there have been a number of reviews and the current RAS is divided into three parts. Part A provides assistance for structural adjustment purposes in the form of interest subsidies, loans or grants to farmers assessed as being viable in the long term, but who are experiencing short term financial difficulties. Part B is for carry-on purposes for farmers assessed as being viable but experiencing a short term downturn through economic or climatic factors beyond their control. Assistance takes the form of short term interest subsidies or loans. Part C provides assistance in the form of household support, equivalent to Jobsearch, to farmers who are assessed as non-viable for one year with the possible extension of another year. If the farmer decides not to leave he must repay this money. If he leaves, subject to a means test, it becomes part of the $34,000 re-establishment grant.

The Rural Adjustment Bill 1992 revises the rural adjustment scheme so that at the end of eight years the farm sector, according to the Government, will be `able to thrive in a highly viable economic and natural resource environment, without relying on government assistance for survival and growth'.

The Government says it wants the national drought policy, the IED scheme and the rural adjustment scheme to function in an integrated way to encourage good management practices. Parts A, B and C of the scheme are abolished and there is now only one section which will provide interest subsidies. In normal circumstances eligible farmers will be able to obtain interest rate subsidies of up to 50 per cent. The amount will depend on individual assessment by the State agents of the RAS.

Farmers will also be able to obtain grants to improve their skill and to assist with the cost of obtaining financial, planning and other advice relating to their business. This assistance, including the States' administration costs, will be 90 per cent met by the Commonwealth and 10 per cent by the States. In exceptional circumstances, such as severe drought or substantial commodity price downturns, interest subsidies may go higher; in the past, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, has said up to 100 per cent subsidy, but most States are only taking 75 per cent because everything is on a dollar for dollar Commonwealth-State basis.

The Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, consisting of up to eight ministerial appointees, is to be established to provide the Minister with advice on the operations of the scheme from a national and strategic perspective. Its job will be to recommend an on-going strategic plan and a proposed annual program for the RAS.

The members of the Council will include one representative from the National Farmers Federation, at least one representative of the States, a Commonwealth representative and up to three people with expertise in farm management, financial administration, training, economics and sustainable agriculture. The Minister may also request the Council to provide him with advice on whether exceptional circumstances are affecting farmers and whether additional support is required. The Council will be required to submit an annual report to the Minister. It can form subcommittees and will consult with interested parties, including the States.

Farmers considered non-viable will be assisted to leave the farm with a re-establishment grant of up to $45,000 when they have nil or negative assets. This is to provide a deposit on a house for the family as the farm home cannot be sold separately from the farm and has little or no value. The major impediment to a farmer quitting is the family home problem. There will be no other assistance through the rural adjustment scheme.

The States Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill ratifies the agreements which have been reached between the Federal Government and the States of New South Wales and Queensland for the distribution of the $14m provided in the Budget for drought assistance by way of interest subsidies. The scheme has been operating since 1 September.

The Farm Household Support Bill has been taken out of part C of the rural adjustment scheme. It is now considered a welfare measure. Household support, at rates equivalent to Jobsearch allowance, are available to farmers who are considered non-viable and who cannot obtain finance and need assistance in meeting day to day living expenses.

The legislation is within the primary industries and energy portfolio and will be administered by the Department of Social Security on an agency basis. Farm household support will be income tested, but farm assets have been excluded from the assets test, including working capital from the farm. The funds will be available as a loan for two years to those who believe they have a future in farming and to those who make the decision to leave farming. However, the money paid in the first nine months will become a grant for those who leave farming and they may also be eligible for the re-establishment grant through the rural adjustment scheme. If they can leave the farm before the nine months are up, they will be able to cash out the full nine months. With this and the re-establishment grant, it is theoretically possible to get up to $55,000.

Farmers who do not leave at the end of two years will not qualify for the grant period and will have to repay all the farm household support received. Farmers will only be required to submit an application for farm household support with the Department of Social Security. Jobsearch allowance will still be available to farmers and their spouses under normal and hardship provisions, but farm families who choose Jobsearch will lose their access to the rural adjustment scheme re-establishment grant once the farmer or spouse has received nine months of Jobsearch allowance payments.

The nine months period will be calculated from the introduction of the farm household support scheme. With the introduction of the new scheme, those on the modified scheme introduced in December 1991 until they are no longer eligible—presumably through improved income—or when the scheme sunsets in December 1993 will have the option of transferring to farm household support. Those currently receiving farm household support under part C of the rural adjustment scheme will be transferred automatically to the new scheme. Importantly, the new scheme has been agreed to by all State governments.

There has been criticism by the coalition of the clumsy attempts by the Labor Government to provide food on the table for cash-starved farmers who usually do not qualify for Jobsearch or other benefits. The failure of those schemes has forced the Labor Government to move closer to coalition policy.

The Government is abandoning its efforts to provide a Jobsearch allowance to farmers in extreme hardship and is now going back to household support, but this is not to be under the rural adjustment scheme and will still be a loans scheme unless the recipient quits farming. Minister Crean promised unemployment benefits to 2,000 farmers when the scheme was introduced, but only 300 people have been assisted. Why is the new household support scheme being administered by the Department of Social Security? Its staff has a bad track record in dealing with self-employed people. The rural adjustment scheme officers have an understanding of farmers and are better placed to administer the total rural adjustment scheme.

Coalition policy to help farmers suffering hardship involves restoring household support as an income tested welfare grant for a period of nine months before any decision has to be made about quitting the farm. We would return the far more limited category of severe drought to the cooperative Federal-State natural disaster arrangements.

While the coalition will not be opposing these Bills, I point out that the coalition has superior policies to that of the Government with regard to severe drought and household support. Certainly, after the next election we will be in a position to implement them, and will do so. We are also not entirely sure that the splitting of the rural adjustment scheme between the State adjustment agencies and the Department of Social Security is entirely suitable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Rural Adjustment Bill 1992. I bring a message from the people of the bush: the veil of distance and ignorance must be lifted so the Parliament sees clearly the sacrifice and struggle of rural families trying to hold on to Australia's rural heritage and economic future. Rural and mining commodities constitute the bulk of our exports. Our economic dependence on a healthy rural sector is as fundamental as ever. In these times of dramatic trade deficits and foreign debt, it is more precious than ever. Once again it will fall to the rural sector to play a fundamental role in turning the national economy around to stimulate growth and investment once the tide of commodity prices and the weather turn in our favour.

PARA.TAB: In recent years many have experienced the worst floods and droughts on record, the highest interest rates, the highest input costs, the greatest fall in commodity prices and the greatest fall in asset values. Rural incomes have plummeted. The wool industry provides a spectacular example of the conditions facing graziers who survived the abolition of the wool floor price. The price of wool is currently around 500c a kilogram. ABARE says that the average cost of production is 610c a kilogram and that the average wool producer will have a negative income of $39,000 this year. It is a matter of time—time which our producers do not have under the present regime.

The extent of the crisis has been exacerbated by many factors. Drought has passed its dry and withered hand over much of southern and central Queensland and western New South Wales. The barren landscape can scarcely support mulga scrub, let alone stock. In many places there have been no lambs for two years. Stock numbers are down by at least a third, the surviving stock are old and weak, and the wool quality is low. Time will also bring rain—but how many producers will be there to see it, let alone have the resources to take advantage of it? Structural adjustment is a necessary part of any efficient industry, but we are in danger of allowing too many producers to leave.

The major difference between this and past rural recessions is the excessive farm debt level. The 1980s saw interest rates of up to 25 per cent for working capital and 23 per cent for property mortgages. Urged on by government experts and lending institutions, producers borrowed to follow, ironically, best risk management practice to enlarge and drought-proof their properties. But with the untimely onset of drought and dramatically rising interest rates, their asset value and equity fell while debt repayments and total debt soared. Any liquid assets have been used to service debt. Labour and other costs have been pared to the bone. Producers are shearing all of their own sheep. There is no money for mustering, shearing and fencing contractors or for property repairs and maintenance, let alone any environmental issues.

In the drought stricken areas, with their greater feed demands, a producer can break even only if there is no debt to service. That means no mortgage, no working capital, no overdraft, no lease repayments and no Bankcards. Yet approximately 1,100 properties in drought stricken south-west Queensland and central west Queensland have an average debt of $350,000. Properties in south-west Queensland alone have a total debt of $200m, up from $140m. Average equity in these grazing enterprises has fallen from 79 per cent in 1985-86 to 58 per cent in 1992-93.

ABARE estimates that those with less than 70 per cent equity are at risk. Under such conditions, producers cannot go forward. Every season their equity in their property is lower; the property and its improvements deteriorate; stock numbers and quality fall. Families in their hundreds, many of whom have lived on the land for generations, are leaving the industry, with nothing to show for the millions of export dollars they have earned for Australia.

The shearing, fencing, transport and mustering contractors they once employed are now jobless. The business they once brought to regional towns has disappeared, taking several businesses along with it. The orders for plant and equipment and consumer items from city centres are sent no more. Left unchecked, with no commodity prices and weather relief, it is only a matter of time before the relocation and rural upheaval become so great that outback Australia will resemble a bleached skeleton, with foreign buyers circling above. It will take years to redress the economic and social consequences of an eroded rural base and divided regional economies.

The Government has introduced some measures under the rural adjustment scheme which aim to alleviate the economic distress of rural families by assisting them to leave and encouraging viable properties to stay in business. An amount of $166.4m has been allocated for 1992-93. In the previous year $157m was spent, of which $14m went to administration. The number of farm household recipients is expected to double and re-establishment grants will increase correspondingly. It appears from this that the same amount of Commonwealth funds will have to cover a lot more people than the previous year, at a time when rural conditions are deteriorating.

Eligibility for the main category of assistance, a maximum of $30,000 interest subsidy, is dependent upon proving viability. Under the present market and weather conditions, this is largely a Utopian concept. Access to these funds is therefore very restricted. Even so, two-thirds of the $30m allocated for debt reconstruction interest subsidies has already been spent, though we are only six months into the year. Demand for these funds will only increase. This is a neglectful and shameful response of a government supposedly committed to efficient rural adjustment.

The economic and social costs of inadequate assistance now will be paid for in later years. This is not a forward looking or realistically timed adjustment package. It targets too few producers. In drought stricken areas the top 10 per cent or 20 per cent of the properties are ineligible because they are using off-farm assets to carry them through. The next 40 per cent are in the eligibility range but could drop out unless there is rain soon and some increase in the wool price. These producers live in fear of getting a letter from the Government's agent informing them that they are no longer viable and will not be eligible for further interest subsidies. The power of government agencies like the QIDC in Queensland is immense. They hold the future of families and enterprises in their hands. Mail from the QIDC is treated with the same apprehension as an official telegram during the war.

The new RAS guidelines are still being worked out, leading to more instability. It is impossible to make effective business decisions or to authoritatively advise on the availability of government assistance. Viability is a very precarious commodity. Frequently, a producer is told that he is viable one season but not the next, or that he is doing too well one year and too badly the next.

Then there is the bottom 50 per cent of producers who are ineligible for these subsidies because the Government does not consider that they can become viable in the long term with the level of assistance being offered. Just the presence of off-farm income sustaining the property can lead to an ineligibility ruling. Rejected farmers and their wives then work twice as hard on and off the farm to make up the differences that a $30,000 interest subsidy would make.

Most of the inefficient producers have already left. The lowest 10 per cent of producers have so little equity that their future in the industry must seriously be doubted, but that still leaves 40 per cent of producers out in the cold. Thousands of farming families are left to carry on as best they can with no assistance to keep the property running and their assets intact. Producers who paid $20 an acre four years ago would be lucky to get $4 an acre now. They are trapped between clinging to their capital investment in the hope of better returns in the future and walking out with nothing except a re-establishment grant from the Government.

There is very little demand for sheep grazing land while the wool stockpile exists and the drought continues. The future of both the wool industry and the land itself is at stake. If the Government fails to provide incentives to buyers and to present improved land management practices to owners, the same situation could arise in another 10 years, when another third of the industry might have to leave.

The RAS legislation allows for a $45,000 re-establishment grant for producers who sell up and walk out with next to nothing within two years of taking farm household support. I do not wish to criticise the provision of this grant because I know that every dollar is appreciated by the producers who have no option but to leave. However, the story does not end once the farmer leaves, nor is the cheque his to do what he wants with it. It is generally drawn down for a deposit when the ex-farmer has found a house to purchase. Who will lend the balance to an unemployed farmer in the city?

Another major aim of RAS is to help with the normal living costs such as food, clothes and education of rural families undergoing severe cash shortages. This cash poverty is widespread and creating great distress. It is ironic that only days ago the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, was talking about Australia becoming the food bowl of Asia while our farmers are struggling to put bowls of food on their own tables.

Aid agencies such as the St Vincent de Paul Society and the Salvation Army are picking up the tab for telephone and car registration bills. During the Great Depression, feral rabbits were hunted to sustain poverty stricken families. These days it is the killing of feral goats and kangaroos that brings in sorely needed cash. Children's education, that essential ingredient of a clever country, is being terminated early as parents can no longer bear the expensive burden of sending their children away to school. This is a great loss not only to the children's future but also to their country's future. The Government is constantly telling us about the need for well trained agribusiness producers, but where will they come from if those from the land, with hands-on experience, do not finish high school, let alone go on to further education?

In this building we turn on the taps and there is water. We go to the dining room and there is abundant food. The gardens are watered freely. We do not have to go outside and fiddle with a generator to have light. We make thousands of telephone calls with no thought of cost. We drive in chauffeured cars without noting the mileage. Yet the people out in the bush whom we serve endure a totally different lifestyle.

We must think how in these tough times a telephone call to a near neighbour or a town is STD-rated and now is unaffordable. Trips to town use up too much precious petrol. Just taking the kids down the drive to the bitumen road to meet the school bus costs one family a drum of petrol every fortnight. The loneliness and isolation that previously gave freedom have become an endless, monotonous prison. Household water has to be carted daily. Water rationing and recycling is a great burden on household chores. It is only relatively early summer, but already babies are being bathed five times a day to keep them cool. Outside there are no gardens and no birds; nothing is green. Perhaps there is a dead kangaroo and a joey to be cleared out of the bore drain or some sheep bogged in the mud of a former dam.

Last Christmas aid agencies were shocked by the neediness of rural families. The pride of these people has concealed the disturbing poverty. They are the last to ask for help, yet right now they are the first to need it. One household celebrated last Christmas with a Red Cross pudding, and this Christmas will be worse. The CWA, which provides Christmas hampers, will not be including gifts for children in some areas this year because the more practical items must take priority.

The strain on households is immense, leading to health and marriage breakdowns. The men pull and push scrub with dozers, chains and chainsaws to feed their shrinking flocks from dawn till after dark, day after day, month after month. They return home too late to see their young children and too exhausted to do more than sleep. Grandmothers are working beside their menfolk on the dozers, unable to spend time with their grandchildren. Fathers are devastated and guilt ridden that they will be unable to pass on the property to their children, as it was passed on to them.

They fear for their future as breadwinners of the family in cities where their skills will be irrelevant and their age against them. Parents watch in despair as their sons and daughters and neighbours leave to join unemployment queues a thousand kilometres away. They watch the dry dust eat away at their life's work, their strength and their pride. The ground is so thirsty that mulga is turning charred and ashen. Red dust swells like flames, in a creation of rural life. Mothers are exhausted with the effort of keeping households together. Not only do they have the responsibility of housekeeping and the care of the children, but often their education as well. They also make time for whatever farm work they can to replace the unaffordable hired labour.

They drive to town, put their young children into day care and return to the dozers. Those who live close to town—that is, within 150 kilometres—compete for scarce off-farm work, putting their children into day care. Sometimes they stay in town with their children while their husbands carry on alone at the property. It is the women who are bringing in the cash that puts food on the table and fuel in the dozer, not necessarily in that order. It is the women who struggle with the stream of government forms inquiring into every aspect of their lives as they attempt to tap into some form of assistance. It is extremely difficult to provide the necessary paperwork when one's accountant has not been paid for two or three years.

The assistance being offered is slim indeed. Under the old scheme, wives could apply for the standard Jobsearch allowance, or the JSA hardship category, which took into account their specialist situation of being so-called asset rich while income poor. If they lived within 150 kilometres of a town they had to work at whatever positions were available in the town, sometimes three or four different part-time jobs a week if they were lucky. Husbands seldom applied because they were trying to keep the property running.

Under the new system, the modified form of JSA will be abolished. Those who remain able to qualify for the standard JSA will forfeit all rights to a re-establishment grant after nine months. So the only real alternative for cash strapped families will be to apply for the farm household support, which is the same rate as JSA. This farm household support comes with strangling strings attached. It is basically a loan. If one can sell one's property within nine months of first receiving FHS, then nine months of farm household support is provided as a grant. If one takes more than nine months to leave, one has to pay the extra FHS back. If the farm is not sold within two years, there will be no further payments and the grant then becomes a loan. The Commonwealth will step in to recover the outstanding 24 months of FHS debt. If the producer wishes to continue to receive FHS after nine months, he must commit himself to selling his property. To apply for FHS is really to commit one's family to leaving the property, leaving the region and leaving the whole rural sector behind.

This is a no-win situation for producers who are temporarily strapped for cash but are confident of a turnabout in the near future and who are determined to cling to their life's investment—an investment that has earned millions of dollars for Australia. It is a no-win situation for the grazing industry which is losing irreplaceable, expert and efficient producers; and it is a no-win situation for the overall national interest, which will depend on the rural sector to drive an economic recovery once drought and market conditions improve. Nowhere else in Australia does accepting unemployment or other benefits mean that one has to sell up one's home and pay the money back later. Nowhere else are our best performing exporters being repatriated to city unemployment queues. It is not surprising that producers are preferring to work themselves into the ground and live hand to mouth rather than take this tied assistance from the Government.

If the hundreds of thousands of unemployed in the cities were told to pay back their payments after nine months, and sell their houses into the bargain, there would be an outcry. The suburban unemployed are not required to do long hours of unpaid work to keep a national resource alive so that in the future it can reap millions of dollars of export earnings. Last financial year, the Government spent $5.4m of household support to keep 766 producers in basic necessities. In the light of the hundreds of millions of dollars spent on unemployment benefits and costly temporary employment creating schemes—such as teaching kids how to build paths through parks—is it too much to ask for some equity for people in the bush?

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy says that taxpayers' money is best invested in those farmers who have the capacity to make the most of government financial support and to become independent of the support within a reasonable time. Why is that maxim not being applied in other sectors of the economy? Billions of dollars are being spent bailing out banks and government errors and writing off huge entrepreneurial debt. Is it too much to ask for greater access to a rural adjustment scheme with a total budget of $166m? Is it too much to ask for some paltry household support to be given out and not lent? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was asking whether it was too much to ask to have a rural sector poised to take advantage of improved market and climatic conditions. Most of our inefficient producers have already gone, and if we continue to prune the industry along the current RAS guidelines, we risk mortally wounding the whole industry. As the drought and low commodity prices continue, fewer and fewer will be able to satisfy the RAS eligibility guidelines relating to viability. Already the Government is leaving four in 10 drought stricken properties swinging, with no help except to leave the industry. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has put out a paper saying that 6,000 to 7,000 producers will finish their RAS contracts this year. Their fates are unknown and their prospects are grim. It is impossible to go forward under present conditions. A sudden large exodus in six to seven months time is being forecast.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) recently suggested that Waltzing Matilda become our national anthem, to better represent our national identity and heritage. The Matilda Highway in Queensland begins at Cunnamulla and passes through Charleville, Augathella, Tambo, Blackall, Barcaldine, Ilfracombe, Longreach and north to Karumba. The first white settlers there opened up vast tracts of country in the most primitive conditions to forge a strong rural based economy. The Australian Labor Party and the National Party have their origins there. One of the world's leading international airlines was born there, and the Royal Flying Doctor Service began there.

This area is now largely under drought. It is quintessential Australian heritage. Yet, if we were to sing Waltzing Matilda now, it would be as a requiem, not as an anthem. Just as the legendary swaggie said, `You'll never catch me alive', so the people of the bush are fighting back, refusing to give up their heritage and our heritage. They are stubborn fighters, resilient, improvising, hardworking, hospitable, patriotic and heroic. The national character being searched for by the Prime Minister and the academic think-tanks is alive and well in the people of the bush. The ghosts of those destroyed by the Government's squattocracy and bureaucratic troopers will forever haunt this Labor Government and the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak on the Rural Adjustment Bill 1992, the States Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill 1992, the Farm Household Support Bill 1992 and the Income Equalisation Deposits Laws Amendment Bill 1992, I could not help but be impressed by Senator Boswell's speech. He obviously spoke on behalf of Queensland, which is in the grip of a very serious drought. Fortunately, on the western side of the continent things are not quite as bad because of the reasonably good seasons that we have had since 1983. That was when the last drought was and, of course, that was when this Government went into power and started the drought in the west. It claims to have ended the drought of the east, but it started the drought in the west. Fortunately, we have had only the one in that period.

PARA.TAB: There are other reasons why, as Senator Boswell said, there are problems with the rural industry, and one is low commodity prices. I know that wool has taken a hit in the last three or four years in Australia, but that was not the fault of even this Government. Yes, it was a mistake of the then Primary Industries and Energy Minister, Mr Kerin, not to call a halt to the reserve price scheme before it was stopped, but it was also the greed of the industry which led to its downfall.

Commodity prices are fairly reasonable in the wheat industry, considering the bad situation in the northern hemisphere where a lot of the wheat has been downgraded. At a meeting that I attended about six weeks ago in Western Australia, I was castigated for saying a few things—in other words, for telling some home truths. But I found out at that same meeting that even the high rainfall areas have their problems—and I did not quite think that problems had extended to those areas. I farm in a low rainfall area. We always used to say, and still say, `If only we had better rainfall, what we would be able to do'.

Unfortunately, having had a good look at the high rainfall areas this year, I can see a lot of problems. People in those areas call it a green drought. They have not been hit by wool commodity prices going down, and beef prices, although not so good, are reasonable, but other factors have affected them—as well as the Government's policies, of course, but I will leave them aside for the moment and concentrate on the factors relating to the farmers.

In the past there have been poor commodity prices, as I have mentioned; there has been some bad management; and, worst of all, there has been bad advice from farm advisers and bank managers. I have always said that if I had to use a farm adviser I would leave farming, and I still say that today. Unfortunately, some farmers have relied too much on what farm advisers have had to say—and we might have one in the chamber now—and far too much on bank managers who have vested interests in the money they are spending. I believe that, in the years to come, if farmers are better educated to make their own decisions on finance, it will improve their farm management.

Senator Boswell led me away from what I was going to speak on—that is, the Rural Adjustment Bill, the Farm Household Support Bill and, mainly, the Income Equalisation Deposits Laws Amendment Bill. I will address the Income Equalisation Amendment Bill first. This is almost a sessional Bill, because every year of the five years that I have been in this place we have amended the income equalisation deposits legislation.

When Labor came to Government in 1983 the real changes started in IED. The original Bill was brought in 1976, under the Fraser Government—I think it was introduced by Ian Sinclair in the other place—and the income equalisation deposits scheme was brought in. It means exactly what it says—excess funds can be deposited in one year, and kept there for the bad times. That was done at a low interest rate, just to cover inflation. I believe that scheme worked very well.

Unfortunately, with the ascent of the Labor Government in 1983, Senator Walsh, a farmer himself, as Minister for Finance, believed—and I suppose believed rightly—that there was some abuse of IEDs. I maintain that if there were any abuses of IEDs, they would have been very minimal. Unfortunately, Senator Walsh changed what I believe was not a bad system at all. The first IEDs were subject to low interest rates—they were increased a bit later on—and were getting well used. At that time, I believe there was about $180m in funds—I might be wrong but it was about that figure. If someone knows better, please let me know.

The IED scheme started to go wrong when the interest rates were increased, because then they were used rather as an investment, I suppose, and not really as an IED—income equalisation deposit. But as I said, Senator Walsh thought that the scheme was being rorted. It might have been, very slightly, but not on a big scale. There was a second edition under the Fraser coalition Government and the interest rates were put up. The third edition was Senator Walsh's first edition, and I do not really remember what he then did with them exactly.

Beyond that Senator Walsh went into a second edition, with investment and non-investment portions. Withholding tax at 29 per cent was retained on the non-investment portion of 61 per cent. We are now on the fifth edition, where the minimum deposit has decreased from $5,000 to $1,000, the maximum deposit has increased from $250,000 to $300,000 and withholding tax is down from 29 per cent to 20 per cent. The fact is that the average tax rate for a farmer in a recession, a drought or at a time of low commodity prices would now be in that area.

There has also been the creation of farm management bonds, where interest is paid on 80 per cent of the deposit rather than 61 per cent. These bonds can be withdrawn only for drought, fire and flood. I agree with that. To have true income equalisation deposits, one must be able to hold them in the scheme for as long as possible for those eventualities.

However, farmers are not able to make a deposit in the bonds if they have off-farm income of more than $50,000. I believe this is wrong. If the Government wants to encourage this new system, I believe the bonds should be open to everyone. I have always believed that off-farm income was the best part of income equalisation deposits because it was always steady. Unfortunately, this Government is discouraging farmers by differentiating between off-farm and on-farm income.

Any interest that is obtained by farmers as carry-on finance would be declared non-farm income. For instance, the income of any person in this place is certainly non-farm income. Non-farm income also includes ownership of a few units or shares in a local co-op and that sort of thing. For the farm management bond system to work properly and be a genuine tool to even out a farmer's situation, a farmer should be able to store reserve cash, just as he has reserve fodder in case of a drought. I believe that that would be a good way to go. However, anyone with that sort of other off-farm income is wiped out. I presume that part of that off-farm income is the interest on IEDs. If the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer thinks I am wrong in this, I ask him to correct me later. I have already mentioned bank interest.

What knocks the IEDs in the long term and does not make them very attractive is that they are still covered under the provisional tax arrangements. I cannot see why the new rate of 20 per cent withholding tax should be applied to the 61 per cent because it is already covered by provisional tax. The farmers need to put money into IEDs but the provisional tax tends to kill the scheme off. One solution would be for the Government to remove the withholding tax. Provisional tax is set at 10 per cent. This year I believe there will be an 8 per cent uplift in the provisional tax factor. I have mentioned the provisional tax readjustment with all the penalties to go with it. So much for the IEDs. The Government has made a forward step with the FMB scheme and the payment of interest on 80 per cent and with the reduction of withholding tax to 20 per cent, but I am afraid it has not gone far enough.

I want to make a few brief points on the Rural Adjustment Bill 1992. As Senator Tambling pointed out, this Bill abolishes parts A, B and C of the rural adjustment scheme. Only one section will now provide interest subsidies where, under normal circumstances, eligible farmers will be able to obtain interest rate subsidies of up to 50 per cent. The Commonwealth will pick up 90 per cent of that cost and the States will pick up 10 per cent of it. I understand that in extreme circumstances, such as drought, the Commonwealth will pick up more of the cost.

So I welcome the measure. It is preferable to having RAS divided into parts A, B and C, as there have been many problems with RAFCOR in each State. The subsidies can be used in various ways. They can even be used to obtain grants to improve skills and, as I said earlier, to assist with financial planning advice. That is very important and very welcome.

Another Bill at hand is the Farm Household Support Bill 1992. This Bill, which comes under the Department of Primary Industries and Energy portfolio, will be administered by the Department of Social Security. I believe that it should always have been so, because it is a social security measure and rural dwellers should be treated like anyone else in Australia. Farm household support will be income tested but farm assets, including working capital, are not to be counted in the assets test. We thanked the Government for that small mercy at the time. The Farm Household Support Bill brings rural dwellers into line with their city cousins, except that there is a limit on the grant. The grant lasts for up to nine months, but beyond that it takes the form of a loan. Senator Boswell pointed out that that provision should be looked at a second time.

Finally, I intend to address very briefly the national residue survey levy legislation. This legislation will enable the Commonwealth to recover 100 per cent of the costs of residue testing instead of the current 60 per cent. I know that the Cattle Council of Australia, on behalf of those in the cattle industry, has made a big objection to this legislation. Our family is also involved in the cattle industry. We believe that we should pay our share of residue testing, but I also believe that the public interest has a stake in this matter. A fifty-fifty payment system, which is the coalition's policy, should be the way to go.
I welcome most of the measures that are contained in these Bills. For a change, the rural industry Bills are not being debated at 2 a.m. on the last day of sittings, which is what usually happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a few more yet. Wait until Wednesday.

—Yes, there are a few more. But I am happy to see these Bills being debated at a reasonable time. As I said, I welcome most of the measures that are contained in these Bills. However, I believe that the Government has a long way to go in respect of some measures, which are ones that we will be addressing in government in years to come. In particular, the fuel levy will be abolished under a coalition government. Senator McMullan will immediately want to tell me that farmers do not pay a fuel levy. However, the transporters who bring all the goods in and out and all the other farm costs that are allied to the rural industry, such as chemicals, are affected by fuel levies, sales tax, payroll tax and all those other taxes that we will remove when we are elected to government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing stands as a greater testament to this Labor Government's incompetence than the continuing crisis in the bush. While unfavourable commodity prices and drought have been contributing factors to the desperate situation of many farmers, undoubtedly the central cause has been the failed economic management of this Government.

PARA.TAB: The Hawke-Keating Labor governments have failed rural people by dramatically raising interest rates to induce the recession we had to have. As a result, many farmers were irretrievably crippled when their interest rates on existing loans soared to more than 20 per cent as against 14 per cent when originally undertaken. Although interest rates have subsequently fallen under the impact of Australia's worst recession since the Great Depression, the damage has been done, with debt having compounded on debt as a direct consequence of the Government's single-pronged approach to economic management.

The Hawke and Keating Labor governments have also failed rural people by failing to initiate adequate micro-economic reform to allow farmers to reduce their costs of production to offset to some extent poorer commodity prices. In short, the Government has failed dismally to take initiatives of which it should have been capable to remove Australia's farmers from the worst cost-price squeeze they have experienced. Caught in this bind, farmers have desperately sought to survive through cost cutting of every possible kind—cost cutting which does not necessarily improve efficiency or productivity of the farming enterprise because it often involves not undertaking maintenance when needed or replacing machinery when necessary.

Farmers were also forced to make great efforts to obtain off-farm jobs and income. This has meant a serious imbalance between the farm labour force and the amount of work to be done covering the ground and maintaining farm standards, because many farms are not returning an adequate income to support their labour requirements. Not only have farmers been unable to employ workers to maintain standards but also in too many cases even the next generation of farmers, the children of owners, who would normally work on the farm and eventually take it over, have had to leave for other jobs because of grossly inadequate farm income.

Meanwhile, there is too much work for the farmer to get through. This has been described as the `work for three, pay for one syndrome', which would certainly not be tolerated in any other industry. Serious consequences for farmers have been stress, overwork and increased health problems.

Undoubtedly family farms are the normal unit of rural settlement and production and, indeed, the most efficient such unit. It should be the aim of public policy to keep the family farm as the basis of agricultural settlement. There is no real benefit to Australian agriculture or its key role as an export earner in seeing large tracts of land transferred to agribusiness firms, foreign investors or investment companies which have no real interest in the future of rural districts. The local experience, expertise, attachment to the land and community and sheer staying power of family farmers cannot be replaced by alternative forms of ownership and operation.

Certainly not all farmers, irrespective of their management skills or long term prospects, should be bailed out by the taxpayers. But we should be seeking to retain as high a rural population density and as many farm families as possible rather than seek to remove farm families. In particular, there should be encouragement for the next generation of farmers to fight through the current malaise.

Inadequate net farm incomes have forced a large proportion of young people to leave farms against their own desires. The average age of farmers continues to rise and the arrival of a new generation is further delayed. The serious question is whether young people who have been forced to leave the farm will ever return to take over from their parents. This is an issue which public policy must urgently address. This malaise afflicts primary production Australia-wide. It has been researched and documented in detail over the last seven years in the Cleve area of Eyre Peninsula in South Australia by Dr Peter Smailes from the Department of Geography at the University of Adelaide. In one of his studies, he concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: It is impossible to conduct field work on Eyre Peninsula without absorbing the feeling of bitterness, frustration and anger among farmers at the heavy interest repayments, costs, charges, taxes and apparent unwillingness or inability of the community at large to give meaningful assistance in a situation over which they have no control. To work so hard for almost no returns, and at the same time to have to pay so much to service debts incurred under quite different conditions, is understandably a cause of great personal stress.

This highlights the urgent need for much greater micro-economic reform, including deregulation of the labour market to allow a reduction in the cost side of farmers' equations. The issues I have raised also provide a basis for assessing the four pieces of rural assistance legislation before us this evening.

PARA.TAB: The Income Equalisation Deposits Law Amendment Bill seeks to amend the IED scheme to reduce the amount of withholding tax at the time of withdrawal, to reduce the amount required to make a deposit and to increase the maximum amount allowed in the scheme. It also introduces farm management bonds, which are a modified form of IEDs.

Essentially, over its time in office, this Government has demolished the IED scheme originally put in place by the Liberal and National parties. The purpose of the scheme was to encourage farmers to insure themselves by boosting their savings in years of good income and thereby provide for themselves when times were less abundant. But there had to be an incentive for them to do that.

Throughout the 1980s, when this Labor Government was tampering with the scheme, it removed that inducement. Indeed, when the Government claimed yet again a couple of years ago that it would be improving the scheme, it announced changes 12 months in advance. But, had that scheme as announced come into effect from the time of its Budget announcement, there would have been a not inconsiderable investment made at that time by the wool industry, because the wool reserve price scheme was still intact.

Because of the 12-month delay in introducing the scheme's changes, the Government ripped additional income tax from woolgrowers' pockets. This effectively prevented sound and considerable investment from the industry in IEDs which would have provided invaluable assistance to those woolgrowers now and which would have ultimately meant a reduced need for them to call on the rural adjustment scheme.

These present changes merely demonstrate that the Government has at least recognised those fundamental flaws and inadequacies and is prepared to make adjustments, albeit inadequate ones. If the scheme is to be worthwhile and beneficial for farmers, why should a farmer be paid interest on only 61 per cent of the cash he deposits in an IED, when he would most probably be paying tax at a rate well under 39c?

Indeed, why should a farmer in a desperate predicament such as drought pay 20 per cent withholding tax when he draws out of either scheme when he has already paid provisional tax? Why is it that a farmer who faces some personal adversity should suffer a loss of interest on 19 per cent of his farm management bond deposit just because he draws out at a time when it is officially not a drought or a catastrophic natural disaster? Do his personal circumstances make his suffering any less real? Even with these changes, the IED scheme remains grossly inadequate.

With regard to the rural adjustment amendment, the legislation will simplify the existing scheme by implementing a single interest rate subsidy scheme of up to 50 per cent for those considered viable, with an additional rate subsidy in exceptional circumstances. However, it depends on just how much the individual States are prepared to provide and, as we already know, this has often been too little, too late. Indeed, there is clearly a greater need here for the States to accept their responsibility in this regard and to extend their obligations to include the difficulties experienced by farming people.

Shortcomings remain with the transfer of the household support component to the Department of Social Security away from the Rural Adjustment Authority, although the Government has recognised the failure of its earlier attempts to apply the Jobsearch allowance to farmers. Some 12 months ago about 2,000 farmers were to become eligible. The rural sector claimed that at least 5,000 needed to come within the criteria if the assistance were to make an impact. I understand that ultimately only some 300 came within the scheme and it has been dropped.

The household support legislation provides an income tested and off-farm asset tested equivalent for a nine-month period as a grant, provided that the farmer then leaves the farm. I understand that the rehabilitation grant is also being increased to $45,000. However, some problems exist when looking at household support and rural adjustment together, particularly in light of my earlier comments regarding the need to keep as many as possible on the land.

The Government must look at the situation of the farmer differently. How does one assess the viability of a farmer or the productivity of a farm in a drought or during a severe downturn in commodity prices? How does the Government calculate at that time whether a farmer would have a viable future in a year's time? The fact is that one cannot, and the Government should at least acknowledge that a farmer needs time to sort out the maze which then closes in around the family in such a situation. The Government should not immediately attempt to draft him through one gate or the other. Market forces or climatic conditions may change, which may eventually assist that farmer.

This is where the coalition policy on this matter is so much better. Providing the farmer with a nine-month, income-tested welfare grant, equivalent to the Jobsearch allowance and which is not conditional on whether or not the farmer finally leaves the farm, is an infinitely more sensible and equitable approach. There are also problems with regard to this issue concerning the inflexibility of the Department of Social Security, which is unable to deal effectively with asset rich, cash poor clients. It is not a Department that is structured to deal efficiently with the needs of farmers in this regard.

Again, as Senator Panizza said, the Government's inability to manage its legislative program means that, as in the past but perhaps even worse this year, legislation dealing with rural issues is crammed in at the last minute of the sittings of this Parliament and those of us on the Opposition side have to restrict the time that we speak on it.

In drawing my remarks to a close, I draw attention to the changes to drought relief which, again, is an improvement, but still does not match the provision provided by the Opposition whereby, when in government, we will restore to the list of cooperative Federal-State arrangements for disasters, measures dealing with the occurrence and effects of severe drought. While we do not oppose this legislation, we certainly draw attention to its inadequacies.

This Labor Government ought to feel ashamed that it has misunderstood and misread the needs of farmers and their families for so long and not dealt with them in an optimal way. In addition to needing a Liberal and National Party in government to provide a more relevant approach to rural assistance, farmers, perhaps more than any other section of the community, desperately need the benefits which only Fightback can provide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are addressing a package of Bills that will greatly affect rural Australia and rural Australians. The Income Equalisation Deposits Laws Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill, the Rural Adjustment Bill and the Farm Household Support Bill go together to map out the Government's program for farming in the 1990s. Before I address details specific to these Bills, I want to note that the Democrats will be moving amendments which will be circulated shortly.

PARA.TAB: I want to talk in general and historic terms about the approach that is being adopted here tonight. I believe this package takes us further along the economic rationalist path in agriculture. It is aimed at further corporatisation of agriculture with little regard for community consequences. It seems to be the Government's intention to remove as many farm families as is possible, not only from the land but from rural communities altogether.

The United States now has lost about 30 per cent of its farm families since Reaganomics began in the 1980s and we are right on track to emulate them. In fact, a front page report in the Weekly Times two weeks ago under the headline `Farmer exodus tipped' suggested that rural counsellors around Australia had been told that one in five farm families may indeed be forced to leave the land over the next five years—that is another 25,000 farmers—with the catalyst being the Federal Government's revamped rural adjustment scheme. The Democrats question whether that is a sensible thing to do—encouraging in economic, social and environmental terms what really is a disaster.

The emphasis of the Government is on adapting to the challenges of the free market. It seems to be loath to take note of the lessons taught by history of world agriculture. We could draw parallels for example with the effect of free trade on Roman farmers more than 2,000 years ago. One reason for the decline of grain farming in Italy was the importation of grain into Rome from the grain rich lands of Sicily and Egypt. In Sicily, these grain lands had been appropriated by rich men and scheming politicians who farmed them with slave labour. As a result, the markets of Rome were flooded with cheap grain. Indeed, grain became so cheap that farmers who still owned small pieces of land could not get enough money from the grain that they raised to support their families or to pay their taxes. They were forced to turn their farms over to the rich landlords.

On the land of Italy slave gangs began to take over, working under overseers in place of the old Roman farmers who had been the very backbone of the state. The farmers, after their land had been lost, went inside the city walls leaving behind the scythe and the plough. They worked, now and then, on a small wage. They ate mostly bread from the wheat which was distributed to them by any politician who wanted their votes at the time of an election. The land itself became poor. The use of slaves meant the land was worked badly. This example from ancient Italy, I believe, mirrors a lot of the concerns that we face today right down to the provision of welfare for displaced farmers. If we learn nothing from history, we are doomed to make the same mistakes.

The ideological debate over free trade is relatively recent, dating back to the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. The first climax to the debate came in 1846 when the free trade advocates in the British Parliament voted to repeal the corn laws which regulated imports of wheat in order to protect British farmers from sudden price fluctuations. The main advocate of the repeal, Richard Cobden, who is still the darling of the Right today, was quite aware of the social, economic and environmental consequences of his proposals. The soul mates of Richard Cobden have control of agricultural policy in this country at the moment, and their policies are wreaking just as much havoc amongst small farmers, consumers and the environment as they did in Britain in the nineteenth century and in Italy some 2,000 years ago.

Two competing visions have emerged of the future of agriculture. The first, often referred to as sustainable agriculture, calls for economic and social initiatives to protect the environment and family farms. This approach emphasises the use of public policy to promote economically secure family farms and rural communities; to preserve soil, water and biodiversity; and to use farming practices which are less chemically and energy intensive—without rejecting technology.

The opposing view is the free market, free trade or deregulatory approach which pursues economic efficiency above all else to deliver crops and livestock at the lowest possible prices. Almost all social, environmental and health costs are, to use the economic jargon, externalised. In other words, they are left out of the price and paid for not directly by the buyer but by taxpayers and, in some cases, by future generations.

The neo-classical view seeks to wind back or eliminate farm programs such as price supports and supply management and land use provisions designed for environmental protection. In world trade the opening of state and national borders to unlimited and deregulated imports and exports is supported. These policies are heavily promoted by powerful agribusiness corporations.

Recently the debate between these conflicting views has been given particular prominence by the trade negotiations under GATT and NAFTA. We are all aware of the position of the Europeans and of the French in particular. They have taken farm support to an absurd extreme. But we must also remember that United States policy—if one were in any doubt—is driven by agribusiness economists with the aim of driving other exporting countries out of the world market. Former US Republican Senator Boschwitz, a leading light on the agriculture committees in the mid-1980s, stated this as an explicit goal. In 1985 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If we do not act to discourage these countries now our worldwide competitive position will continue to slide and be much more difficult to regain. This should be one of our foremost goals of our agricultural policies and the Farm Bill.

The US agribusiness economists promised a huge growth in export volumes, which they said would be more than enough to offset the drop in prices. They were mistaken. Although export volumes rose, lower prices meant that their value fell. In fact, in constant dollar terms, US farm exports in 1990 reached only half the value of those in 1981, even though the amounts exported were far greater.

PARA.TAB: Why did this happen? It happened because other countries simply did not stop exporting just because the United States wanted them to. When the US orchestrated lower prices, other countries lowered their prices to match. The Europeans have kept pace with all of this through their own huge subsidy system of price supports. The world has been presented with extremely low price grain exports with prices far below the cost of production—and the result has seen many farmers in Australia and the rest of the world wiped out.

Farmers have searched for ways to produce at lower and lower costs. The first obvious way is to intensify production methods. Australia leads the world in finding sustainable improvements in this area, but it has not been enough. There is evidence that farmers are having to abandon long term soil and water conservation practices to try to reduce short term costs. To the farmers themselves, and to all of us, this is unacceptable, but they really have little choice.

The second approach has been to try to reduce input costs. This is why we are constantly hearing about micro-economic reform. The third way farmers have survived has been to take off-farm work to subsidise their farming operations, or for one member of the family to move away to take off-farm work. The stress upon families and communities has been severe, with large increases in marital problems, family breakdown and suicide.

Make no mistake: country communities are in crisis. Each time a farm family is forced to leave a local community, the impact is enormous. The effects ripple through the community. The local store has fewer customers. The local post office and the local bank may not survive. After losing a few children the local school may indeed lose teachers as well. They are all affected.

Many of our rural communities are at a crisis point in terms of economic and social sustainability. Some 35 per cent of our young people between the ages of 18 and 35 are leaving rural Australia, never to return. We must question whether the rush to a leaner, meaner agribusiness-based corporate farming sector is in the long term best interest of rural Australia. I do not believe it is and the Democrats certainly do not believe it is.

Honourable senators will be aware of my interest in the area of rural incomes policy from the time I arrived in this place some 2 1/2 years ago. My interest comes from having lived in the country for many years, from having friends on farms still surviving and managing to hang on, and also from having a family living in rural Australia. Now, of course, this is part of my responsibility as a senator representing South Australia. I cannot claim, as can many honourable senators who are taking part in this debate, to be directly involved in farming industries, but that does not mean I cannot or do not understand.

I now want to turn to the specific Bills we have before us. I want to concentrate on two Bills in this package—the Rural Adjustment Bill 1992 and, in particular, the Farm Household Support Bill 1992. The objects of the Rural Adjustment Bill are, firstly, to foster the development of a more profitable farm sector that is able to operate competitively in a deregulated financial and market environment; and, secondly, to improve the competitiveness of the farm sector in a sustainable manner.

The Government says that there will be a focus on improved farm productivity, profitability and sustainability through structural adjustment. What it is talking about is changing forever the nature of the farm sector. I remind the Senate of the article that I mentioned earlier. That article pointed out that rural counsellors had been warned that 20 per cent of farmers could be adjusted out—which is a lovely, non-emotive phrase for basically saying `getting them out of farming as quickly as possible'. But adjusting them out to do what? This raises all sorts of questions about what the Government really intends for these people. Where will they go? Where will they find work? What will their families do? It also raises questions about what the Government means by `sustainable'. It seems to be exclusively sustainable profit. What about socially sustainable rural communities? Nowhere is it explained if or where this all fits in with regional development strategy.

In formulating the Bill, the Government commissioned an allegedly comprehensive review by independent consultants and undertook extensive consultations with States and farm sectors. I believe that this review team set out with a very narrow focus and effectively delivered exactly what the Government wanted. It is completely in line with that economic rationalist approach I outlined earlier and, as I said then, we have a number of problems with that philosophy. We believe it is taking agricultural policy in the wrong direction.

The direction is to be overseen by the new Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council that the Bill proposes be set up. This Council is a worry to us. It will have enormous power over the rural sector and, like the independent review team which devised this Bill, the views which will dominate are those of the agricultural bureaucrats and big agricultural businesses. The composition of this Council will be vital to the future of Australia's agriculture. As it stands, I do not believe that it is truly representative; it is certainly not representative enough of all the views that we should be hearing.

Consequently, I will be moving amendments to increase the size of the Council from 8 to 12, with the extra four members being two from the major banks and two from the coalface of rural counselling. I hope the new Council will, as a matter of priority, undertake a comprehensive review of debt restructuring options outside the present rural adjustment scheme. In this respect, they could call and build on work currently being done in South Australia by the rural support working group, which is a combination of grassroot farmers, bankers and rural counsellors. Options they have explored include partial debt write off, debt splitting, debt discounting and property lease-back and purchase. I believe there should have been far more work done on these things by the so-called independent review team on whose recommendations this legislation is based. I do not have time to go into all of these options but they are quite well worth pursuing.

I also ask whether the new Council will be looking at alternative exit incentives besides re-establishment grants. Options include performance agreements and putting in place an effective debt mediation system, such as exists in Western Australia.

There are a couple of favourable developments connected with this Bill which I will comment on. The most important for South Australian farmers is the development of consistent Federal policy guidelines relating to the administration of RAS. Honourable senators may not be aware of the problems with the administration of RAS in South Australia. The Rural Finance and Development Division, under the control of Mr Graham Broughton, has taken a very inflexible, unsympathetic and hardline approach to the administration of RAS. The RFDD in South Australia has imposed completely ludicrous conditions on farmers, which I believe are not found in other States. For example, to access re-establishment grants, farmers have to sign a statement declaring that they will not return to farming within five years, work as an employee for the new farm owner or share-farm any farm property. Not only do farmers have to sell their property; their skills must be lost forever to the farm sector. This is just ridiculous. I look forward to the South Australian administration being brought into line by the new Federal guidelines.

Another problem currently faced in South Australia is the rumoured closure by RAS of TRACS, the rural adjustment coordination service, which undertakes a specialist role, offering independent financial analysis and outlining personal business plans and business options. It is in danger of being eliminated. It brings together primary producers, rural counsellors and the financial institutions. The TRACS coordinators currently have a portfolio of some 450 cases covering all sorts of adjustment problems. It seems to me that if the focus is on structural adjustment, and if that is what the Government is promising should occur, these services will be needed more than ever. I trust that the South Australian RAS authority will be kept well and truly in line by the new Federal guidelines in this respect as well. The $45,000 re-establishment grant is certainly welcomed for those who will qualify.
I now turn to the Farm Household Support Bill. The thrust of this Bill, as described on the title page, is:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act relating to the provision of income support, and financial incentive to leave the rural industries, to primary producers without a long-term productive, sustainable and profitable future in the sector.

The Bill sets up a farm household support payment to replace part C of RAS. The objects of the Bill are to provide financial assistance to farmers who are unable to meet day-to-day living expenses and cannot get commercial loans and to provide financial incentives for such persons to leave farming. To qualify for farm household support payments, the farmer must have a certificate of inability to access finance from a financial institution. This means that a farmer cannot access commercial carry-on finance. In other words, we are dealing with the worst off farmers—the borderline cases.

PARA.TAB: The support is available for up to two years at a level up to the Jobsearch allowance. There is the usual income and assets test. The income test is the same as for JSA. The assets test is an assets test excluding the tools of trade—at last—that is, farm land, machinery and livestock. The rationale for exemption is as outlined by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in his second reading speech.

The Democrats see this as a major breakthrough. For the first time since I have been here the Government has recognised the need to give farm assets special treatment. The Democrats have long argued that if farm assets are included the majority of farm families immediately exceed the normal asset test limits, excluding them from many farm support payments regardless of the size, often negative, of their income. We do not see payments which are designed to put food on the table and meet basic clothing and educational needs as subsidies for uneconomic enterprises. They are a basic human right and it is surely one of the fundamental tenets of social justice that people are supported in times of need.

I hope the principle will now be extended to Austudy and the new family support payment—that is, the former family allowance and family allowance supplement. Were the former Minister for Social Security here, I am sure he would fondly remember my attempts to exempt tools of trade from assets tests for Austudy, the family allowance, the family allowance supplement, the Jobsearch allowance, pensions and anything else remotely resembling income support.

Farm household support is aimed at putting food on the table for the worst off farmers. The problem is that the scheme is a loan. It represents a philosophical sticking point between us, the Government and the Opposition. I did not like it when RAS part C was a loan and we certainly do not approve of it being a loan now. As was mentioned earlier, if unemployment benefits had to be paid back once a person got a job, we would have an enormous outcry throughout our cities. Here we have a situation where farmers who may get out of farming with as little as $45,000 are being asked to pay this back. Indeed, if they hang on even further, they will not even be eligible for the $45,000.

We have had discussions with the Department and the Minister's office on this point. They have been very helpful and very open with advice, but we appreciate that it remains a sticking point and we are not going to move the Government. We only hope that when we come to the amendments in the committee stage the Opposition may be so moved. As has been outlined, farmers who do not leave farming at the end of the two-year period will have to pay back that household support with interest. In other words, the Government could well be making a profit out of farmers who are in dire straits. Basically, this amounts to the Government making money out of alleviating poverty. To make it clear, we are talking about farmers who need a payment to put food on the table, but they may end up after two years with a debt of some $20,000.

The Democrats believe that the only strings which should be attached to the farm family is that the farmer must consult on a regular basis with rural diagnostic experts to ascertain possibilities and to set up all the options available, including various forms of debt restructuring and land management. This, I understand, is an intention of the legislation. My amendments retain the incentive offered that if farmers decide to go at any time within the first nine months, the whole nine-month farm household support amount will be paid in full as a grant. The Democrats believe access to re-establishment grants provides sufficient incentive to leave, without the threat of destitution or another debt if they do not. The bottom line to us is that under the normal process of commercial loans, those farmers who are genuinely unviable will be forced to leave the land anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Rural Adjustment Bill 1992 and related Bills, and to compliment my colleagues Senators Tambling, Boswell, Panizza and Chapman for their contributions. Apart from one aspect, I cannot find much fault with what Senator Lees said about the rural adjustment scheme and how it operates. The flawed part of her contribution was her citation of the situation in America. I think she said that some 30,000 farmers in recent years had left their farms, but contradicted that by saying that we should be going down the path of the Americans and the Europeans. The facts show quite clearly that even with all the assistance that has been given to American and European farmers, with the adjustment process, the rate of farmers leaving the industry in those countries has been at least double that in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, that does not mean that the Australian situation is satisfactory—far from it. But what the current Government fails to understand in terms of farming in this country, in particular, is that farmers are price takers; they have always been price takers except for a couple of notable exceptions. As price takers, the only two areas where they can do something about their operation are the costs of doing business, and in being more efficient in how they go about doing their business. It is a well-known fact that in our major agricultural industries in this country we are recognised as the most efficient in the world. But in the other area of costs the Government has failed the Australian farm sector absolutely dismally.

There is nothing strange about collapses in commodity prices. Successive governments over the years have used the downturns in world commodity prices to make a case for virtually doing nothing and farmers have learned to live with that. What they cannot live with are the excessive costs that are passed back to the farm sector. That is where I come to the point of them being price takers, because it is not only in the price of their product that they are price takers but also in the services that are delivered to them.

I want to give honourable senators one example of a direct result of this Government's policy in terms of high interest rates. During the period of high interest rates, because of the pressure that was put on service industries—small businesses, for example—a mechanic's wages at Ravensthorpe went from $17 to $35 an hour. That increase was almost entirely due to the impact of high interest rates on the cost of that service industry. Of course, that cost is now in-built into the system. It will not go away, even though people on the other side of this chamber will claim that they have lowered interest rates.
