The damage has been done to those small businesses and that price taking will flow through and be there virtually forever and a day. The indirect impact of high interest rates on costs has been very severe; it has been ongoing. As I said, it is not going to go away.

Tonight I wish to make some comments about the rural adjustment scheme. I have long argued, and I firmly believe, that the rural adjustment scheme is fundamentally flawed. It is flawed because in the commodity downturns which occur in agriculture, there is a process of adjusting people out of the industry and transferring the debt from those transferred out to another farmer who might be next door or very close. That is what the adjustment process is all about. Under the guidelines of the rural adjustment scheme, it is the so-called most efficient ones who pick up that extra property and that extra debt. But, of course, in the next downturn—the cycle which goes around—they cannot handle that debt. Those people who were the most efficient four or five years beforehand suddenly become victims of circumstances.

That happens over and over and over again. That is why I say that the rural adjustment scheme is flawed. We cannot predict when we will come out of this recession—and come out of it we will but, fortunately, it will not be while this current Government is in power. In four or five or six or seven or eight years, whatever it is, when we again have that cyclical turnaround, it will be the very people who picked up the various property that is being adjusted onto other properties during this phase out process—and I will come to that in a moment or two—who will be the victims the next time around.

There needs to be a circuit-breaker in terms of the whole philosophy behind the rural adjustment scheme. We can go through it. The figures are there. The years are there: 1972, 1976, 1982, 1986, 1991 to 1993. We have had exactly the same pattern every time and nobody seems to be able to come to grips with it and learn what the problem is all about.

I wish to introduce some figures into this debate. I refer to the tragedy which is now occurring in rural Australia. Despite that tragedy, with low commodity prices, we still find that last year, in 1991, agriculture contributed over $21 billion worth of export income to the Australian economy. In my State of Western Australia the figure was almost $3 billion. Yet, when we look at the next set of figures, we find some horrific results. I will quote a few of those.

In New South Wales in 1989-90 farm business profit was $6,493. In 1990-91 it was minus $21,090. In 1991-92 it was minus $34,800. So we have seen a turnaround of approximately $27,000. If we look at the other figures for New South Wales, we find that net capital purchases in 1989-90 amounted to $21,142 per farm. In 1990-91 it dropped to $3,940 per farm. I do not know how many farmers there are in New South Wales, but I do know that there are about 170,000 in Australia, which is approximately one per cent of the population. As I said before, that one per cent of the population produced over $21 billion worth of export income for this country in what was a bad year. The figures for 1990-91, which are the latest figures available, show that net capital purchases have dropped to $3,840 per farm.

I turn to my State of Western Australia. In 1989-90, the average farm in Western Australia had a farm business profit of $21,513. In 1990-91 it was minus $27,900. That is a turnaround of very close to $50,000 per property. In 1991-92 it was once again minus $28,500. In 1989-90 the average amount of net capital purchases of farmers in Western Australia was $46,570. In 1990-91 it was $11,880.

Even in my small district of Jerdacuttup, which has only 52 farms, that is over half a million dollars of cash flow through the businesses in Ravensthorpe. If we add the cash flow of all those around, it is not difficult to get to $5m or $6m. If we multiply that right across the system, it is no wonder that people say that when things are good in the bush things go well in the city. That is because farmers are high spenders of their income. They do not lock it up in banks; they do not put it under their beds. They use it to put in dams, to build fences, to build sheds and to buy fertiliser and so on. That provides the cash flow for the community. It is well known that the multiplier effect of the dollar that is spent off the farm is second to none in the community. This Government has failed dismally to recognise that aspect of the importance of the farm sector in terms of cash flow and overcoming the problems of the recession.

The other point I wish to make is about farm debt. To be consistent I will use the figures from New South Wales and Western Australia. Unfortunately, I do not have the time to go into the other States, but they all show similar figures. In 1989-90 average farm business debt in New South Wales was $97,955. In 1990-91 it had risen to $106,780. I do not have the figures for 1991-92 as yet, but they will certainly go up another $10,000 or $15,000 per property. Senator Brownhill, who is in the chamber, would be well aware of the impact that that has had on the viability of farmers in New South Wales.

In Western Australia in 1989-90 the average farm debt was $123,685. It rose as a result of those negative incomes to $129,530 in 1990-91. I have the 1991-92 figures for Western Australia. There the average farm debt has risen again, to $134,700. That does no credit to this Government. It has occurred because of its policy of high interest rates and because it has not addressed, in the correct or proper manner, the infrastructure costs or micro-economic reforms at the haste at which they need addressing in Australia.

Micro-economic reform, particularly in the areas of transport, a much more accelerated reform on the waterfront, shipping—whether it be internationally or on State ships—road transport and rail transport, does not have benefits only for the farm sector; they also have enormous cost benefits for the whole of the community. This is the area in which we can do meaningful things which will allow for a break even point, at least in these times of lower commodity prices.

I would now like to address a couple of points in regard to these Bills before us. Although I believe the assessment process we have before us is fundamentally flawed, it is a minor improvement on the previous scheme. But I still ask, as others here have done tonight, why farmers are treated differently. This scheme has been transferred to the Department of Social Security, as has already been said here tonight. I suggest that, if somebody on unemployment benefits was asked to pay the money back, the third world war would break out in Australia. The Government's approach on this matter is very inconsistent.

I acknowledge that the first nine months of payments now is a grant, but the next 15 months is a loan. Certainly the increase to $45,000 will help a few individuals, but the real area to be addressed is getting the costs down. We can look at some of the other figures around currently. In the wool industry the average price is about 500c a kilo; yet the production cost is 610c. Once again, particularly while we have the stockpile, it is the issue of costs that this country has to address. From those figures, it is not difficult to work out that woolgrowers are losing between $1.10 and $1.50 per kilo under the current price structure.

I also wish to raise the issue of agriculture and industrial relations. It is fundamental not only to the recovery of the farm sector but also to the recovery of this country. I put it to Senator McMullan, who is sitting here with us—I note that nobody else from the Government benches is here, other than you, Mr Acting Deputy President—that when we have the situation in this country where the price of shearing can go up 16 per cent in 12 months, when an industry which is providing an enormous amount of employment is on its knees—

TALK.START.PARA: —The AWU denies that.

—The AWU can deny it all it likes. I thank Senator Brownhill for that interjection. The facts are there; one can go to the Government's own umpire, as it calls the Industrial Relations Commissioner—the producer of fairness and equity. That is what the Government has done in terms of an industry that is on its knees. It is absolute madness when we have a situation such as this. It is not as if these people in the wool industry are earning bad money. Earlier I gave the figures; while the losses per property are up around $30,000, those properties would pay out individually somewhere between $40,000 and $50,000 per year to get their sheep shorn. If we take that across the particular individuals, from the rouseabout in the shed to the shearer, they earn anything from $25,000 or $30,000 to $50,000 or $60,000 per year. That is what can be addressed in this particular industry. We see all the nonsense that goes on in terms of the so-called weekend work and lack of flexibility which exists in the award. As far as I am concerned, those things are an absolute nonsense. In Western Australia we do not have the sorts of problems that exist in some parts of States on this side of the nation.

PARA.TAB: Another area in the farm sector where costs can be reduced and where the Government can play a positive role is that of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service. One could cite many examples, but last week, when the nonsense strike action was coming out of Victoria, virtually all of the AQIS inspectors in this country were out on strike, closing down meatworks at an enormous cost to this nation but also at an enormous cost to the individual producers on the ground. They are the ones that have to pick up the burden of this irresponsible action that has gone on here in recent times.

Of course, in Western Australia, and I presume in the other States, we found in the peak of harvest CBH workers—members of the AWU in particular, but the Electrical Trades Union as well—going out on strike and hindering farmers at the most important time of the year. Farmers are having their incomes reduced by an average of some $30,000 per year, as I have already said. That loss is being exacerbated and costs are being put up. This is where the Government can give some positive leadership. Of course, it does not have the courage to do that; it just jumps as high as its masters in the trade union movement tell it to jump.

The Government will come out—as the Minister has already done—and call me the resident union basher. There are a lot of responsible unions in this country, but those unions that in this case hold the farm sector to ransom deserve to be condemned, because both the AQIS inspectors and the people working for CBH carry out their action at the peak of the killing season or the delivery season and maximise the damage to those individuals.

I conclude my remarks by re-emphasising what I said at the start. In my view, the rural adjustment scheme is fundamentally flawed, and until such time as that aspect is addressed we will have the merry-go-round every four or five years where there is a sudden surge of interest by the Government to adjust a few more people out of the industry. Quite frankly, it is time that process was stopped and it was readjusted and turned around. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Rural Adjustment Bill 1992, the States Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill 1992, the Farm Household Support Bill 1992 and the Income Equalisation Deposits Laws Amendment Bill 1992. Most of the things that I had to say have already been said, but I would like to reiterate a few of them. Senator Crane spoke very eloquently of some of the complaints, concerns and worries about the amendments that are being made in these Bills. These four Bills are all interwoven and encapsulate the full spectrum of the fortunes and misfortunes of the farming sector. That has been well and truly mentioned here tonight by Senator Boswell, Senator Crane and others. It is impossible to deal at length with each Bill individually, so I will basically address my remarks to all four of them.

PARA.TAB: Rural adjustment or assistance for the farm sector in times of assessed need has never been administered to the entire satisfaction of all the parties concerned and possibly never will be. However, I believe that the Keating Labor Government's approach to the difficulties facing rural Australia has been too little too late, too inflexible and inappropriate. If one looks at the problems of the rural sector—Senator Crane has elucidated pretty well on many of them—most of them have started in the last 10 years under this Government. One of the biggest hits in the guts, if you like, to the farming sector was high interest rates. That has driven many people to the wall.

Farmers have also suffered drought—they have always had droughts—and the Keating Labor Government has said that drought should be taken out of the natural disasters program. The Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, of which Senator Crane, myself and others are members, in its inquiry into drought, did not think that was too bad an idea as long as people who were in severe hardship occasioned by drought were looked after in some way.

Commodity downturns have caused big problems in the community and also quite horrific costs in the farming sector. In the past year there has been an increase of some 16 per cent in costs in the farming sector—not only in the actual cost of shearing but also in the cost of shearing a sheep—as a result of the downturn in wool prices which has caused some horrific problems to the wool growing industry. This legislation streamlines the process a little, but in my view it is not flexible enough and does not offer real assistance to those who ought to be entitled to assistance.

Clear evidence was provided to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs during its drought inquiry that the need for rural assistance and rural adjustment was greatest for those experiencing drought. There were some areas where insufficient rain had fallen for three to four years. Many drought declared areas are entirely wool growing areas. The drought came just as the bottom fell out of the wool market, so it had a double negative income effect on those people. I stress that these financially crippled farmers are, for the large part, in that position due to circumstances beyond their control. In most cases, no amount of preparation would have prevented the present situation.

As I have said before, farmers do not want handouts; they want a fair go. They want a government that will work with them, not against them as the present Government has been doing for the last few years. At the moment they are seeing a little change of heart with the legislation before us. The Opposition has been advocating for 10 years that we should go back to the old IED scheme. I know that some people on the Government side of the chamber say that it was rorted. I do not believe that the Government should have taken away the good scheme that we had, introduced by Ian Sinclair in conjunction with the Rural and Industries Bank, which did a great deal to help farming communities.

The changes to the income equalisation deposit scheme still do not go far enough. This legislation amends some of the changes that this Government made in 1989, but it still does not have the basic criterion: to encourage farmers in good years to put money aside at beneficial rates to provide for the lean years. The scheme is not sufficiently attractive to warrant its success and it highlights the Government's lack of commitment to rural Australia, notwithstanding that, in the One Nation statement, recovery in the rural sector will underpin Australia's recovery. When we look at the One Nation statement—it is good to see that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) is in the chamber at the moment because he has had a big part to play in the One Nation statement—it is interesting to see that it says rural industries are going to underpin our recovery and yet—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't blame him for that.

—He had a part in it; he is the very financial Parliamentary Secretary. That being the case, if the rural industries are going to underpin Australia's recovery, then they have to be looked after in the long term—we cannot chop and change all the time.

PARA.TAB: During the inquiry the Committee heard from some 78 people in public hearings and visited eight family properties. Eight per cent of those people had no equity left in their properties and high debt was common to many others in the area. In Queensland we found that one in seven grain properties were for sale, farm debt had increased by 24 per cent in two years, and 30 to 40 per cent of farmers were uncertain of their future with the high probability that half would be leaving farming.

In the western division of New South Wales, my home State, approximately 66 per cent of the lessees have only 65 per cent equity in their holdings, with average land values dropping by 50 per cent. If the drought had broken 12 months ago it would still have taken five years for the general recovery in that division. Therefore, we need long term planning and long term incentives for people to look after themselves. Many others in that area were only coping because one or both partners were able to find work off the farm. We had instances of the parents going off the farm and the son being left on the western division property just to shoot the kangaroos. This meant that the parents were away, which is not beneficial for the future of that farming property.

Losses in the region of $33,000 a year per farm, which Senator Crane has mentioned, have meant negative incomes. Despite the fact that no money is coming in, there is still a need to maintain a property with stock and feed, and to feed, clothe and educate families. Children have had to be withdrawn from boarding schools because their parents cannot afford the fees. In some instances, there are simply not enough local schools or the nearest schools are too far away. Many parents have had to ask their children not to complete their schooling. They do not have the money to send them to universities or to TAFE institutions.

Earlier I spoke of high interest rates, commodity prices and droughts. I believe that this Government can take a lot of the blame for the problems. It has created an underpaid and under-skilled rural work force. Farmers simply cannot afford to pay workers. They cannot afford to keep their children at school in order to qualify for something other than farming. At the moment it is really a catch-22 situation. Basically, the only growth industry in the western parts of rural New South Wales is the counselling service which is inundated with the problems of desperate people.

The new rural adjustment arrangements make no real allowance for people who want to stay on their farms and who, given a fair break, can work their way out of their problems. The emphasis has been placed on assisting people to get out of farming rather than on keeping people at it. I wonder about the future of rural areas if people cannot be helped or cajoled into staying on the land. I do not think people will leave the comfort of places like Canberra or Sydney to go out into those western areas.

Farmers cannot afford to take out more loans, irrespective of interest rate subsidies. The Government had the opportunity, given the special circumstances of the extreme drought and in the absence of any long term strategy, to provide one-off assistance to help farmers restock and reduce their debt. I do not believe that sufficient deserving cases are receiving assistance in that area.

According to the latest RAS report, total applications for assistance stand at 9,132, which is more than double the 3,455 in the previous year. So a lot of people are looking for help and assistance. There is evidence that the farm household assistance arrangements of RAS are not working. Evidence given last week to a Senate committee hearing shows that despite the overwhelming evidence of need, only 438 farmers were approved for a re-establishment grant by State RAS authorities in 1991-92. To date only 172 have been approved in 1992-93. That seems low when the extent of the hardship is realised. I will cite those figures again: in 1991, 438 applications were approved by the State authorities—and I think that basically shows up the problems with that scheme.

Before I finish, I would like to say something about the IED scheme. One of my real concerns is that we have not gone back to the original IED scheme. The Government has taken up the recommendation of the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee relating to an increase in the size of the investment component. I have talked to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) about the IED scheme. It is all very well to say that a big farmer can look after himself. But even though the maximum is $300,000, the big farmer needs to put away more money. So why should not these farmers be given an incentive of maybe two years running expenses or whatever so that they can really look after themselves in the future?

The Committee recommended a reduction in the minimum amount of deposit and I thank the Government for taking up that good idea. We also suggested a review of the withholding tax provisions. The Government has done a bit about that by reducing the withholding tax provisions that applied to withdrawals from 29 per cent to 20 per cent. What concerns me is that if a farmer has to self assess and does not have to pay that withholding tax, what happens if the season changes dramatically during that year, the amount blows out and instead of going into a lower tax bracket he goes into a higher tax bracket? I have asked that question before of departmental officials, and it still concerns me. Why we have to have a withholding tax payment, I do not know. If a farmer put away a certain amount of money, why can he not get the whole lot of it back in the year that he needs it, without having money held away from him? The other point is the interest only being paid on a component of the total amount of money that farmers put away.

This legislation is a step in the right direction but the Government has not gone far enough. If we are going to have a viable agricultural base in the future, we need to make sure that the parameters are right for the rural industries in the future so that we have a prosperous rural economy which will help Australia out of the problem it is in at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleagues who have spoken earlier, I have no opposition to the Rural Adjustment Bill 1992 and related legislation. I reiterate my support for what the Government is putting forward tonight. Most of what I was going to say has already been said. I would particularly like to compliment the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Boswell, for giving a very eloquent speech. He also put on the record the pain and suffering that he obviously has had described to him by people in those terrible situations that have happened in rural Australia over the last two or three years.

PARA.TAB: Like my colleague Senator Brownhill, I am also a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs that looked at the national drought policy. We were told at first-hand of the experiences of some of those poor, unfortunate farmers who are suffering drought not only in the western region of New South Wales but right around Australia. I have some experience in this matter because, like most of the previous speakers, I too come from a rural background. Even though I come from Tasmania I have experienced droughts there. Some people think that we do not experience droughts in Tasmania, but I can assure them we do. When we do experience droughts in Tasmania they have a larger effect on us because we are not geared up for continuous dry spells as farmers are in other parts of Australia.

I have also been a recipient of the rural reconstruction scheme which was one of the measures in vogue quite a few years ago. The long term, low interest loan is probably one of the reasons why I still have my farm. This was brought out to us in some of the Committee's public hearings. A lot of the old timers, like myself, made the point that the rural reconstruction scheme was effective because it gave them that long term, low interest rate assistance when they most needed it, and their agricultural efficiencies saw them through.

It is interesting to note that the Government has moved towards the coalition's policy. I commend the Government and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) for that. I just hope that this legislation will prove to be the success which they hope it will be. I believe that they may find that they have to amend it further—we certainly would under a coalition government; I think Bruce Lloyd has already made that patently clear.

As was said earlier, as a member of the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee I have received a large number of submissions outlining the failures and hardships caused by the inadequacies of the rural adjustment scheme, particularly in drought situations. Unfortunately, the Committee found that many problems were caused by the fact that rural producers needed to be in a desperate financial position before they were even considered for assistance. Too many of them were too far down the track before they received any assistance at all. One of the problems pointed out in our report is the fact that some farmers were too proud to ask for assistance. By the time they did, they were eligible only for part C of the scheme. By the time they got to part C, it was a case of being over and out.

For the information of honourable senators and in order to back up what I said about hardship, I will briefly read a couple of extracts from the inquiry's submissions. The submission from Cattle Council of Australia stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The eligibility criteria for RAS limits its use to those producers who have liquidated any substantial off-farm assets and who are generally in an extremely poor financial condition while still being deemed profitable in the long term.

It was brought forward to us on many occasions that when the crunch came—the drought and the recession we had to have on top of that—the people who had built up a reserve of cash off the farm used up their off-farm assets and ended up in a situation where their farm could not carry them on. A Mr W.W. McLaughlin, from Tongo station in New South Wales, a fourth or fifth generation grazier in that area, said:
The main inadequacy with the current government rural policy is that it simply does not provide any general assistance to those in genuine financial need, prior to total collapse.
One of my major concerns about any assistance is whether we get to the patient before he or she has lost too much blood and falls over.

PARA.TAB: The legislation before us goes a long way towards alleviating the problems caused by drought situations. In particular, I refer to the establishment of the RAS Advisory Council, which, with the Minister, advises on the operations of the rural adjustment scheme. I notice that the Australian Democrats have put up an amendment to amend the make-up of that Advisory Council. I cannot see the point in it. I have not discussed this amongst my colleagues, but it seems to me that they are being a bit restrictive in not allowing the Minister enough flexibility to appoint the sorts of people that he thinks should be appointed. Nevertheless, I presume that the Democrats have a reason for moving that amendment.

In an earlier speech, Senator Tambling outlined those who will be involved in advising the Minister. That will help alleviate the problem of having persons with no experience of the particular financial problems faced by rural producers interpreting the decisions which affect the rural community. Up until now, I believe that one major fault with any assistance from government to the rural community is that it is usually on the advice of bureaucrats and a number of people who have not had a lot of experience on the land. In fact, it is often said that most of the people who end up becoming counsellors or rural advisers are people who have gone broke anyway. They are trying to advise the ones who are left on what to do. I will again quote from Mr McLaughlin's submission:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that none of the relevant authorities . . . have an appreciation of the severity of the economic crisis currently being experienced in rural Australia.

Those words come from a man who should know. After all is said and done, something like 150,000 sheep, on his estimation, had died during the drought. The situation was compounded because he had to decide what to do with the ones which were still alive. His property in Sydney had to be mortgaged to keep himself going. So if anybody really knew what it was all about, it was him.

PARA.TAB: The problem that he raised about the economic crisis currently being experienced has certainly been pointed out by more than one speaker here tonight. For those people who are left in the rural areas, the problem still remains and it is being highlighted by the Government's decision not to adopt the coalition's income tested household support scheme. Rather than make farmers undergo a lengthy process of bureaucratic tests, the coalition's policy, which has been outlined by our shadow Minister, puts food on the table straight away. Speakers here tonight have already mentioned the burden which the present scheme places on rural families: the paperwork they have to go through, the tests they have to pass and the criteria they have to meet to get some sort of assistance. Surely the people who are receiving Jobsearch allowance and the like in the cities do not have to go to the trouble the rural families have to go to.

Another issue of major concern which has been covered tonight is the assets test. As Senator Boswell said, the poor old farmers end up being assets rich and income poor. A lot of them say to me, `You can't eat dirt'. But they hang on. Unfortunately, in times of drought, the only assistance they are getting from the Government now is through the rural adjustment scheme.

I am disappointed that the Government has refused to implement one of the major recommendations of the drought policy review task force concerning incentives for drought proofing. Most of the farmers we spoke to said they wanted to be drought proof and they wanted to be self-sufficient. I do not believe the RAS goes far enough to allow them to do that.

I am also concerned that the Government has refused to place severe drought back into the Federal-State natural disaster arrangements. Whilst some of the States—New South Wales and Queensland, in particular—have been of tremendous assistance during this current drought, other States have not been so generous. Whilst an extra $14m has been allocated to the rural adjustment scheme to compensate for this, the fact remains that there is an annual limit to the rural adjustment scheme's budget and the financial impositions caused by severe drought would far exceed this limit.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, I support this legislation with some reservations. I applaud the Government for moving closer to the coalition's policy. However, after further consideration of the problems faced by rural producers, a coalition government will make further amendments to this legislation in particular, placing severe drought back into Federal-State cooperative arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those of us who have been present in the Senate chamber tonight have been extremely lucky to hear one of the most eloquent speeches on primary industry that has been delivered in this chamber during the last three years. I refer to Senator Boswell's speech. Not only was it eloquent, but also it was to the point. Senator Boswell spoke about the real hardship and suffering—and I do not use those words lightly—of the people of rural Australia who not only have been deprived by an act of God of an opportunity of making a go, but also have been deprived by high interest rates, by an economic recession and, in many cases, by bureaucracy of having a chance of staying on their farms.

PARA.TAB: I know that many farmers—possibly the majority of farmers—will survive this current rural disaster. But one's heart cannot help but go out to those thousands and thousands of Australian farmers who, unless they get real, adequate help, will not survive this rural crisis. That is not a tragedy of human proportion; that is a tragedy of national proportion, because we are not talking about inefficient farmers or the ones who cannot make a go under any circumstances. We have lost those farmers. We are talking about our best farmers; people who have survived on the land for 20 or 30 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Generations.

—In some cases generations of families who have been on the same property and who now face—not even risk—losing everything. It is not as though it is a gamble where they are rolling the dice and choosing to call the shots. They are facing nothing other than the prospect of the loss of everything for which they and their families have worked for so long.One has to ask: what future is there for this nation if the one sector that has always been the basis of our national prosperity; the one sector which has been the basis of our exports for years and years and years—the farm sector—is destroyed by a combination of drought, recession and bureaucracy?

PARA.TAB: Those of us on this side will be accepting these Bills, because we feel duty-bound by our constituents—especially those of us in the National Party—to accept whatever is made available. In that sense, we are in a position no better than the people we represent because we, like they, have been forced to accept the crumbs coming from the Government's table. Would it not be a great thing if we had loaves of bread instead? That is the question we have to ask.

To put this into perspective, the Government will be making available something in the vicinity of $160m in rural assistance under these Bills tonight. In the last great drought that this country faced, when the Government in power was the National and Liberal Party coalition, that Government presided over by Malcolm Fraser and Doug Anthony gave almost three times as much in 1983 dollars as this Government is giving in 1992 dollars.

Yes, we are grateful, but I also feel honour and duty-bound to ask on behalf of my constituents, `Can the Government not do better?'. If the Government wants an export mentality and wants to boost our exports, it must be willing and prepared to work alongside those whose task it is to produce those exports, and we are talking about the farmers of this nation.

I said that we are in the position of our constituents in accepting what crumbs fall from the Government's table, but I have a major reservation about this legislation tonight. I have in my hands a draft tax determination numbered TD92/D201. That draft tax determination indicates that many of the farmers who receive rural adjustment under these Bills that go through Parliament tonight will in fact be asked to pay tax on it at the end of this financial year. Before I proceed any further, and so that everybody can understand the enormity of this particular problem, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the draft tax determination to which I have referred.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: FOI Status: draft only—for comment Page 1 of 1
Draft Taxation Determinations (TDs) represent the preliminary, though considered, views of the ATO. Draft Tds may not be relied on; only final TDs are authoritative statements of the ATO.
Draft Taxation Determination

Income tax: sugar cane growers may receive a grant/subsidy from the Queensland Industries Development Corporation (QIDC) under the Commonwealth-State Scheme of Adjustment Assistance. When is this subsidy to be included in the assessable income of the recipient?

(1)In the income year in which it is received. It is considered that in these circumstances the subsidy is income. This is supported by the decision in Lincolnshire Sugar Co, Ltd. v Smart, (1937) 20 TC 643. In this case it was held that the subsidies paid to the taxpayer were trade receipts assessable in the year of receipt.

(2)Although the subsidy is paid directly to the lender to reduce the principal of the growers loan or to provide an interest subsidy over the term of the loan, section 19 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, deems it to be derived by the taxpayer when credited to the lender.
(3)The subsidy is made to growers for the purpose of debt reconstruction, farm build-up or farm improvement. The subsidy is paid by QIDC either as:

PARA.TAB: (i)a lump sum, equivalent in present value terms to the amount of the approved interest subsidy payable over a maximum period of seven years—assessable in full in the year it is credited to the taxpayer, or
(ii)an approved interest subsidy over the term of the loan—assessable in each year as credited to the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: Commissioner of Taxation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The draft tax determination in question refers to the liability of sugarcane growers in this case, who receive interest subsidies under the rural adjustment scheme paid to them by the Queensland Industry Development Corporation or who receive a subsidy over a period of time for the loan.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate that we understand what this determination says. The question is: when is this subsidy to be included in the assessable income of the recipient? The answer is: in the income year in which it is received. In other words, people are getting a government subsidy on a loan because they cannot make ends meet and there is no way they can possibly stay on the farm without it. Yet, under this Government they will be made to pay tax on it, for goodness sake! They are having enough trouble staying on the farm as it is. I am sure that there must be some oversight. I do not believe that a humane government could possibly give people a grant with one hand and tax it with the other when the purpose of the grant is to help them stay alive.

I would suggest that the Government look at this matter tonight because it is fairly important. Senator McMullan is the relevant parliamentary secretary in the area of taxation matters. I would beg and plead with Senator McMullan that, if at all possible, this legislation be amended so that the amounts of money given by way of rural adjustment are not treated as assessable income for the purposes of income tax. If this tax ruling applies to canegrowers, it will apply as well to other farmers who get assistance under the rural adjustment scheme and that frightens me immensely.

It may be that some of those farmers will still have a loss at the end of the year and therefore will not pay any tax. But there may be some farmers who will just break even or make a very slight loss and who would probably fall into the category of people eligible to receive rural adjustment. Therefore, they will have to pay tax on the value of the interest subsidy that they have received from the Federal Government. That seems to be wholly unfair, wholly unjust and wholly unproductive. If the Government really intends to give $160m of assistance then it should say so. But if the Government does not intend to give $160m of assistance, if it intends to claw $10m, $20m or $30m back, then I believe it should say so as well so that everybody understands exactly how much money is available.

The absurd thing about this ruling is that it is based on a 1937 tax case from the United Kingdom in respect of subsidies paid to sugar beet growers in the UK in 1937 under the British Sugar Subsidy Act of 1925. There is enormous difference between that Act and what we are doing tonight. Under the British Sugar Subsidy Act of 1925 a long term subsidy was provided irrespective of the circumstances of the farmers in question. It was just like the common agricultural policy of today. It would be appropriate for the money to be taxed if we had such a subsidy scheme. But this is money that we are giving by way of a humanitarian assistance to farmers who cannot otherwise survive. I do not believe that one can draw any analogies between the two at all. In fact, I think that sort of logic is wholly flawed.

I would normally make some other comments in relation to IEDs. There has been an improvement but it does not go far enough; it certainly does not go as far as the National Party and the Liberal Party would go were we in government. I know that some of my colleagues have spoken about that tonight. I do not want to detain the Senate unnecessarily but I would seek some indication from Senator McMullan tonight as to whether the Government will amend this legislation so that the subsidies are not eligible for taxation. I do not know whether Senator McMullan has heard a word of what I have said about this matter this evening. He has talked to all and sundry and does not seem to be listening to a word I have been saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard.

—I would hope that Senator McMullan might be able to give me some indication as to whether the Government would be willing to countenance an amendment tonight to these things because that would be of great assistance. We would all be very grateful for that. I do not wish to say anything further during the second reading debate other than that I hope and pray like everybody here that this drought will be over and that our farm sector will be able to get back to where it ought to be, which is providing the food for the nation and the exports that we need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to this debate on the Rural Adjustment Bill and allied Bills. A range of issues has been raised. Given that a number of senators abbreviated their contributions to facilitate the Government's program, as Manger of Government Business I will not make a long speech and abuse that cooperation which we have received. But I will seek to respond briefly to either those issues that were raised directly with me, for example, by Senator O'Chee, or the more generic ones.

PARA.TAB: Many of the senators who spoke are people with significant experience in rural matters, and it showed in their contributions. I do not necessarily share all the views that they expressed but they made substantial contributions to the debate. I do not wish to be provocative so I will just say generally that that does not apply to every contribution that was made. Others can make their judgments about those to whom I think it did not apply; but there were a number of weighty and worthwhile contributions.

This is a package of Bills which will do much to strengthen the performance and resilience of Australia's rural communities. Each of them individually and collectively has a contribution to make to the future of the rural sector and to their survival through the difficult times through which they are now going.

Senator Tambling queried the administration of the FHS by the Department of Social Security. Some other speakers thought that actually was a good idea, and I share that view. It is appropriate to the character of the program, the nature of DSS's services these days, the distribution of DSS officers and the professional skills of the people in those programs. It will prove to be a worthwhile change. That is a view that I think is shared by many of the senators who spoke. History will be the judge, but I think it will turn out to be a plus. It seems on the face of it to be an appropriate change.

Senator Boswell queried the appropriateness of the Budget allocation for 1992-93 when compared with last year's expenditure. I point out to him that the FHS and the re-establishment grant components of the package are claims based. I am advised that the actual expenditure on these items can go beyond that Budget figure. Further, the RAS budget is subject to a mid-year review concerning the adequacy of the funds made available. So there is more room there than perhaps Senator Boswell first recognised.

I want to make it clear to Senator Boswell that farmers do not have to commit themselves to sell the farm to get the FHS support from the first nine months of the payment through to the full two years. That is not required. It seemed to be implied in something Senator Boswell said. Perhaps he thought that was so, but we make it clear that it is not.

We are now not going on to the committee stage, so I do not want to spend a considerable amount of time considering the amendments. We are not disposed to agree with those of which we are aware. At the very least we would say that they are not necessary. With regard to the other amendments, it is a little late in the day to be proposing such a range of amendments, and we are not disposed to support them.

There was a lot of consideration about the loan nature of the FHS in comparison to the Jobsearch allowance. I do not think it is an entirely appropriate analogy. I understand the way in which people raise it, but FHS is not intended to replace or equate with the Jobsearch allowance.

It is not a reasonable comparison to suggest that farmers who are in difficulty are in the same position as urban employees who find themselves without a job. They have some common problems and they face some common difficulties, but the situations are quite different.

This situation is probably more analogous to a struggling small business person, whether rural or urban. When we think about that comparison, we see that the farm household support is not perhaps appropriately compared with the Jobsearch allowance and is not inappropriately structured. It is for people to have their views about how generous it should be, but to make the comparison with Jobsearch allowance is not, I think, appropriate, nor does it really enhance the debate or lead to and assist in an informed analysis.

The FHS scheme also provides farmers who believe in their future with an opportunity to ride out the recession, even if their banks will not provide further loans. The farm is not required to be offered for sale. The farmers and their families alone decide their future. If they take the difficult decision to leave, a package of up to $55,000 per farmer is available to assist.

Senator O'Chee raised, in an impassioned way, a matter to do with a tax ruling. All I can do at the moment is undertake to look into that and see whether the concerns which he raised are valid. On the face of it, there did not seem to me to be a serious problem, but I am not across all the issues to do with the ruling, of course, and I do not know all the circumstances of the individuals who might be affected. They would be very complex. But as I understand it, most interest subsidies are paid directly to the financial institution and, therefore, the interest cost charged to the farmer is after the interest subsidy. If the

SPEECH.PARA: subsidy is paid to the farmer, it is included in his or her income, but of course it is then likely to be deductible, I would have thought, as an interest cost to such individuals in the normal course of earning their income under section 51 of the Income Tax Act.

PARA.TAB: On the face of it there does not seem to be a problem, but I understand there is a range of different circumstances that might be involved. It is not a ruling with which I am personally familiar; I just heard Senator O'Chee's outline of it. I will take that up with the Tax Commissioner and, if there are more factors which need to be reported, I will either advise Senator O'Chee directly, or, if it is of more general concern, I will advise the Senate. I thank senators for their support for the legislation and I encourage the speedy passage of the second reading.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Motion (by Senator McMullan)—agreed to:
That consideration of the Bills in the Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
Consideration resumed from 13 October.
The Bill.
