The coalition's amendments seek to set up the Australian Health Ethics Committee, the AHEC, as a body separate from the National Health and Medical Research Council. The AHEC would be established by the Minister and its functions would be advising, making recommendations and formulating guidelines and ethical issues relating to health, formulating guidelines for the conduct of medical research involving humans, conferring with State Attorneys-General during the formulation of guidelines and such other functions as the Minister determines.

PARA.TAB: The coalition amendments will also ensure that membership of the AHEC constitutes members of certain specified professions and areas of professional interest that are relevant to the Committee's functions. Our amendments will ensure that the appointment of members to the AHEC is undertaken in consultation with the Australian Health Ministers Conference and relevant professional bodies. Most importantly, the coalition amendments seek to ensure the separation of the AHEC and the NHMRC by providing that no member of the NHMRC or of a principal committee of the NHMRC is eligible for appointment to the AHEC.

The coalition amendments also require that any guidelines formulated by the AHEC can be effectively scrutinised by the Parliament by way of tabling and amendment. Our amendments set out the ground rules for the conduct of the independent AHEC, including meetings, voting procedures, resolutions, record keeping, the disclosure of pecuniary interests, terms of office of members, staff, and the engagement of consultants. The amendments will also ensure that the AHEC must furnish an annual report, which must be tabled by the Minister.

Finally, the coalition amendments seek to ensure that the current National Health and Medical Research Council statement on human experimentation and supplementary notes, which will be the current guidelines on medical research involving humans, will be reissued within six months of the date of proclamation. Under our amendments, these reissued guidelines must also be tabled and would be amendable by the Parliament. Both the Australian Federation of Right to Life Associations and the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference have expressed concern that there is a conflict of interest in having an ethics committee as part of a body whose major function it is to promote medical research. Both these organisations have called on the AHEC to be established as a separate statutory authority and for its guidelines to be subject to the scrutiny of the Parliament.

The Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985, which was chaired by Senator Tate, also supported the establishment of such a body as a statutory authority. In view of the continual developments in bio-medicine, the coalition contends that it is eminently sensible that the AHEC and the NHMRC remain separate. We believe it is imperative that the objective ethical review of medical research and clinical practice is ensured. We believe that the conflict of interests can neither be allowed to occur, nor be seen to be allowed to occur, in regard to the NHMRC's research and community functions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have some real concerns. As Senator Patterson has already foreshadowed, we will not be supporting these amendments. I believe that the climate at the NHMRC is changing. Representation on the Council is much broader and is not quite so heavily dominated by medical researchers or the medical and scientific professions. There is now a wide range of interests represented on the Council. I believe that, by the time we have finished with this Bill tonight, we will have an ethics committee that does have some teeth.

PARA.TAB: If the Democrats' amendments are accepted, then we will make sure that we have consumer representation as decided by the consumer organisations rather than any process whereby the Minister simply appoints who he thinks may represent the consumer bodies. I believe that the NHMRC is now far more open to input from the general public, and all that we are doing tonight will go further to ensure that. Therefore, I believe there is no need for the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health and Medical Research Council Bill 1992 is to establish the National Health and Medical Research Council as a statutory body. Since 1936 until now, that body has had its existence by virtue of an Order in Council decision. Considerable concern has been expressed over a number of years that the body which promotes medical research is the same body which establishes the ethical guidelines which should govern that research. That is a conflict of interests. It is one which should not have been allowed to continue, yet the Government has allowed it to continue.

PARA.TAB: Following the report and recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation, the Government came up with a response which, as history has proved, was found to be totally inadequate. The Government's response was not to agree to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee. Actually, that Select Committee recommended, inter alia, that there be a legislative principle which would, amongst other things, render unlawful any destructive non-therapeutic experiments on human embryos. The Committee also recommended the establishment of a separate national body which would not be associated with any other body, but which would be able to deal with the ethical questions involved and which would also be able to license particular institutions for the purposes of research.

The Government established an organisation which had no real statutory force. That was the NBCC, the National Bioethics Consultative Committee. The claim to fame of the Committee was the surrogacy report, which was roundly condemned throughout the whole of the nation. Indeed, the Australian Health Ministers Conference rejected the recommendation of that committee on surrogacy. So, for one reason or another, it became untenable for the Government to continue with that Committee.

I think that we have finally reached a stage where the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats all concede that the situation should not continue where the body which promotes medical research is the same body which establishes the ethical guidelines governing that research. The difference between the Government and the Opposition on this particular question is as to accountability.

The Government's proposal—and I have to deal with it to contrast it to the Opposition's proposal—is to establish an Australian Health Ethics Committee which will continue to be a principal committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. The Government seeks to amend clause 35 of the Bill to establish the constitution and appointment of the Australian Health Ethics Committee. The Opposition's amendment also establishes the constitution of the Committee. That is to be found in proposed clause 34E of the Bill.

I believe it is interesting that the Opposition includes in proposed paragraph (m) that on the Committee there is to be a person with an understanding of the concerns of disabled persons. That is something that is missing from the Government's proposal. I am quite surprised that the Democrats will not support this proposal from the Opposition because this is an area which is of great concern.

Disabled Peoples International, in a submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, made perfectly clear its concern about the way that the National Health and Medical Research Council is treating persons with disabilities. It strongly expressed its view that the proposals that were made by the National Health and Medical Research Council last year in regard to the establishment of registers of persons with genetic disorders were insufficient.

A number of honourable senators have read the submission made by Disabled Peoples International, so I will not go deeply into it. Suffice it to say that, echoing the concern that persons with disabilities have, a consultant ethicist, Mr Nicholas Tonti-Filippini, in a submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs on this Bill, referred to that guideline established by the National Health and Medical Research Council last year on genetic registers. In his submission he indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: The information for a genetic register begins to be collected when a family member is referred to the register staff for diagnosis, genetic counselling, predictive testing or management of the condition. The NH&MRC's guidelines for genetic registers state that the pedigree and health status of family members are to be recorded in so far as they are known by the family member being interviewed. The use of the phrase `pedigree and health status' in a human context is indicative of the level and eugenic direction of the NH&MRC's thinking. Information about family members is to be recorded even though consent has not been obtained from them.
Mr Tonti-Filippini, quite rightly, says:
This clearly breaches the right to privacy under article 12 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

The Bill proposes to continue to have those matters dealt with by a group without accountability to the Parliament. The Opposition is proposing, quite rightly, that these very major guidelines should be the subject of scrutiny by the Parliament because they are affecting future generations as well as existing ones to a very large degree.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, the Opposition's amendments require that, in the appointment of the persons referred to in proposed new section 34E, the particular bodies should be consulted. Senator Lees seems to indicate that the only authority that should be consulted is the consumers organisation. Why should not the other bodies be consulted when it comes to the appointment of those persons? For example, I notice that the Opposition's proposal says in paragraph (c), `a person who has expertise in law'. Further, the Opposition says, in proposed section 34F(4)(a), that, before appointing that member, the Minister should `seek nominations from such bodies representing the legal profession as are prescribed for the purpose'. Proposed section 34E(d) refers to `a person who has expertise in philosophy'; and proposed section 34F(4)(b) says the Minister should `seek nominations from such learned academies as are prescribed for the purpose'. Proposed section 34E(e) says `a person who has expertise in religion', and proposed section 34F(4)(c) the Minister should consult with `such peak religious bodies as are prescribed for the purpose'. And so it goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you supporting my amendments?

—No. Senator Lees proposes that this be done only so far as the consumer organisation is concerned. Senator Lees seems to be indicating that in respect of the consultation process her proposals are similar, if not identical, to those of the Opposition. I certainly have not seen those so I would be interested to have a look at them. But do Senator Lees' proposals contain a provision for a person with understanding of the concerns of disabled persons? They do not. This is an extremely vital area, one where Disabled Persons International has expressed grave concern. I will deal with the issue of eugenics shortly, because much of the experimentation that is proposed is to do with eugenics.

PARA.TAB: The vital part that is missing, I presume, from the amendments proposed by Senator Lees is that Parliament will have a say. At least at the present moment the National Health and Medical Research Council is responsible to elected representatives. It is now at least responsible to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services; it is not directly responsible to the Parliament. But under this legislation, as proposed by the Government, it will no longer be responsible or answerable in any shape or form to Parliament or any elected representative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the arguments against the Opposition's amendments were clearly put by Senator Lees. The Government, of course, opposes the amendments. We find virtue in the NHMRC being structured in a way which would have an ethics committee as a principal committee of it and, as a consequence, that committee being involved in the mainstream work of the NHMRC.

PARA.TAB: I think the way the legislation has been drafted ensures that we strike a balance between, on the one hand, the independence of the ethical view and, on the other, the need not to inhibit research by unnecessary rules. It should be noted that the guidelines of the Australian Health Ethics Committee would be made public and its independence is guaranteed by the structure of the legislation. However, the basic point is that we, as a government, feel that there is merit to ensure that an interlocking network exists between the committees of the NHMRC and, as a consequence, we oppose the Opposition's amendments.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being past 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will now deal with Government amendments Nos 1 and 2 together.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Bolkus)—by leave—proposed:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1)Clause 8, page 5, subclause (2), lines 29 to 32, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclauses:

PARA.TAB: "(2) The guidelines for the conduct of medical research involving humans must be issued precisely as developed by the Principal Committee known as the Australian Health Ethics Committee and provided to the Council for the purpose.

"(3) Sections 12, 13 and 14, and the procedures developed and published by the Council under section 15 apply to the activities of the Australian Health Ethics Committee in developing guidelines for the conduct of medical research involving humans as if the references in sections 12, 13 and 14 to the Council were references to that Committee and as if the procedures under section 15 had been developed to assist the Committee.".

INTERJECT.PARA: (2)Clause 35, subclause (1), page 17, lines 15 and 16, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "35.(1) The Minister must establish Principal Committees called the Medical Research Committee and the Australian Health Ethics Committee.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Government could explain to the Committee the true purport of amendments 1 and 2. They are amendments to the Government's own legislation. As I see it, the amendments are designed to have a principal committee of the NHMRC—namely, the Australian Health Ethics Committee—issue the guidelines for the conduct of medical research involving humans rather than, as provided for in the Bill, making those recommendations to the National Health and Medical Research Council. But I ask the Minister: what are the guidelines to be for the conduct of medical research involving humans, having in mind the provisions of clause 89 of the legislation?

—I could get up and say that they are embodied in the NHMRC's statement on human experimentation and supplementary notes 1992. But I suspect the question Senator Harradine is asking is: what are they in the interim before the next draft guideline is promulgated?
—Yes.
—My advice is that the guidelines are saved by the legislation, excepting supplementary note No. 4 which guideline would have to be remade by the Committee.

—I thank the Minister. When is it anticipated that the AHEC will reconsider those particular guidelines that the Minister has just referred to? Within what period of time is the AHEC expected to do that?
—My advice is that it would be expected to do that immediately.
—That is to say, the AHEC will expect to undertake the necessary public consultations, thoroughly review the guidelines and come forward with recommendations; is that correct?
—That is the case, yes.

—The Government amendments require the establishment of a principal committee of the NHMRC, called the Australian Health Ethics Committee, whose specified functions will be to advise the NHMRC on ethical issues relating to health and to develop and recommend guidelines on the conduct of medical research involving humans which must be issued by the NHMRC.

PARA.TAB: From what I can gather, the NHMRC would be required to issue these guidelines without amendment and we believe that the Government's amendments do not go far enough. They give the AHEC the responsibility of developing the guidelines on the conduct of medical research involving humans which the NHMRC would be required to issue without amendment. However, due to the open membership of the AHEC, the Government's amendments will not ensure that members of the NHMRC remain outside the decision making process during the formulation of these guidelines.

Unlike the coalition, it appears that the Government does not believe that the guidelines on ethical issues relating to medical research should be formulated by the AHEC but should remain the responsibility of the NHMRC. In effect, these amendments provide for a partial separation of responsibilities in relation to medical research involving humans, but no separation of ethical issues relating to medical research generally. These amendments provide no parliamentary scrutiny whatsoever of any of the guidelines, including those relating to medical research involving humans. That is one of the bases of our concern. It forms the basis of the Opposition's amendments, which I have circulated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are supporting these Government amendments. I shall speak on Government amendments Nos 1 through 11 because Nos 2 to 11 hang together in a package. These amendments basically set up the Australian Health Ethics Committee as a principal committee of the NHMRC. They provide a formal structure for the Australian Health Ethics Committee, give it far more autonomy from the Council and ensure broad membership of that Committee. I foreshadow that I will be moving amendments to these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to add to what has been said by Senator Patterson in relation to the Government amendments. I would like to comment on amendment No. 11, which sets out the composition of the Health Ethics Committee as a principal committee of the NHMRC and lists how the members are to be appointed and the areas of expertise they are drawn from. Paragraph (2) of proposed new section 35A states:

SPEECH.PARA: There must be included among the members of the Committee individuals who collectively have membership of all the other Principal Committees.
I find that a little difficult to understand. Does it mean that amongst this list of (a) to (m) there must be at least one person who is a member of one or more of these committees?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack, you might be a bit ahead of us. We are looking at Government amendments Nos 1 and 2 at the moment.
—I thought we were taking them as a whole; I am sorry.
—We were at one stage but something happened.
—Mr Chairman, it may be appropriate to do so. I do not think Senator Patterson disagrees with that.
—Mr Chairman, I presumed we were taking them as a whole.

—We are taking it as a whole. Let me indicate what I would like to do. I am in the hands of the Committee but this is probably the best idea. We will deal with Government amendments Nos 1 and 2 together. Senator Lees has another amendment to Government amendment No. 3, so I think we should take No. 3 by itself. Amendments Nos 4 to 10 can be taken together. Senator Lees also proposes to amend Government amendment No. 11. That seems to be a structured way to proceed so that we will get through this Bill much better. If there is no objection, I would like to proceed that way. The question is that Government amendments Nos 1 and 2 be agreed to.

—In respect of Government amendment No. 1, I refer to those matters which are now to be determined and issued by the Australian Health Ethics Committee—namely, guidelines for the conduct of medical research involving humans. Why is the Government proposing to put the AHEC in such an authoritative position only in respect of those guidelines and not, for example, in respect of ethical issues relating to health, including the establishment of genetic registers?

PARA.TAB: This is a matter of the utmost concern to persons with disabilities. It is also an issue of utmost concern to the community at large. It is most important to ensure that the body which finally determines that issue should not be the National Health and Medical Research Council, whose principal objective is the promotion of medical research. It seems to me that the rights of persons with disabilities may not be as adequately reflected by a body which is research driven as they would be in a body which is established specifically for the purposes of considering in detail the ethical questions involved in medical research.

That is not to say that the National Health and Medical Research Council or any of its constituent bodies should not consider the ethical questions that are involved. Of course they should consider at every step the ethical questions involved. But I just wonder why the Government has taken the view that only guidelines for the conduct of medical research involving humans are to be the prerogative of the AHEC and not other aspects of its functions—namely, the consideration and determination of ethical issues relating to health.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will say this in the nicest possible way: I do not blame the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, one bit because this Bill does not come within his portfolio responsibility. Senator Tate is on top of the whole aspect of this legislation. He was chairman of the committee which looked at human embryo experimentation in Australia. The committee brought down a recommendation that will no doubt be put later. That recommendation formed part of the Opposition's amendments that we put earlier this evening. I wonder whether Senator Bolkus could tell me where Senator Tate is. Why has Senator Tate let Senator Bolkus handle a Bill that is his prerogative? Senator Tate represents the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) in this place and he is a full bottle on this subject.

—I do not think that is within the ambit of amendments Nos 1 and 2. But since Senator Tate is not here and I am, and to the extent that anyone can understand the issues and the legislation involved, I have also had some interest in it.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the question posed by Senator Harradine: why distinguish between the function performed in the first amendment, paragraph (2), as opposed to the functions spelt out in the third amendment? It is basically a matter of balance. In trying to determine that balance, the Government felt that the functions as espoused in the first amendment are of major concern and have attracted an enormous amount of public interest and debate. It was assessed that there should be the utmost transparency in terms of that issue, and that was the best way to do that.

In respect of the functions performed within clause 3, it is fair to say that we are talking about issues that are developing there. In terms of achieving a balance, it was felt that the Health Ethics Committee would have an appropriate and probably a more proper role in respect of those issues of advising the Council, for instance, on ethical issues relating to health and so on. It was basically a matter of balance and the way that is reflected in the legislation before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister's answer to my question was not an answer. He just said `I happened to be here'. I ask whether Senator Tate is indisposed and whether he is going to ask for a pair later.
—Quite honestly, I do not think it is relevant to Government amendments Nos. 1 and 2, but I will ask the Minister whether he wishes to reply.

—This is not the first time that Ministers have been asked to take legislation through; it is sometimes done at short notice, sometimes at no notice and sometimes with a lot of notice. I find nothing extraordinary in respect of that. I do not know what Senator Walters is trying to get at.

—I would like a more definitive response from the Minister than the one he has given me thus far. The Government proposes that, of the functions of the Australian Health Ethics Committee, only (b) is a function for which it has total responsibility. The other functions are advisory only to the National Health and Medical Research Council. I make the point again that one of those guidelines, that is, the guideline governing the establishment of genetic registers, was decided upon last year—1991—by the National Health and Medical Research Council. It was decided upon after consideration, after a working party had been established which was principally research driven. Those are the guidelines currently determined and currently on foot. There is nothing in this legislation that is about to change that. The Minister said in response to me that, yes, the guidelines for the conduct of medical research involving humans would be the subject of complete review and reassessment by the new AHEC. The Minister was referring to the National Health and Medical Research Council statement on human experimentation and supplementary notes, with the exception of supplementary note 4, and we will come to that after dealing with the amendments.

PARA.TAB: I am just seeking information from the Minister on an issue that is of great concern to a number of people as to whether the AHEC will reconsider those guidelines relating to the establishment of registers of persons and families with genetic disorders. I mention to the Minister, so that he is aware of the conflict of interest involved, that a prominent member of the working party which prepared these guidelines is Professor David Danks. In submission No. 1 to the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985, he declared precisely what he meant by the word `prevention'. By that word he meant the elimination of those tiny humans deemed to have a genetic disorder.

If a situation develops where registers of persons and families with genetic disorders will be established in Australia, not for the purpose of curing the disorders but for the purpose of eliminating the bearers of those disorders, then I would have thought that that is a major question of public policy and a matter of great concern. That is not to say, of course, that some registers may not be useful in the treatment of diseases.

I know we are in the committee stage and, therefore, to quote from something would be ruled out of order. However, the thrust of all of this is to establish a situation where disease will be prevented not by curing a disorder but by the elimination of the small bearer of that disorder. I remind the Committee that that is precisely what occurred in pre-war Nazi Germany. A very interesting book by Robert J. Lifton entitled The Nazi Doctors describes the establishment in Germany in 1934 of registers, card indexes, of persons and families with genetic taints. As a result of these registers, hundreds of thousands of persons were sterilised.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you asking?

—I am coming to that. I am indicating the problem to the Minister. This is a major question. The problem that I see with the Government's amendment is that it allows these questions of major public policy to be determined by non-elected elites; by members of the National Health and Medical Research Council—a research driven organisation by definition.

PARA.TAB: The Minister is not even proposing that the Australian Health Ethics Committee be the organisation which has the final authority, let alone the Parliament. We have just been through that argument whereby the Parliament has been denied, by virtue of the vote of the Government and the Democrats, a say in this major question of public policy. That debate has finished for the time being, but this matter will come back to haunt the people who have voted thus. This whole question of genetic registers and what is proposed to be done with them will come back and haunt people, but it may then be too late.

I am asking the Minister whether he would explain to the Committee why such a major question, if it is not going to be the subject of scrutiny by the Parliament, is reserved for decision by the National Health and Medical Research Council? Why has the AHEC an advisory function in regard to this question rather an authoritative, determinative function?

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that Senator Harradine is talking about genetic registers. I did answer, in essence, that question when he asked the same question earlier this evening. The answer I gave was that it is a matter of balance and some areas are in the research and discussion stage. In the case of others, as is embodied in the first amendment, we feel that the debate has progressed a lot. In the interests of ensuring that independence and transparency, that is how the legislation is formed.

PARA.TAB: But I think when one analyses what Senator Harradine refers to when he talks about genetic registers and looks at the report of the NHMRC in respect of the subject, one sees that there is no imperative, no demands, and no mandatory provision to ensure that those sorts of registers are set up. I do go back to my basic point, though, that there is a balance. In respect of some issues, the Government feels that the Health Ethics Committee should have an advisory role and in respect of others, one in particular, we refer to a mandatory role.

Senator Harradine and I could probably discuss this matter all night, but the matter of balance is one which depends on value judgments which the Government has made in deliberative processes. I also ask the Committee to note that there is a public process involved in the formulation of these guidelines and that is an important aspect which will not be denied by the legislation.
Amendments agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to proceed to Government amendment No. 3 and follow that with Senator Lees's amendment No. 1.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:

INTERJECT.PARA: (3)Clause 35, page 17, after subclause (2) insert the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2A) The functions of the Australian Health Ethics Committee are:
(a)to advise the Council on ethical issues relating to health; and
(b)to develop and give the Council guidelines for the conduct of medical research involving humans;
(c)such other functions as the Minister from time to time determines.".

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the other functions as the Minister determines them from time to time? Could the Minister at the table give us an indication of what these functions might be? We are being asked to agree to an open-ended clause, which says:

TAB.TAB: "(2A) The functions of the Australian Health Ethics Committee are:

PARA.TAB: (c)such other functions as the Minister from time to time determines.

SPEECH.PARA: Could the Minister give us an example of what `such other functions' might be and by what method they will be determined? Who will refer matters to the AHEC? Where does the Committee get its instructions from?

PARA.TAB: For example, I know the NBCC took up this matter of surrogacy. It was suggested that there are a whole lot of other matters that the NBCC should consider but it happened to take up the matter of surrogacy, despite the fact that the various Australian States had already indicated their views. The States were appalled when the NBCC came down with its recommendation on surrogacy.

Since medical research is a matter of national importance, what role do the State Ministers for health have in this area? Do they have an ability to refer a matter to the AHEC for consideration? Again, will the AHEC publicly call for expressions of interest on what ethical questions it should consider when it comes to health issues?

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the Federal Minister is the only person who can make references; the State Ministers cannot. The Committee can assume references and it can also ask for expressions of interest if it is so desired—within the Committee's ambit of powers. So that is a clear answer to the second part of the question.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the part of the question that goes to subclause 35(c), I ask Senator Harradine to note that probably every second piece of legislation that comes before the Parliament has those convoluted words. It is a standard subclause which would be determined in accordance with the principal and ancillary functions of the Committee involved. It is a catch-all clause that would ensure that there is no gap in pursuing those functions. So nothing is intended to be hidden in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that point. I realised when I said it that it does occur on a number of occasions. But having looked at it, it seemed a rather incongruous way for the draftsperson to have put it.The Minister has pointed out a very significant fault in his proposal. That fault is that it excludes the State Ministers from making a reference. After all, the question of health is constitutionally a question for the States.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister: in respect of the NHMRC statement on human experimentation and supplementary notes, for example, will the Minister agree that at least one part of those supplementary notes is contrary to legislation in at least three States? There could be a situation whereby the AHEC makes recommendations to the National Health and Medical Research Council, and the National Health and Medical Research Council then makes a determination on ethical issues relating to health and that determination is contrary to State legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose what is seen by one person as a fault may very well be a virtue to others. I think there is something to be said for the fact that we cannot have people coming in from all angles to send off references to the Committee. We are talking here of a Minister responsible for the Act and, as happens quite often in areas of policy—not only in the health area but across the spectrum in government—the States do have an interest. Just because they have that interest, it does not mean that they can invoke reference powers in national legislation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine asked about whether there is a conflict between part of a guideline and legislation in three States. Quite often one finds that there is not total consistency between national and State situations. In fact, one often finds inconsistency between the States themselves. So the fact that there may be that inconsistency—and I am not so sure that there is—does not necessarily mean that we have a problem on our hands. Some degree of inconsistency can be quite healthy, especially when we are talking about issues of public debate.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 35, page 17, after subclause (2), insert the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2B)Where guidelines are issued by the Council under subsection (2), such guidelines are to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House of the issuing of the guidelines.".

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, this amendment provides that the guidelines that are developed by the Australian Health Ethics Committee for the conduct of medical research involving humans, and then issued by the Council, need to be tabled in both Houses of Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —For what purpose are the guidelines to be tabled in Parliament? Any member of Parliament who is interested in the subject will have, like I have, been able to obtain the guidelines that have been issued from time to time and the statements that have been issued from time to time by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Let us not make any error about it: Senator Lees has proposed that they simply be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days. The Parliament has no power under this proposal to disallow, let alone amend, those decisions of the National Health and Medical Research Council or of the AHEC.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees is simply putting on a gloss. The Democrats have voted against this Parliament having any scrutiny at all over the matter. This does not give us any scrutiny at all—let us make that clear—unless I am reading something to the contrary. I cannot read scrutiny into it. Therefore, it seems to me that in these major areas of public policy the Democrats are going to go along with the Government and allow non-elected groups to determine issues of major public policy. On other matters, the Democrats have seen fit to support proposals which allow the Parliament scrutiny on other issues which are of a lesser import.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Harradine; it is just a gloss effect. A set of amendments have been circulated in the chamber which go much further than the Democrat amendment, which provides just for tabling. They require approval of the ethics guidelines, notification in the Gazette, tabling in each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days, and the ability to be amended. We believe that is a much better course of action than merely tabling the guidelines. I am foreshadowing that those amendments would be stronger and cover in more detail the concerns we have rather than the amendment that the Democrats have put before us.
—All I wanted to say was that the Government sees virtue in bringing the reporting time forward, so we support the amendment.

—I am not surprised that the Government is accepting the Democrats' amendment because it is virtually a worthless exercise and does not give the Parliament any power whatever to take action. I agree entirely with Senator Harradine. It is putting the cart before the horse for the Committee to be dealing with the Democrats' amendment in this way when the Opposition has a much better amendment, which has been circulated, and which was part of a much more elaborate amendment which the Opposition first proposed and which was defeated. It was defeated on the grounds that it was setting up an ethics committee which was totally separate from the National Health and Medical Research Council.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate to point out that we could not pass the Democrats' proposal and subsequently pass the Opposition's proposal. If we are trying to have a tidy exercise, it would have been better to move the Opposition's amendment to an earlier clause of the Bill than to the one we are dealing with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did suggest earlier that that should occur, but it was suggested to me by the mover that it should come after the Government amendments.

—The point I am concerned to make is that the Opposition's proposal is far superior to the one which we are now dealing with. It provides not only that any guidelines dealing with experimentation in relation to humans should be tabled in both Houses of Parliament, but also that either House of Parliament can take some step in relation to amending those guidelines. That is a very great weakness, as Senator Harradine has already pointed out, in relation to Senator Lees's amendment.

PARA.TAB: Here we are dealing with matters of vital significance to human beings. These are not purely scientific matters; the guidelines are not just in relation to scientific research. They may be dealing with major moral or social issues which require political determination, and are not simply a matter for scientists to decide even though those scientists may be advised by colleagues on the Committee who have other expertise. These decisions are really not only a matter for experts; they are matters of public policy, and they certainly should be able to be considered and perhaps amended by Parliament. Therefore, I do not believe that the amendment by Senator Lees is really worth having at all. I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that the Opposition has an amendment which will satisfy the requirements of public policy and justice in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, you are right in saying that you did suggest that this amendment go first but, given the Government's overall amendments which have resulted from the examination of the Bill by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, it seemed neater for our amendment to go afterwards. Given that the Democrat amendment has only just come into the chamber, that I did not have time to see that particular amendment beforehand and have not thought through its full implications and the point that Senator Durack has brought up, I wonder whether there is any possibility of moving my amendment before the Democrat amendment in order for it to make more sense, or is there no possibility of doing that?

—There are probably two ways to do this. There could be a motion to postpone the amendment moved by Senator Lees, and then Senator Patterson could move her amendment. Alternatively, if Senator Lees is in agreement with the proposal, she could withdraw her amendment for this stage, Senator Patterson could move hers and, dependent upon that, Senator Lees could move her amendment.

—I am quite happy with that, and to do anything to make sure the process works as best as we can possibly get it to work at this hour of the night. I am more than happy to withdraw temporarily and let Senator Patterson move her amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wouldn't matter.

—Senator Bolkus has just made the comment that it would not really matter anyway, but to understand the fine points of what is happening here, it would be more appropriate that we do it this way. Whether we achieve anything more this way or not, it just makes more sense for some poor souls trying to read it in years to come when they are doing some Ph.D on human experimentation.
—Or late nights in the Senate.
—Or late nights in the Senate. On behalf of the Opposition I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 8, page 5, insert the following clause:
"8A.(1) Guidelines issued by the Council under subparagraph 7(1)(a)(v) or subsection 8(1) must be:

TAB.TAB: (a)notified in the Gazette; and
(b)tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the guidelines have been formulated; and

SPEECH.PARA: take effect only as provided by subsections (2) and (3).

TAB.TAB: If:

PARA.TAB: (a)notice of a motion to amend the guidelines is given in either House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days after the guidelines have been laid before that House; and
(b)the guidelines, whether or not as amended, are subsequently approved by that House; and
(c)the other House approves the guidelines in the form approved by the first-mentioned House;

SPEECH.PARA: the guidelines take effect in the form so approved from the day on which that other House approves the guidelines in that form.

TAB.TAB: If no notice of a motion to amend the guidelines is given in the House of Representatives or the Senate within 15 sitting days of the particular House after the guidelines have been laid before that House, the guidelines take effect from the day immediately after that 15th sitting day or, where that day differs in respect of each House, the later of those days.".

SPEECH.PARA: We have put these amendments forward because of the lack of support—except from Senator Harradine—for the coalition's attempt to separate the functions of the NHMRC and the AHEC. As I said, a number of submissions were made to that Committee suggesting that, plus it was the recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 chaired by Senator Tate.

PARA.TAB: The amendments will ensure that the AHEC is both independent and is seen to be independent of the NHMRC. The amendments will, if they are passed, ensure proper parliamentary scrutiny of the guidelines developed under subparagraph 7(1)(a)(v), that is, ethical issues relating to health, and subparagraph 8(1), that is, medical research involving humans. As I stated before, a number of organisations, including the Australian Federation of Right to Life Associations and the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference, have called for guidelines formulated by the AHEC to be subject to scrutiny by Parliament.

A number of people have said to me, `You are going to get all the riffraff coming along and saying, "These guidelines are not right"'. It would seem to me that this is a very important area of human endeavour. It is right at the edge of the research that is being undertaken. There are great temptations to those working in the field to get excited about being right at the forefront. It is sometimes a bit like being here in Canberra. Being locked away here day in and day out, we may lose sight of what is really going in the outside world. The same applies to those people in research. Sometimes they can get carried away with the moment of their research and lose sight of the overall outcome of what they are doing. It would seem only appropriate that those guidelines be looked at carefully and that people have the opportunity to make known publicly to their elected representatives their concerns about what is most probably the most contentious area of human research, or research of any sort—other than, most probably, nuclear research.

I am reminded of Robert Jungk's novel Brighter than a Thousand Suns. According to that book, all the people involved in the development of the atom bomb were absolving themselves of responsibility. Each said, `I was just working on this area'. Somebody else said, `I was just working on this area' and the military people said, `I was only working on this area'. Nobody seemed to have overall responsibility. Really, in the area of research it ought to be Parliament which has overall responsibility. I read that book as a young student and it made me think very carefully about absolving oneself of responsibility and thinking that we can give it to somebody else to do.

I have had discussions with Senator Lees. She said, `We should leave it to the experts'. It was left to the experts in that case. If Senator Lees has not read the book, I recommended that she read it over the Christmas vacation. It is a most enlightening book on what can actually happen when people get caught up in their own areas of research and their own areas of interest. There is a lack of an overall view.

It is worth noting that in the submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs inquiring into this Bill, DPI—Disabled Persons International—expressed concern that when the NHMRC issued guidelines on genetic therapy in 1988, it did not seek input from the community, and especially from people with disabilities. In the submission the DPI stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There needs to be much more input by people with disabilities into the determination of issues associated with genetic therapy and genetic registers.
The submission continues:

The unique life experiences of people with disabilities provide them with a different perception of reality to that of the medically dominated and non-disabled profession's consciousness of the NHMRC.

The coalition believes that the Parliament is the proper authority to weigh up the widely varying and sometimes conflicting viewpoints that will inevitably result when guidelines are issued in relation to the conduct of medical research involving humans and other ethical issues relating to health. Both of these areas, but in particular issues relating to medical experimentation involving humans, are more than likely to be the subject of extensive conjecture and public debate in the future. The coalition contends that it is the right and proper role of a democratically elected Parliament to be able to exercise its influence on behalf of the Australian public in relation to such issues.

PARA.TAB: In light of the fact that the Senate has rejected the coalition's very sensible amendments to separate the AHEC and the NHMRC, it is now doubly important that Parliament has the ability to amend these important AHEC guidelines. I would not like to be in a position 20 years down the track, when somebody a writes a book about research in this area, to have been party to absolving ourselves of that responsibility. Therefore the coalition moves those amendments to ensure that we as a Parliament have the ability to scrutinise the guidelines.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —There certainly is a very fine balance between giving an organisation such as the NHMRC the capacity to operate independently and flexibly and then subjecting this process to parliamentary scrutiny. We have had many concerns. There was a long debate in the Democrats' party room on this issue. Wide ranging issues were raised. There has been some concern in the past that the whole matter of medical research was running ahead of community understanding and community interest of the issues. In some cases, issues were surfacing before the Committee had even recognised that they would become issues.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the ethical issues involved here are more appropriately addressed by the greater community and consumer participation that will now be included in the Ethics Committee. The wider range of involvement from and more consultation with the community and the wider dissemination of information about the issues should be given a chance to run and work. Therefore, we will not be supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this amendment. I suppose it is a fall back position and, as Senator Patterson has indicated, an effort by the Opposition to ensure some sort of accountability to the Parliament. A number of submissions have been made to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, most of which appealed to the Parliament to ensure that these matters were the subject of accountability to Parliament. Is it not strange that people in the medical ethics field, academics and women's groups are coming to the Senate Standing Committee appealing to the Parliament to ensure that this body is accountable to the Parliament, yet here the Parliament is rejecting that? That is ironic, but that is what we have seen.

PARA.TAB: I have before me a press release entitled Bioethicists Agree on Need for Accountability of Australian Health Ethics Committee. It is signed by Ms Heather Deitrich of the Social Ecology Centre, University of Western Sydney; Professor Hiram Caton of the School of Applied Ethics, Griffith University; Mr Christopher Newell of Disabled Peoples' International (Australia); Mr John Fleming, the Director of the Southern Cross Bioethics Institute in Adelaide; and Mr Nicholas Tonti-Filippini, a Consultant Ethicist, of Melbourne. That press release appeals for accountability of decisions. It also appeals, as was indicated around the chamber, for adequate consultation with or representation of those who are affected by the new possibilities and for consultation with the broader community. It talks about the issues that are likely to be involved, such as genetic registers of Australian citizens on computer databases, surrogacy, drug trials, reproductive technology, privacy of medical records, gene therapy, organ transplantation, health resource allocation and management of the terminally ill. These are all major questions of public policy.

Senator Patterson, on behalf of the Opposition, is attempting to respond to that appeal for the Parliament to have a scrutiny over these decisions and these guidelines. I support the amendment moved by Senator Patterson. I hope that the Democrats will see this as a compromise position. I hope—I suppose forlornly—that they, or at least some of them, will support it because other matters will arise, not necessarily to do with health ethics or human experimentation, but to do with the development of new organisms and the like.

Unless the general public, the people, through their elected representatives, have some say over it, the technological imperative will ultimately prevail. I believe that some time in the future we will probably regret what we are doing here.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with interest to some of the debate on this, and it concerns me that the Australian Democrats have shifted ground on a very important point of principle. In a number of pieces of legislation recently before this Parliament, the Democrats and the Opposition have agreed that there are special arguments to say that issues such as this really ought to come before the proper scrutiny of the Parliament and that, instead of having the normal process of regulations being disallowable, there should be a process of amending the particular guidelines or whatever.

PARA.TAB: I draw Senator Lees's attention to the debates that the Democrats initiated and put forward recently with regard to the Disability Discrimination Bill, the Disability Services Act itself and the residents' rights agreements. Yet very surprisingly, and not understandably, they have now moved on an issue as fundamentally moral as the issues that have been debated here today by Senator Patterson and Senator Harradine.

I find that to be an argument that lacks comprehension and logic. Really, if the Democrats cannot see the good reason for this amendment on this important and fundamental issue, there must be a question over their credibility. I would challenge Senator Lees to put forward her counter-argument as to why the Democrats have moved away from the position that they have seen to be so fundamental as a point of principle on other important issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether Senator Lees could explain to the Senate whether the Democrats will be supporting this amendment, and, if not, why not.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson must not have been listening because I already have. I explained that we would not be supporting it. I went over the fact that there is a fine line between the operation of an ethics committee that is truly independent, open, flexible et cetera, and then having to subject all of that to parliamentary process and parliamentary scrutiny. We believe we are setting up, after this Bill tonight, a different ethics committee—one that has far more teeth within the NHMRC. While we believe it is important that we at least have a chance to publicly look at the guidelines, we do not believe that we need to subject them over and over again to the parliamentary process at this point in time.
—Is Senator Lees saying that the Parliament should be able to see them but not disallow them? Is that the situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically, yes. We should have a situation where they are open and freely available. That is why we are asking in our amendment that they be tabled so that they are open to scrutiny. We are setting up a far more independent structure with the new ethics committee within the NHMRC where we do not need to be constantly putting ourselves in the role of ethicists and then reviewing every one of its independent decisions.
—What is the point of them being tabled? If we cannot do anything about them, why should we even look at them?

—It should be an open process. Senator Harradine has already pointed out to us that, yes, they should be available if one has a specific interest and that one should know where to go and who to see to ask for them and so on. But we feel that it should be even more open than that and that all people should have access. All honourable senators—indeed, honourable members—should have access to them. If we wanted to, for example, raise an urgent issue or even move an urgency motion or use some of the decisions by way of initiating amendments to legislation or other processes, surely it is fair and reasonable that they are readily available in both Houses so that one does not have to go searching for them.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 35, page 17, after subclause (2), insert the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2B)Where guidelines are issued by the Council under subsection (2), such guidelines are to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sittings day of that House of the issuing of the guidelines.".

SPEECH.PARA: As we have already discussed, my amendment requires that the guidelines be tabled in both Houses of Parliament to give all members and senators access to them. I am not aware of all the details, although I know the basic processes. I am sure some honourable senators may not even be aware of some of the simple processes involved in getting copies. This is quite a simple amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask Senator Lees a question. How would these guidelines be tabled in the Parliament? Is it proposed that they would be

SPEECH.PARA: tabled in a manner similar to that which currently occurs; that is, that the Clerk gets up and says that there is a list of documents tabled in the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would seek guidance on that, but I presume that would be the normal course of events.

—I just picked up the list that was tabled today. The Clerk tables these documents every day. The list contains an interesting array of documents but I do not know how many senators study them every day. As we know, there is no provision in the Standing Orders for those documents to be debated. This is a matter of concern. In order to debate any one of these matters—
—I have done that by leave.

—Yes, but if we have to seek leave to debate the documents, by definition there is no provision in the Standing Orders to debate them. If there were provision in the Standing Orders to debate them, we would not need to seek leave. This is a problem. There is no scrutiny involved in this. I think Senator Lees said a moment ago that there would be scrutiny, but there is no scrutiny on the part of the Parliament. I am afraid that I am somewhat concerned about that.

PARA.TAB: I would have liked to have the opportunity to look at this amendment earlier. I might have suggested another fall-back position. That is, if we had not the amendable procedures but at least the disallowance procedures, this would enable the Parliament to have some sort of scrutiny and exercise some sort of accountability that the majority of those involved in submissions to the Senate Select Committee have appealed to the Parliament to exercise.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, this amendment ensures that the Minister has to seek nominations from the key organisations. The Minister cannot just presume that a particular person represents an organisation—for example, the church bodies. Indeed, he or she must select from those persons nominated by the said bodies, a list of which is on the second page of the amendment, and then select from that list persons with that particular level of expertise.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition can correct me if I am wrong, but it seems to me that this amendment is very similar to the Opposition's amendment. There appears to be a difference in the composition of the Australian Health Ethics Committee in that there is nothing in the Australian Democrats' amendment to the Government's proposal, as there was in the Opposition's amendment, to have somebody on the Australian Health Ethics Committee with an understanding of the concerns of disabled persons.

PARA.TAB: That may have been an oversight. If it is, I would be happy to move an amendment so that the provision of the Opposition's amendment to paragraph 34E(m) goes in, as does provision (i), which is on page 4. But I would need to draft that very rapidly, and I have not had the time to do so now. Firstly, I will see whether I have some understanding and agreement with the Opposition and the Democrats to see whether we cannot get a person so described onto the AHEC to be appointed pursuant to consultations as provided for on page 4 (i) of the Opposition's amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure Senator Harradine that I did not use the Opposition amendments. We have developed these amendments independently. Indeed, I have had my amendments circulated for a month or more. But I am quite happy to take Senator Harradine's suggestion on board. It was not something that I had considered previously, but it is a body that will no doubt have quite a specific opinion and quite a lot of expertise to add to this Committee.

PARA.TAB: Presumably, the drafting problems can be overcome, as the amendment is already before us in written form. It can simply be noted that I am quite prepared to accept Senator Harradine's amendment to my amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we can get the words right, the Government also supports Senator Harradine's concept. We could get consensus in this place on this point, but we might take a few minutes to get the wording right.

—One would have thought that Senator Harradine was saying that we will just extract that part of our amendment to paragraph 34E(m). Could Senator Harradine check our amendment, which is on page 3 of page 10 of the large number of amendments. If we are referring to paragraph 34E(m), I presume that we would have wording that would include the words `a person with understanding of the concerns of disabled persons'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is right. Senator Patterson may need to pick up that one as well as the one on the next page, clause 35(4)(i) which covers the appointment of members.
—I agree.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Vanstone)—Is it the wish of the Committee that consideration of Senator Lees's amendment to Government amendment No. 11 be postponed and that the Committee, while various persons work on the detail of what amendments then need to be made to Senator Lees's amendment, proceed to look at Government amendment No. 12? That being the wish of the Committee, it is so ordered. We will move to consideration of Government amendment No. 12.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12)Clause 89, page 39, line 33, after "with effect from that day", insert "and with the exception of the Supplementary Note 4".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an amendment to clause 89 of the Bill which states:

PARA.TAB: The guidelines entitled the "NHMRC Statement on Human Experimentation and Supplementary Notes" in force immediately before the proclaimed day are taken, with effect from that day, to be in force as if they had been made under subparagraph 7(1)(a)(v) and in compliance with section 8 until they are revised by the Council under this Act.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, this sets in concrete the National Health and Medical Research Council Statement on Human Experimentation and Supplementary Notes 1992. That was the intention of the Bill some weeks ago when the Bill was introduced into the Parliament. Now we have an amendment by the Government which says, `and with the exception of the Supplementary Note 4'. What does that mean? That means that supplementary note 4 relates to in-vitro fertilisation and embryo transfer.

PARA.TAB: That is the very supplementary note that the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 referred to when it said the marker event stated in that supplementary note lacked inherent ethical validity. When I saw clause 89 of that original Bill I decided that if that was going to be set in concrete in legislation, as was proposed, I was going to move an amendment which made it clear that there should be no funding by the National Health and Medical Research Council of any project which involved destructive non-therapeutic experimentation on a human embryo.

That was the recommendation made by the Senate Select Committee. I indicated that intention in the second reading stage of the debate. Since then there has been a great deal of misinformation supplied to honourable senators by certain people. I would like to refer to some of that misinformation which is largely the result of statements made by Dr Robert Jansen, who is the Medical Director of Sydney IVF Pty Ltd. As a matter of interest, Dr Jansen was the co-author of supplementary note 4 before he left the NHMRC Medical Research Ethics Committee and took up his position with Sydney IVF Pty Ltd.
He has been saying a number of things and I will quote something he stated in a circular which was distributed among honourable senators. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Twelve years after the birth of Australia's first IVF babies, the methods for culturing, or growing, human embryos in vitro have not changed much. As a result, success rates with IVF have improved relatively little.
Clearly that is wrong because overseas the figures for success rates on IVF have improved very little. In the UK there is very little restraint on experimentation on human embryos.

PARA.TAB: In fact, it is interesting to note that Fiona Stanley, an epidemiologist of very great standing in Australia, conducted a study actually funded by the NHMRC and stated recently on an ABC program that the success rates on IVF are identical to those people who are on the waiting list. That is an interesting comment and people ought to take a bit of notice of it. I am pointing out the inaccuracy of what Dr Jansen said. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Embryo research with objectives approved by independent committees can be ethical up to 14 days from fertilization.
That is what he said as co-author of the Medical Research Ethics Committee recommendations to the National Health and Medical Research Council which are contained in supplementary note 4.

PARA.TAB: That is what he said, but the Senate Select Committee stated that that comment lacked ethical validity. Frankly, it also lacks scientific validity, because when I asked the question, `Why fourteen days?', Professor Lovell—who was the Chairman of the MREC at the time—said, `Well, that is about the time when implantation takes place'. I asked him: had he not heard of Hertig and Rock? I suspect that he had not.

At that stage, Dr Jansen conceded that implantation did commence on the sixth or seventh day. So from a scientific point of view, 14 days is a nonsense. In any event, a human embryo cannot be transferred into a uterus after 14 days. For that matter, a human embryo cannot be successfully transferred into a uterus after about three or four days. So, scientifically, it is a nonsense. What he is saying there ignores what has been said on a number of occasions.

There are a number of other issues I would like to go through on this particular matter, but I presume I will not be permitted to by the Chairman. I ask the Minister why the Government decided to take out supplementary note 4. I think that is a valid question which the Government should answer. Does it also consider, as did the Senate Select Committee, that the marker event therein lacked ethical validity? I would be interested to know the real reason for this decision. Perhaps the real reason may have been somewhat different.

Was any consideration given to the question of whether or not a conscience vote would be allowed to the Opposition? Was that part of the considerations? Some members of the Government are saying—and I feel for them—that they do not have a conscience vote with regard to an amendment I am proposing. The reason that they do not have a conscience vote, it is being suggested, is that if supplementary note 4 were to be retained in the legislation, it would cement into legislation the provision which allows for human embryo experimentation up to 14 days. Having pulled that out, the Government is saying to its colleagues that, therefore, there is no conscience vote on the matter because that particular issue does not arise.
I would be grateful for some sort of authoritative statement from the Minister, if he can give it, for the Government's action in removing supplementary note 4 from clause 89.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I first of all ask Senator Harradine and Senator Lees in this informal way for agreement, hopefully, in respect of the previous amendment which we were working on across the chamber regarding disabled persons. When we are talking about organisations representing disabled persons we, as a government, would like to insert the word `peak', as in peak organisations representing disabled persons. It seemed as though Senator Lees is acceptant of that, and if Senator Harradine is as well, then we can go ahead with it.
—That is quite acceptable to the Democrats.

—This is a test of how good Senator Harradine is to his word. He asked why supplementary note 4 was excluded. It is essentially because of the work that he has been able to put together over a number of years. Can I get his response to that?
—Can the Minister tell me how this review is taking place? Can he give us a bit of detail on it?
—It will be done in accordance with the procedures set out in the Bill.
—There is no detail.

—The detail that Senator Walters would find in the Bill is that it would require public consultation and public discussion. I gave Senator Harradine a very brief answer. To be fuller, it is fair to say that we are talking about a note which is still controversial. It is, I think, some 10 years old. It is felt that it does need to be looked at again. That is the commitment I gave at the start of this discussion this evening—that it will be looked at again very quickly in the public discussion.
—I was asking for the detail of how the review is taking place. How is the public discussion taking place?

—I refer Senator Walters to page 7, clause 12, subclauses (2) and (3) of the Bill. That basically spells out a very public process triggered off by the Council publishing a notice in the manner and form specified in regulations, and on goes the process.

—Can the Minister tell us how long the process will take? The Minister said it would be very speedy, but can he tell me when it starts? Will it start as soon as this Bill has royal assent? Will it start prior to that? What will actually take place? I have been told that it will be looked at, that there will be public input and that the Bill will then be brought back. Is that the intention?

PARA.TAB: We have a proposed amendment tabled by Senator Harradine. I have been instructed that the Government has not given its members a conscience vote on something as basic as Senator Harradine's amendment. This side of the chamber, of course, has a conscience vote and the Democrats have a conscience vote. It is only the Government members that have been caucused and refused a conscience vote on that particular amendment. Can the Minister explain why the Government is not permitting its members a conscience vote on Senator Harradine's proposed amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Walters raises in respect of the matter before the Chair is the first one. In respect of the second, I have no knowledge of that point. In any event, it is not before us at the moment. In respect of the honourable's senator's first point, the point I made at the start of this discussion this evening in answer to a question from Senator Harradine was that we anticipate that the process will commence as quickly as possible. That is as precise as one can get.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the duration of the process, the legislation provides for a very full public interaction. It is very much in the hands of the Council as to how speedily that process can be effected. The question I have been asked is how soon we can get the process commenced. The answer is as quickly as possible, without being able to give Senator Walters a precise date and place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that in relation to one amendment that was to have been moved this evening Senator Walters and I would have had different views. Nonetheless, I have exactly the same view as her in relation to the question she has just put, as I understood it, to the Minister. I did not understand the answer at all. As I understood the question that Senator Walters put, it was whether Government members earlier this evening were under the impression that they would have a conscience vote on this matter and, if that was the case, whether it is now the case that that conscience vote has been withdrawn. They seem to be fairly simple questions.

PARA.TAB: The Minister looks around to his advisers for an answer. If they are advisers from the Department, I would be surprised if they have any obligation to know the answer. But I would have thought that the Minister, as the Minister conducting this matter, representing the Government and his Party—since there is a distinction—would have an answer to that question. It seems a pretty simple one. For the Minister to stand up and say that he has no knowledge of that matter, quite frankly, I find somewhat startling. I would be interested if he could strain the depths of his memory and give a better answer to Senator Walters. I understand that the amendment I am referring to has not been moved and, as I understand it, will not be. Nonetheless, what Senator Walters was asking has an impact on that question. I was wondering whether the Minister has anything to say in response to the question that has just been put to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—I think it is appalling. It is unbelievable that the Minister, who is meant to be taking this Bill, has no knowledge of whether the conscience vote of Government members has been withdrawn. TALK.START.PARA: —I table a replacement explanatory memorandum relating to the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill.
—I ask the Minister to explain why a replacement explanatory memorandum is being tabled.

—The explanatory memorandum presented on 25 November 1992 did not reflect some of the most recent changes to the draft Bill. This problem, together with some typographical errors, has been corrected in the version circulated this morning. The major changes to the explanatory memorandum are: firstly, the inclusion of `accidental' in sections 14 and 19; secondly, the heading of section 20; and, thirdly, clarification of section 27.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill which has been introduced in the Senate is purported by the Government to implement a national ban on tobacco advertising and promotion. However, in effect, it is a further extension of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1976 and the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Act 1989, which have resulted in the current situation whereby the direct advertising of tobacco is banned in the print and broadcast media.

PARA.TAB: This Bill will further widen the current tobacco advertising restrictions. From 1 July 1993 it will be illegal for tobacco companies to advertise their products by sponsoring or promoting cultural or sporting events. It will also be illegal for tobacco companies to use billboards and other outdoor displays to advertise their products. In addition, it will be illegal to use tobacco associated brand names on non-tobacco products. The maximum penalty for breaches of the Act will be $12,000 for individuals and $60,000 for corporations.

While the so-called ban commences on 1 July 1993, many of the restrictions contained in the Bill will commence from the beginning of 1996. Any tobacco sponsorship contracts entered into prior to 1 April 1992 will be allowed to continue until 31 December 1995. In the case of cricket matches, this extension will continue until April 1996. Similarly, any contract for a large billboard established prior to April 1992 will remain valid until the end of 1995, although tobacco advertising on smaller signs will be abolished by 1 July 1993.

The Bill provides for a number of exclusions to the tobacco advertising restrictions. For example, the broadcasting of overseas sporting events from countries where tobacco advertising is permitted is exempt as long as the local broadcaster does not derive financial benefit from the advertising. The labelling of cigarette packets will be allowed to continue. Tobacco manufacturers will be able to continue to use their company letterheads and advertise in publications that are distributed solely within the tobacco industry. Advertising at the point of sale, including advertising on tobacco vending machines, will continue to be permitted.

By way of a notice in the Government Gazette, the Minister may also authorise the advertising of specified non-tobacco products which have tobacco brand names. Obviously, anti-smoking advertisements which are intended to discourage smoking will be exempt from the ban. Tobacco advertising in imported magazines will also continue to be allowed, although the Minister will have the power to exclude a particular publication if it is considered that this exemption is being abused. Individuals will also be allowed to publish tobacco advertising on their own initiative if they do not receive any benefit from such publication.

Finally, the Bill permits tobacco advertising in association with certain specified sporting or cultural events. The Minister must deem that such an event is of international significance and that Australia would be unlikely to be able to continue to hold the event if tobacco advertising was not permitted. The Minister may impose conditions on advertising at such events. In imposing these conditions, he or she must pay regard to guidelines under the Act which will be disallowable instruments.

Any decision made in regard to specified non-tobacco products, imported periodicals and events of international significance will be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Decisions in relation to specified non-tobacco products and imported periodicals can be delegated to the Department. However, decisions concerning events of international significance cannot be delegated.

At the outset, I wish to state that the Opposition supports the legislation. It is irrefutable that cigarette smoking is an unhealthy and addictive habit.
