The Australian Medical Association estimates that some 20,000 Australians die annually from smoking related diseases and that 450,000 children presently under the age of 14 will die because they smoke. Tobacco is claimed to be the number one cause of preventable death and disease in Australia. As such, it also imposes a huge financial burden on the community, with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) stating in his second reading speech that tobacco cost the Australian economy over $6.8 billion dollars in 1988. I do not think that anybody in the Senate would disagree with me when I say that any responsible government should do everything within its powers to lower the incidence of tobacco use in the community, both by persuading smokers to give up speaking and by dissuading non-smokers from taking up the habit.

To date Government efforts to reduce the incidence of smoking in Australia can be put into five main categories: first, State and Federal governments of all political persuasions have continued to increase the tax from cigarettes. In the last Budget the current Government increased tobacco excise by 10 per cent. Fightback provides for a 25 per cent increase in tobacco excise. While such tax hikes obviously may dissuade non-smokers and new smokers, their effect on long term smokers is questionable, given the addictive nature of the habit. Governments also remain open to the perennial criticism from citizens that they do not want to reduce tobacco consumption because tobacco is such a lucrative revenue raiser.

Secondly, State and Federal governments continue to allocate resources for education and publicity campaigns which have the twin objectives of preventing people taking up cigarette smoking and of weaning addicted smokers off the habit. I include in this category the resources which are used directly to assist individual smokers to kick the habit as well as money which is spent on research into the cigarette smoking phenomenon in our society.

Thirdly, there are initiatives which seek to prevent the harmful effects resulting from the inhalation of cigarette smoke being experienced by non-smokers. Most commonly, this entails the banning of smoking in public places. The two major government areas in which such a ban has been imposed are in government buildings and on domestic aeroplanes and in airport terminals. It is also feasible that such initiatives have an indirect affect on the incidence of smoking. They often make smokers feel alienated from mainstream society. The effect of these bans on workplace and industry efficiency is also an important consideration. Recent court decisions on the harmful effects of passive smoking mean that these bans are likely to become more widespread in the future.

Fourthly, there are prohibitions on the sale of cigarettes to minors. While it is not feasible to ban the sale of cigarettes altogether, it is generally agreed that tobacco should not be readily available to children. This attitude is based on the belief that people at younger ages are more susceptible to peer pressure unless able to make a reasoned and informed decision about a matter which can potentially be very harmful later in life.

The final category of government initiatives is to stem the incidence of smoking in society. It relates to restrictions on the advertising of tobacco products. This Bill directly relates to this category. In the Minister's words, the Bill establishes a national ban on tobacco advertising. However, I think it is more accurate to describe this Bill as a further restriction on some of the methods of tobacco advertising rather than a total eradication of such advertising. I think we need go no further than the exemptions in this Bill to understand that it is virtually impossible to eradicate tobacco advertising altogether.

Some time ago when I was in Hamilton talking to a group of sixth graders, one little boy said to me when they were allowed to ask questions, `Senator, is one of the hardest things in your job making decisions?'. I think that was one of the most profound questions I have been asked while I have been in politics, and it came out of the mouth of a babe. The answer I gave that little boy was that it was probably one of the hardest parts of this job.

This Bill is one such example. It is no secret that there was considerable debate on this side of the chamber as to the pros and cons of the Bill. Those people both on this side of the chamber and the other who support the Bill present statistics and medico statements telling us about the harmful effects of cigarette smoking. On the other hand, those who would oppose the Bill because they believe that it is against the principles of free speech and that a company has a fundamental right to advertise to promote a legally available product such as tobacco would take another point of view. Some material that was sent to us provided statistics from a researcher at Monash University which interpreted the data entirely differently.

One does not get many belly laughs in this job. I think that when some people send us stuff they think we do not read it, but I assure them that we try to read it as much as possible. I read an article that was sent to us amongst a stack of material called `Politics and ideology of health promotion'. In that article, the author, Petr Skrabanek, a senior lecturer in community health in Trinity College, Dublin, was talking about a similar Bill that was being debated elsewhere. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The hypocritical exercise was described by Matthew Parris—
this is of a parliament, and I think it was the British Parliament, discussing a similar Bill—

after listening to the parliamentary debate on yet another blueprint for the nation's health were these words: `Fingers stained with nicotine, bellies hanging over their belts, faces flushed with climbing the stairs after a heavy lunch, MPs told the nation to care for its health'.

I wonder whether Mr Matthew Parris, in observing the debate on this Bill, would have the same words to say about people with fingers stained with nicotine, bellies hanging over their belts and faces flushed with climbing the stairs, telling other people how they should look after their health.

PARA.TAB: That goes to the essence of the debate that surrounded this Bill. There was considerable debate on this side of the chamber about the pros and cons: on the one hand, the very convincing and very emotive argument about the impact of cigarette smoking, and the impact of advertising, especially on young people taking up cigarette smoking; on the other hand, those who believe that it really is not for us to tell people, especially when it is a legal drug. We have a responsibility as parliamentarians to ensure that everything possible is done to educate young people about the problems associated with cigarette smoking, because that is what actually makes them free—their being able to choose whether or not they smoke on the evidence rather than on the basis of their not being allowed to see certain advertisements.

Given the pros and cons of the argument, we in the coalition finally reached the decision, with much soul searching, that we would support the Bill, given the fact that we understood all the other arguments that can be put on the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the introduction of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill we have a further part of the Government's package of reforms aimed at reducing the level of tobacco smoking in the community and, in particular, discouraging young people from taking up smoking. I am very pleased that the Opposition members in the party room supported this legislation, proving themselves to be more enlightened and concerned with the health of all Australians than their front bench colleagues who in fact opposed it. It seems that, once again, Dr Hewson could see the writing on the wall—but this time there was actually something worthwhile that he could do about it.

PARA.TAB: Like other senators, I have received a good deal of lobbying material on this legislation. I would like to deal with some of the issues that have been raised in argument against the Bill. It has been said, and I think it may well be raised in this debate, that it is hypocritical of the Government to legislate in this fashion when we are leaving other substances, such as alcohol, alone. Alcohol has not been left alone. Restrictions have been placed on its advertising, particularly aimed at discouraging young drinkers. It is true that these restrictions are not as rigorous as those on tobacco smoking, and I for one would be favourably disposed to tighter controls, but if we look at the relative situations of alcohol and tobacco it is easy to see that the argument that we should not proceed on tobacco unless we proceed on alcohol at the same time is a meretricious one, and it is intellectually unsustainable.

The most important factor is that of use as recommended by the manufacturer. The alcohol industry accepts the National Health and Medical Research Council's recommended maximum use of alcohol as the desired standard and it does not press for higher consumption. This recommendation is four drinks a day for men and two drinks a day for women. At this level the NHMRC believes that alcohol is not harmful. In fact there is even some research to suggest that at these levels of consumption alcohol has some beneficial effects on health.

There is no doubt that abuse of alcohol is a large problem in our society, but 30 per cent of the community do not drink at all, a further 30 to 50 per cent drink amounts below the NHMRC's recommended maximum levels, and only 10 to 20 per cent of the rest who drink above these levels can be described as chronic abusers of alcohol.

The problems relating to chronic abusers are severe because, as well as the obvious health problems that result, we also have social problems such as domestic violence and drink driving. Nevertheless—and I believe these are very interesting figures—if every man of drinking age had the NHMRC's recommended maximum of four drinks a day and every woman of drinking age had two drinks a day, the alcohol industry would double the amount of alcohol it sells.

Tobacco, unlike alcohol, will kill when used as intended by the manufacturer—that is, when it is smoked in any quantity. In other words, there is no safe level for the usage of tobacco products. This was certainly the finding of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Welfare in 1977 in its report entitled Drug problems in Australia: an intoxicated society. The Committee, under the chairmanship of former Liberal Senator Peter Baume, recommended a total ban on tobacco advertising. The tobacco industry then launched one of its infamous lobbying campaigns. The result of its success in avoiding an ad ban has been many more years in which death and disease have been spread with impunity in the Australian community.

With the series of legislative changes brought about by this Government—and with the bipartisan support for this legislation—I am pleased to say that I think that the tobacco industry's charmed run has come to an end. It has also been said that, as tobacco is a legal substance sold over the counter, it should be treated in the same way as, for example, Mars bars, which are often sold in the same outlets. I will presume, against all the evidence, that those who say this are serious. If they are serious, the best rebuttal of this false analogy is to look at products listed in schedule 3 of the Poisons Act, which lists dangerous substances. This is much more of an apt comparison, as tobacco is also a dangerous substance.

Schedule 3 includes about 150 items—everything from wart treatment to insulin to, significantly, nicorette chewing tabs. I use the word `significantly' because nicorettes contain exactly the same poison as tobacco products do—that is, nicotine—although, of course, they avoid the dangerous effects of smoking and of many of the known carcinogens in cigarettes.

What restrictions are placed on schedule 3 items? They are available over the counter in pharmacies—that is, from behind the counter and not on display shelves. There is no age restriction on their purchase. They are not allowed to be advertised or promoted to the general public. In other words, they have restrictions placed on them to ensure as far as possible that the material is sold and used in a sensible way and in the way that the manufacturer intended. If used in the proper manner, each of these preparations confers a benefit, a cure or an alleviation of an existing problem.

Unfortunately, while the Government can legislate to have tobacco products sold and used in a sensible way, as this legislation shows, this excludes the test of manufacturers' intentions of usage because, as I have said—and it is worth repeating—there is no level of safe usage. I have mentioned that nicorettes are schedule 3 items. The big difference between nicorettes and tobacco products is that nicorettes were developed after we became aware of the dangers associated with nicotine, one of the most poisonous and addictive substances we know of. They were developed specifically to offer addicted smokers a somewhat less destructive means of feeding their addiction.

Unfortunately, the patterns of sale and distribution of tobacco products were well established before this time and, therefore, difficult to change too quickly. In fact, our awareness of the problems associated with smoking is relatively recent. We have all seen the war films where the greatest kindness a soldier can do for his dying buddy is to light a fag and stick it between his lips. I think it gives a whole new meaning to the famous phrase `last dying gasp'. The tobacco industry's relentless campaign to recruit young smokers to replace older and wiser smokers who are kicking the habit I think is making it likely that these young people will also end up with the same `last dying gasp'.

We as a Government are doing our best to ensure that the tobacco industry's attempted recruitment of new young smokers is unsuccessful. Obviously, it is not an easy battle, not only because of the activities of the tobacco industry but also because of a complex interaction of factors that cause young people to take up smoking. There is peer pressure; there is rebellion against adult values, which is incongruous in itself as it is adults who tend to be pushing these products; and there is the glamour associated with tobacco sponsored sports. In the case of teenage girls, who are taking up smoking in alarming and proportionally greater numbers than boys, I think the strong incentive is the widespread belief that smoking will help girls to stay thin.

The tobacco industry continues to insist that sports sponsorship and the associated advertising does not attract new smokers but merely changes market shares within the existing market. I think this flies in the face of an overwhelming amount of research done on the subject. I have received recently, as I am sure other senators have, research which indicates a very strong link between tobacco advertising, sport sponsorship and children's smoking behaviour. For example, Professor Stephen Leeder of the Department of Public Health at Sydney University points out that he and his fellow researchers have estimated that tobacco advertising might be responsible for as much as 14 per cent of the uptake of smoking by children. While other peer pressures will continue to operate, there is no doubt that they will be mitigated by the removal of the factors covered by this legislation. We have every reason to hope that this combined with positive education programs such as the current `Smoking. Who Needs It?' campaign will reduce the number of young people taking up smoking.

A number of sporting organisations have lobbied hard against this legislation, claiming that it will virtually mean an end to sport in Australia as we know it. However, they have wandered onto very dangerous grounds, I think, by entering into the health debate at all. I have been sent material which claims that there is no definite, indisputable, beyond doubt causal link between smoking and disease, between cigarette promotion and the level of smoking; that not as many Australians as claimed are dead or diseased because of tobacco smoking. I must say that this really makes me wonder: at what point would the relationship start to worry these organisations? Would it worry them if their sponsor's product was killing Australians at the rate of a hundred a year, a thousand a year, 10,000 a year? At what point do dead and diseased Australians become more important than horses running around a track, footballers kicking the leather or—it really hurts me to say this—even the whack of leather against willow on the cricket pitch?

One thing that was obvious was that both the themes of these letters and the so-called research to back up what they were saying were obviously provided to them by the tobacco industry. The Royal Australasian College of Physicians confirms that `advertising by tobacco companies, including their sponsorship of sporting and cultural events, has been a factor in encouraging the uptake of smoking by young people'. (Quorum formed) The RACP also points out that the tobacco industry sponsors medical research as part of its strategy to undermine research findings about the health effects of smoking, to foster the illusion that the issue of whether smoking damages health is still a matter for debate, and to enhance its public image.

I would like to point out the hypocrisy of the tobacco industry raising these issues, given the disgraceful treatment of cricketer Greg Matthews, who exercised his right to free speech by appearing in a double page spread entitled, `When you really want to quit' in the Woman's Day of 25 May this year. For this heinous crime Greg Matthews lost three months pay, presumably at the behest of the sponsors, Benson and Hedges. Cricketers' contracts are now being rewritten to prevent this example being followed. Honourable senators could well exercise their minds as to what this sort of action means.

While I am on the subject of the Australian Cricket Board, I was interested to read a media release put out last year jointly by the British Medical Association and the Australian Medical Association which roundly criticised the ACB for being the only national sporting body in Australia clinging to tobacco sponsorship. They pointed out that all countries in the European Community were set to ban tobacco advertising and sports sponsorship.

Dr Roly Bott pointed out that an extensive survey conducted in Western Australia showed that tobacco sponsorship of sporting events was seen by children as a personal endorsement of smoking by the athletes involved—the very same athletes who are role models for young people at the most vulnerable age as far as smoking is concerned. Dr Ian Field of the BMA said that a UK survey had found that 64 per cent of children aged 15 and 16 believed that cigarettes were advertised on television. In fact, tobacco products have not been advertised on television in the United Kingdom since the 1960s, which shows clearly that children do not differentiate between advertisements and a telecast of tobacco sponsored events. It also shows the necessity for us to plug all the loopholes to prevent the tobacco companies just moving the circus to a new venue.

It is to be hoped that the progressive legislation which has been introduced by this Government will provide a role model to help other countries avoid the mistakes that we have made and to spare them the huge price in terms of medical and other costs associated with smoking related illnesses, given that tobacco companies are responding to an overall decline in tobacco consumption in this country by now focusing their activities in the Asia-Pacific region. If this legislation denies to tobacco companies the absolute right to commercial free speech that they desire, it does not deny to individuals the right to kill themselves, to destroy their health with tobacco products or to add to national health costs. It merely closes off some of the means used by the tobacco companies to entice them to do so. That, of course, is the right of any government which has to pick up the pieces. I support the Bill. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be speaking on the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill 1992 tonight, not just because it has been a while now that we have waited for it to come before us but also because I am one of a long line of Australian Democrats who have taken an interest in this issue, which is the advertising of tobacco products. In preparing what I had to say tonight, I went to Hansard to look up what had been said by my colleagues in the past. I have found so much information from the Hansard database, even culling it twice into about one third of what I originally had, that I will spend my time basically saying to the Senate—we have all said it before—that the Democrats have been calling for a variety of actions to be taken to limit the advertising of tobacco products.

PARA.TAB: I will go back only as far as 1981 and begin with a question without notice asked by Senator Chipp of a Minister concerning the advertising of cigarettes. In those days, it seemed that the problem related to the misuse of the terms `mild' and `extra mild'. The tobacco companies were mislabelling products and trying to con people into believing that they were smoking a mild variety when there was no such thing. The findings of the report basically said that many smokers who believe that they are smoking low tar cigarettes are not doing so. Action was promised but, as we see from further reading, that was basically an agreement with the tobacco companies, on consultation with them, and that agreement well and truly broke down.

On 21 April 1983, a notice of motion was put forward by Senator Mason relating to the relationship between health costs and the smoking of tobacco products. He argued that user pays principles should be instituted by which manufacturers, sellers and users of substances which can be demonstrated to increase the costs of health care to the community should contribute substantially towards those costs.

On 6 September 1983, a private member's Bill was introduced by Senator Jack Evans entitled the Australian Capital Territory Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill 1983. Senator Jack Evans said this about the basic purpose of the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: I propose this Bill as the Australian Democrats spokesperson for sport and recreation. I do so in an effort to protect the children of Australia and to prevent debasement of sport and recreation. After many years of active involvement with sporting organisations I am appalled at the way tobacco companies use sport as a means of enticing young Australians into tobacco addiction. This Bill is intended to protect young Australians from the influences which encourage them to begin smoking tobacco. It is a tragedy that young Australians are being subjected to such pressures. It is even worse when activities such as sport and recreation are abused by using them as vehicles for luring our young Australians into addiction. The Government currently spends millions of dollars on curative medicine relating to diseases and ailments associated with the use of tobacco products. Preventive action can ease the cost and burden which society has to bear resulting from the use of tobacco products. This Bill is a small step towards lifting that burden.
On 15 September 1983, Senator Jack Evans continued his pursuit of the issue with a question on cigarette advertisements. Part of his question stated:

Will Senator Grimes ask the Minister for Health to convey to the States' Ministers for Health a proposal that all States and the Commonwealth Government should now legislate to oblige tobacco advertisers to draw the public's attention in all their advertisements to the harmful effects of their product?
Again, the reason for emphasising this was that the voluntary code had broken down. The Minister's answer noted:

I know that it was a recommendation to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare and is a recommendation of most knowledgeable authorities in the area that there should be a ban on the advertising of cigarette products in the written media as well as the electronic media, where a ban already exists at the moment.

I remind the Senate that we are going back to 15 September 1983 when the problems were well recognised. In March 1984, Senator Jack Evans asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health a further question relating to the fact that the voluntary code had broken down. The Minister said:
. . . clearly contrary to the voluntary code . . .

It is a problem that we are just finally coming to terms with. I turn to a question without notice asked by Senator Jack Evans relating to the advertising of tobacco products to children under the age of 16 years. The Minister's answer in part was:
. . . it would not be possible to prevent children under 16 obtaining access to otherwise permitted advertising.
He went on to say:
In 1977 Senator Baume—
that is former Senator Peter Baume—
and I and others suggested that we should ban all tobacco advertising. No government has been willing to take up that recommendation.

On 14 October 1986, Senator Vigor gave notice of his intention to move amendments to a tax Bill to make tax deductions for tobacco promotion not allowable as a business expense. When Senator Vigor went on to move these amendments, he said that he was looking at the goal of reducing smoking by young people. He stated:

PARA.TAB: Another means of achieving our goal is to put tobacco virtually out of the economic reach of youngsters . . . if the cost of promotion goes on to the tobacco, we will raise the price of this commodity and, hopefully, put it out of the reach of youngsters. We know that more than 80 per cent of those who smoke become addicted before they are 20. This is the key age group on which we must concentrate—the teenage years. The pedlars of tobacco know that so they deliberately target their promotional and advertising strategies to hook the young because they are victims for life.

SPEECH.PARA: All of the facts are well known. When the vote was taken on those amendments the Democrats lost, but I do note that Senator Harradine joined us against the rest of the chamber. On 4 December 1986, Senator Vigor proposed amendments to remove tax deductibility from advertising of tobacco products, but again those amendments were not passed. On 4 December 1986 Senator Mason asked a question without notice:

Is the Government aware of an article in the October issue of Nature stating that smoking is estimated to cause 30 per cent of all cancers, that in Norway a national anti-smoking campaign involving banning cigarette advertisements resulted in fewer people taking up smoking, and that a general approach to the treatment of cancer ought to be preventive in view of the increasing indictment of smoking as a major cancer hazard? When will the Government ban all advertising of tobacco, prohibit smoking in aircraft and other public places, and ensure that tobacco products are taxed at levels which compensate for the enormous sums in health care costs they cause to the community?

I note that we have at last seen the ban of smoking in aircraft. Petitions were lodged to support Senator Jack Evans's Bill, which I mentioned earlier, and yet further petitions were lodged, this time by Senator Sanders. Unfortunately, that Bill was not successful. But on 7 May 1987 Senator Mason introduced a private member's Bill entitled the Air Navigation (Smoking) Amendment Bill. In his speech he said:

I think it is very plain to everybody that there is no proper separation between the non-smoking and the smoking areas of aircraft. There is absolutely no protection to enable people in the non-smoking zones to get away from smoke.
Later he said:
. . . it is important to examine the reasons why nothing is done about smoking.
He gave two reasons:
The first is the pressure of the tobacco lobby on members of parliament; the other is the pressure of the tobacco lobby on the media, which carries a very heavy responsibility.

On 14 May 1987, Senator Sanders, in support of the Olympic Insignia Protection Bill 1986, moved amendments which were basically aimed at precluding the insignia and other Olympic designs being used in a context where they may be associated with the promotion of tobacco or, indeed, of alcohol consumption. Unfortunately, when he moved these amendments on 14 May they were lost.

PARA.TAB: On 9 October 1987 Senator Coulter, in a question without notice, raised this issue. On 18 April 1988, Senator Coulter spoke on a matter of public importance on the national campaign against drug abuse. I will quote briefly from Senator Coulter's speech:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1981-82 the Medical Journal of Australia estimated that the direct dollar costs of smoking and the ill health and deaths associated with it were roughly $1 billion per year—about $400m in the cost of hospital beds and care, $250m associated with deaths and about $350m in social costs related to lost wages and lost productivity. It is worth making the point that those costs have almost certainly risen at least 50 per cent to 100 per cent by now.

In August 1988 Senator Jenkins asked a series of questions on notice. Again, in 1988 Senator Macklin asked further questions related to smoking. Later Senator Macklin presented a notice of motion concerning smoking in Parliament House. Very briefly, it states:
. . . requests the Presiding Officers to—
(a) prohibit smoking in confined working and public places in this new Parliament House;
(b) enforce the provision of non-smoking areas in all recreational, retail, restaurant and working areas not covered by (a) above;

I note that at least some of that has been picked up by us in 1992. On 2 March 1989, Senator Macklin spoke on the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988 and on 31 May 1989 he presented a notice of motion. The final part reads:

(d) calls on the Government to adopt the recommendation of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority that the Commonwealth Government ban all advertising of tobacco products on radio, television, in cinemas and in print so far as it is within its constitutional power to do so'.

On 31 August 1989, Senator Powell introduced the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Bill 1989. Many petitions were received in support of this Bill over the ensuing months. This private member's Bill was passed in December 1989 with Government, not Liberal, support unfortunately. Senator Powell, in her second reading speech, stated:
The effect of the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Bill 1989 will be to end cigarette advertising in the print media.
Of the surveys which had been conducted, she stated:
A Morgan poll of 2,251 Victorians in October/November 1988 showed 63.7% approval, 28.9% disapproval and 7.4% do not know, on the question of an advertising ban.

Clearly, there was already widespread community support. I now move to amendments to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990 and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 which were moved by Senator Powell and which highlighted the problem that we are now dealing with. Senator Powell said:

The amendments which I will introduce relate to the deficiency in the Act which we believe the loophole allowing incidental advertising on broadcast media of tobacco products represents. We wish to close that loophole.

These amendments were not successful when they were finally dealt with in December of that year. I move on to look at further amendments. These were again moved by Senator Powell and were aimed at closing the loophole through other legislation. There were amendments to the tax legislation by Senator Spindler, which tried to get at tax deductibility for the advertising of tobacco products. But again these were defeated by the combined vote of the Opposition and the Government.

PARA.TAB: There were now a large number of petitions being put forward in support of the actual closing of that loophole. I have sheet after sheet of them here, including those submitted by Senator Powell, Senator Bourne and Senator Bell. Senator Bell put down a notice of motion in April 1991. This again related to advertising which associates sporting events with cigarette brand names and cigarette company names.

There were further petitions calling for a ban on incidental advertising. This time one of them was presented by Senator Kernot. There were further notices of motion, again calling for government action on this problem of incidental advertising. There were further speeches from Senator Bell and a notice of motion from Senator Sowada relating to rugby league and tobacco sponsorship of that particular sport. I go on to Senator Kernot's efforts to move the amendments restricting tax deductibility for advertising. She basically said that the Australian Democrats believe that this is very bad public policy and that no tobacco advertising expenditure should qualify for an income tax deduction.

I move on to another series of notices of motion and efforts by Democrat senators to bring us to the point we are at tonight. We are finally dealing with what is hopefully the last loophole; whether or not it is the last loophole I guess we will only see in time. But hopefully what we are doing tonight will close that last loophole with a couple of exemptions. The first exemption is for international sporting events of national significance, which does cause us some concern. We hope that the two Australian events likely to be affected by this can find alternative means of sponsorship very quickly. Then there is the question of magazines coming in from overseas. This area perhaps offers the greatest potential to be the next loophole that we have to close.
However, I wish to finish on a positive note by congratulating the Government on finally taking note of all of the pressure put on it over the years. We certainly support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought one of the interesting facets of Senator Lees's contribution—I am sure Senator Powell picked this up—is that I did not hear one reference to anything Senator Powell has done in the last few years.
—I did. I specifically referred to her.

—I apologise totally. It is very fair of Senator Lees to also include people such as Jack Evans and Don Chipp. It is good to see that there has been a strain of consistency through the Democrats over the last 15 years with regard to this policy. Many other issues do not enjoy the consistency that people such as Don Chipp and my old friend Jack Evans would be pleased about.

PARA.TAB: However, I want to make reference to something Senator Faulkner said. This is a debate which I know has caused, I guess, high blood pressure and a lot of emotion within the Opposition ranks over many years, culminating in a party room discussion which I thought was well argued on both sides. I understand that in the Caucus meeting on the opposite side there were also long, ongoing debates, as I presume there have been over the years. There were very strongly held views on both sides.

So I thought it was unfortunate—but not surprising—that Senator Faulkner should try to score what I thought was a very cheap point and fire a very cheap shot by saying that somehow the Opposition front bench had a differing view from that of the back bench when indeed the discussions and the debates, both on the front bench and the back bench, were fought from both sides of the argument with deep conviction. I know that is the case federally.

The Government resisted for years and years the Democrats' private member's Bill when it came to banning advertising. Indeed, not so long ago—I know that it was during my time in this Parliament; Senator Herron will remember better than I—it was the Government which refused to support this measure. I know that Senator Herron was going to support it, along with a number of other Liberals. So I thought it was silly of Senator Faulkner to make those comments when his own Ministers had refused to act on this over so many years.

I do not think there is a single person in politics, indeed a single person in Australia, who would seek to encourage children to smoke. I am perhaps naive, but I do not think that even executives of tobacco companies would like to see children smoke, even though people who are opposed to the tobacco industry as an industry would have one believe that these nasty tobacco executives go around trying to encourage young people to smoke. Indeed, on the surface it may seem that it is in their own best interests to do that but I personally do not believe that is so. Perhaps I am naive and foolish.

Also, I do not enjoy the self-righteousness which people who support the banning of all advertising bring to the argument. There are sound arguments on both sides—both the freedom of speech and free enterprise argument and, of course, the public health one. It does not help the debate for either side to brand the other with simple name calling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say yes and sit down.
—I thank Senator Ray for his help; he is always very helpful in here!
—You are wandering around the subject. Let's hear a decisive view from you—you support it—and sit down.
—Order!

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President, for that support. Senator Patterson referred to an article called `Politics and Ideology of Health Promotion' by Mr Peter Skrabanek. I thought something that Peter said would enlighten the Senate and probably amuse Senator Ray. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: The loud and preposterous moral crusades that so endlessly rock the republic—against the rum demon, against fornication, against the cigarette, against all things sinful and charming—these astounding jehads offer fat clinical material to the student of mobocracy—
he was quoting H. L. Mencken in 1918—

shortly before the wowsers (as he called them) won their first victory—the Volstead Act, enforcing prohibition of alcohol in the USA. The current health promotion campaigns also emanate from the USA and are eagerly imitated elsewhere. What has changed since 1918 is not the content of the rhetoric but its form. What were once the ravings of bible belt preachers have become the dry prose of the Surgeon General's reports and the bland language of risk factor epidemiologists, who act as advisers to government bureaucracies. These are peopled with a new class of secular oligarchs who busy themselves with drawing blueprints for the nation's health (or, in the case of the WHO, for the health of the whole world) by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: In 1988, the then Director General, Dr H Maher, received a symbolic present to celebrate the WHO's 40th anniversary, in the form of a poem:
Mankind's true

SPEECH.PARA: Health must come

PARA.TAB: With the new

SPEECH.PARA: Millennium

PARA.TAB: Heed the call

SPEECH.PARA: For common wealth

PARA.TAB: Health for all

SPEECH.PARA: All for health
That this piece of puerile trivia warranted an official press release is symptomatic of the unreal world in which some bureaucrats live.

PARA.TAB: Health promotion was defined in a journal as the `science and art of helping people change their lifestyles to move forward towards a state of optimal health . . . a balance of physical, emotional, social, spiritual and intellectual health.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no faith whatsoever in governments being able to deliver that state to the citizenry. That is why I have severe doubts as to whether or not this Bill will achieve its objectives, particularly those of increasing public health and stopping children from smoking.

PARA.TAB: I will be supporting the Bill because my party, in its great wisdom, has chosen to do so. I wanted to take this opportunity to respond to a couple of things that the Minister said in his second reading speech, wherein he said, `Removing tobacco advertising is primarily a prevention activity intended to reduce the number of children taking up smoking'.

SPEECH.PARA: I do hope he is right. I doubt that he will be.
Although advertising may not directly cause children to smoke, it reinforces other influences such as peer and social pressures which cause children to smoke.

As someone who did take up smoking, as what I believe was a result of peer group pressure, I still think that is a very significant cause and it is a cause that I do not think will be diminished by the authorities telling children that they should not smoke and banning advertising. The Minister goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: We are reminded by the recent decision of the High Court that free speech is a value fundamental to Australia. Serious consideration must therefore be given to any restrictions on free speech, including commercial free speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I thought it was very wise of him to put the strongly held views of the Opposition on this Bill in his second reading speech.

PARA.TAB: The last point I want to deal with in my short contribution is one section of the Bill that does concern me particularly, and that is the broad regulation making power which is contained in section 16. The Government has set out to ensure that, in States where there are no regulations controlling point of sale, the Federal Government will have the power to make regulations.

I remind the Senate that there are currently no point of sale restrictions in New South Wales, even though it is moving to the position where they will be implemented shortly. In Western Australia there were some regulations passed recently. However, these are being challenged in the High Court by a small business person. The position in Queensland, the Northern Territory and Tasmania is that there are voluntary agreements which encompass things like not having cigarette point of sale advertising within certain distances of schools, playgrounds and so forth. I understand that these voluntary agreements are working quite well.

I would seek from the Minister in his response, or in the committee stage, some sort of indication from the Commonwealth as to how it would see these regulations working and some sort of assurances that the regulations will be in the spirit of the Bill and in keeping with the point of sale regulations which are emerging in the States.
I conclude my contribution by moving, on behalf of Senator Patterson, who ran out of puff during her speech and was not able to do so, a second reading amendment. I move:

At end of motion, add ", and the Senate congratulates the Coalition on its commitment to preventative health measures that will benefit our community and in particular, that it congratulates the Coalition for its Fightback commitment to increase tobacco excise by 25 per cent".

TALK.START.PARA: —It is somewhat ironic that we are here debating a pretty significant public health measure at this hour of the night, at some risk to our own health no doubt, and particularly I think—anticipating some interjections from the Opposition—that the Bill that most recently took us a lot of time had been around since October and bounced in and out of a committee system which is supposed to speed things up in this chamber. However, I am very pleased finally to be standing to support the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill 1992, which is long overdue, but which could not be more welcome. This is legislation which will go a very long way—and I believe perhaps as far as can be gone—towards removing tobacco promotion from the daily lives of Australia's population and particularly our children.

PARA.TAB: It has been a long haul. I acknowledge Senator Lees's contribution on behalf of the Australian Democrats to that long haul. This is the third piece of legislation in this Parliament in two decades. In 1973 legislation began the phase-out, finishing in 1976, of electronic broadcasting of direct advertising. Then there was my own private member's Bill some 13 years later, the last piece of legislation to pass the Parliament before the 1990 election, which banned print advertising of tobacco products, something which they said could not be done by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth was said not to be able to legislate over the print media when print ownership takeovers were taking place and so on. Nevertheless this Parliament was enlightened enough.

In the end, we took a cross-partisan approach to pass that legislation, which banned print advertising. A great many other initiatives have been taken along the way, but not requiring Federal legislation. One that I approved of a great deal in terms of my own personal comfort was the ban on smoking in aircraft. I welcome the extension of that ban to various international flights as well.

I would like to spend most of my time talking about the process that has led up to this legislation and what it represents. I know something about it, having been responsible for the passage of a fairly large slice of the legislation leading up to this particular Bill and having supported the process which has taken place since. This piece of legislation—and the private member's Bill banning print advertising for which I was responsible—is an excellent example of the way the community can win out over an extraordinarily powerful commercial lobby. The community has won out in this case because of cooperation, well organised effort, persistence and patience. Nevertheless, it has won out. This is a very important message in a whole lot of areas where quite often individuals and groups in the community feel that their efforts will not be rewarded and are inclined to give up. My comments are designed to encourage these people not to do so.

Honourable senators who have contributed to the debate have referred to the intense lobbying which they personally have received. While this legislation has been in gestation I have heard people quote from documentation that has been sent to them by the tobacco companies. I have received none of that. It has been at least five years since the tobacco companies gave me a hard time, because they knew very well that it was a waste of their time. I was never rude to them. Just before my own Bill was passed, they sent a token delegation, not even of their heaviest heavies. I know that that lobbying has continued with other people. One of the most encouraging things about this piece of legislation is that it has finally not succeeded on politicians.

I pay tribute to those community groups who have had the patience and persistence to make this achievement successful—groups such as the action on smoking and health and the Australian anti-smokers movement. In particular, I wish to refer to one individual, Stephen Woodward, who needs to be acknowledged at this point in the debate since this may be the last major hurdle that he thinks he has to jump. Wherever he jumps, that issue is bound to be successful in the end.

The various health organisations around this country—the anti-cancer councils, the National Heart Foundation, the Australian Medical Association, the Doctors Reform Society and various other medical organisations—have been very active in putting forward the facts, the figures and the data and encouraging politicians across party lines to see the light and to support this kind of legislation.

State governments have played a role. My own State of Victoria and the State of South Australia should be mentioned as pioneers in the sort of enlightened legislation that has been coming forward over the past decade or so and which pretty well culminates in the chamber tonight.

I also want to pay tribute tonight to the many people in the sporting world who have encouraged this Government to go ahead with a piece of legislation that has been politically sensitive. Following the ban on print advertising at the end of 1989, the next step was definitely the question of sporting and major cultural sponsorships, but in particular sporting sponsorships. My attempts, which Senator Lees referred to, to close the sports sponsorship loophole provided by the incidental advertising provision in the Broadcasting Act were time and again unsuccessful. My final thrust there was, in fact, another private member's Bill. After unsuccessfully moving some amendments, I put them in a form of a private member's Bill which was introduced at the end of 1990. That was done in order to keep that issue on the Notice Paper. As a matter of fact, it is probably still there.

It really was then down to those people who wished to pursue it to address the question of what would happen to the major and minor sports in this country. My regret is that it has taken so long, because for every delay, the ante has been raised by tobacco companies. It was always my fear that the political will would not be found. I have known all along that there have been people in the Government, and indeed in the Opposition—although here I feel the ghost of former Senator Peter Baume in this chamber tonight and I can imagine his delight at the passage of this legislation—continuing to work on this issue.

I believe that Minister Staples and people in his office also deserve to be commended for their persistence, for their sensitivity and for the consultative process for which they have been responsible. I have been willing—and sometimes able—to assist them in that process, sometimes simply by pulling in my horns. That can often be important in the political process when it is at a sensitive stage. I am not unwilling to do that if it is going to help the issue in the end. Often, it does.

I think that one of the things that we need to say is that certainly our children and our children's children will thank us for what we do here today. I was interested to note an article by Claude Forell earlier this year, just after the Government announced that this was what it proposed to do, which said that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, who, of course, had a significant role to play in this joint exercise, had been finally persuaded by some statistics—actually from a 1984 survey—so it was obviously a long process of persuasion. Nevertheless, she was.

That survey showed that the preferences of young children aged between 12 and 14 in the various States who were smoking coincided strikingly with the main brands sponsoring the main football codes in their various States. In many debates in this place I have put that information on the table and I know that all Government Ministers have been lobbying on the basis of those surveys for a good many years. Nevertheless, finally, a very significant Minister, with children of her own, was persuaded by this information. I am very grateful that it did persuade her.

In November 1991, the Australian Medical Association found that 61 per cent of Western Australian 12- to 17-year-olds believed that the sponsorship of cricket by Benson and Hedges would encourage children to smoke. As I say, I regret that this has taken so long. The ante has been raised and that is really, in part, the reason why that Benson and Hedges sponsorship will last until April 1996. Various other phase-outs will last until 1995, and it is really only the smaller billboards which will go as early as 1993.

I congratulate all of those who have been responsible. I acknowledge the work of those who have been attempting this process for a very long time and am proud to have been a part of that. I want to encourage this Government and successive governments, when dealing with this legislation and with my private member's Bill dealing with print prohibition legislation, to maintain a strength of purpose.

In the area of imported publications—a loophole in my private member's Bill—there is ministerial discretion. I believe it has been a sensible way to approach that problem. However, it will not work if the Minister concerned in whatever government is involved at any given time does not have a strength of purpose and does weaken. It will be exploited by the tobacco companies which we know are very accustomed to and efficient in exploitation.

For those events to be deemed of international significance and therefore able to be exempted, a strength of purpose is needed. The propaganda should not be believed. I have here an example of the way a nation, through broadcast bans, can ban tobacco sponsorship. In the British Grand Prix, cars were travelling around the course without tobacco sponsorship, yet in Germany the cars were with tobacco sponsorship. Those bans are extending around Europe, and Australia should not weaken on this issue and give encouragement and heart to the tobacco companies.

Senator Faulkner expressed concern about the practices of the tobacco companies in the neighbouring Asia-Pacific region. I express that same concern about the Third World generally. I think we have acted positively, sensibly and responsibly in our own situation. I think we all have a responsibility to keep an eye on what is going on in the Third World, to the extent that we can, and not see this problem shifted because of our ability to pass enlightened legislation into other parts of the world, as it already is to quite a large extent.

Perhaps of all the points I want to make I most want to underscore my view that legislation such as this is an encouragement to those of us who really do believe in a democracy, because it proves that if we do persist and work hard we can achieve enlightened legislation, even against massive commercial interests whose persuasive powers seem to have always won out in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is appropriate that the Senate ought to be discussing a major piece of legislation to do with health at 1.43 a.m. I suppose part of the comfort in that is that it is only 10.43 p.m. Western Australian time. In doing that and putting pressure on ourselves, I wonder what confidence the electorate in general can have in us putting health legislation of this nature forward at this time in the morning. It certainly tests my commitment.

PARA.TAB: I do not intend to pursue this topic in the depth and to the extent which I would like. I will start my contribution by quoting a number of passages from the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) of Wednesday, 25 November 1992. The Minister's speech read:

SPEECH.PARA: This is especially so when advertising has the effect, intended or otherwise, of persuading children to take up an addictive life-threatening habit.
It continued:

Although advertising may not directly cause children to smoke, it reinforces other influences such as peer and social pressures which cause children to smoke. Tobacco advertisements glamorise smoking, making it seem like a desirable activity.
It further said:

There can hardly be a more bizarre association than that between a product which is known to be a killer and the health giving nature of sport. This is especially so in the Australian context where sport is a vital part of our culture and where elite sportspeople are idolised, particularly by the young.
It went on:

The ban on tobacco advertising will lead to reduced smoking rates. The effect on the tobacco industry (growers, manufacturers, importers etc) is expected to be gradual as the major impact of the ban will be a reduction in the number of children taking up smoking rather than a sudden increase in smokers quitting.

I do not necessarily accept the wisdom of those words. I do not believe it will be that that stops children getting into smoking. Since this debate on smoking started—and it has been around for quite a number of years—I, as a smoker, have deliberately gone out of my way to talk with children, with young people, as to why they are smoking. What I have found out, in my limited research, is that it is nothing to do with advertising. It is nothing to do with whether Greg Matthews smokes or does not smoke.

PARA.TAB: It is peer group pressure in the main, and also—and this is perhaps partly the reason I got into smoking myself; there certainly was not much advertising around when I was coming through my formative years—it is rebellion. It is testing what authority is telling us. I have some fears about where this will ultimately—(Quorum formed)

I hope my colleagues will stay here and offer me support in my contribution this morning. I doubt it because I did not, as I think is publicly known, get such support in the Caucus meeting when this matter was being discussed. I was very heavily outnumbered and I did give the commitment to the Caucus that, while I would be expressing a view on this Bill, if it came to a vote on the floor of the chamber I would support it. I have expressed some of my doubts on the effectiveness of the legislation, and I will continue on that tack. If we as a government were really serious about stopping young people taking up this awful habit—and I can say that with authority because I am a heavy smoker—we would take decisive action against it. We would act to ban the product: we would ban the importation; we would ban the distribution and we would ban the sale of this particular noxious product. I have no argument about the statistics which are put around which say that 18,000, 19,000 or 20,000 people per year die because they have engaged in this habit. I do believe and accept those figures.

I wish that the researchers would delve a bit deeper and look at some of the industry gases and fumes that those smokers may have inhaled in their occupations. I suppose when I kick the bucket I will become another smoking statistic, but during my time in industry before entering this place I was exposed to a number of products which would not necessarily be tested by the researchers who do post-mortems. We do not see too many of those statistics around.

The governments—plural, because I am referring to the State governments as well—have vested interests in this. That is the reason why they will stand by and allow some 20,000 individuals to die per year, or allow 200,000 young people to continue with this habit. That vested interest is in the region of $3 billion per year—the revenue raised in taxes and excise from smokers. In the recent Budget, our own Government increased tobacco excise by some 10 per cent. The money raised went into job creation programs for the unemployed. I can say that I am making a real contribution to them, because I have continued with the same level of smoking that I was at before the increase came to bear.

I have a number of other concerns about what will happen when cigarette and tobacco sponsorship of sport is ceased. I draw the Senate's attention to an article which appeared in the Financial Review on the second of this month by Matthew Doman. It was titled `Tips on filtering out the smokers'. He referred to a recent paper by an economist, Terry Alchin, from the University of Western Sydney, who examined cigarette smoking from the early 1960s into the 1990s. Advertising expenditure and cigarette prices were compared with total and per adult consumption. The result of Mr Alchin's study found that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . advertising expenditure does not statistically significantly affect the demand for cigarettes, while. . . cigarette price [is] significant.

Statistics have been given to me by various lobby groups, including my friend Stephen Woodward, whom I will have a word to say about in a few minutes. He has given me a graph which shows that consumption of tobacco products is declining. I would like to measure increases in taxes and in excise and compare them with that graph which shows that consumption is reducing. I would also like to compare it with the various pieces of legislation that governments have passed, and see which had the most effect—the price increases or the advertising bans or other government actions.

PARA.TAB: Senator Powell in her recent contribution mentioned the survey which proved—and certainly helped to convince the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly)—that various sporting sponsorships in different States proved that there was a direct nexus, a direct link, between the consumption of Peter Jackson in one State and the consumption of Winfield in another. That survey is from 1984 figures. It is not pertinent to the young people of today, because they are not smoking those brands of cigarettes.

They are certainly not smoking them where I live in Western Australia. My stepchildren are not into those brands. The brands that they are smoking are not the brands that are being advertised through tobacco sporting sponsorship at the moment. They are not those brands at all. They are smoking the cigarettes in the larger packets which the tobacco producers have brought out to make smoking cheaper. Price is a very significant factor.

However, I have a very great and serious concern which, as Senator Faulkner mentioned earlier, is the link with another poisonous substance which abounds in our community. I quote from the statement on tobacco and tobacco-related products which I received from the Royal Australasian College of Physicians. Item 4 of the rationale in support of this particular legislation reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Seventy-five percent of drug-caused deaths are due to tobacco—
I do not dispute that—
23% are due to alcohol (including road crash fatalities). . .
Matthew Doman in his article, which I mentioned and quoted from earlier, goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: If this is the case, further increases in tobacco taxes would provide a greater discouragement to smokers, and improve the health of Australians and the balance of State and federal budgets.
Meanwhile, the brewers, pushers of that other at times dramatically unhealthy habit, stand in line to pick up the high-profile sports sponsorships soon to be forcibly vacated by tobacco companies.

The virtual absence of advertising and sponsorship restrictions on alcohol companies, and the lack of health warnings on their products, results in an extremely uneven playing field in the marketing of bad habits.

SPEECH.PARA: That is of concern to me. If the Ministers and their advisers are encouraged to believe that tobacco sporting sponsorship encourages young people to get into that obnoxious habit, then alcohol sponsorship will do the same.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner in his contribution mentioned that great sportsman Greg Matthews, who recently came to Western Australia and played a tremendous game of cricket against us and beat us—he was not playing yesterday. Greg Matthews had made the headlines—and Senator Faulkner referred to it—when he was fined by the Australian Cricket Board because he had appeared in a `Quit' advertisement. He was fined three months salary—salary which I understand was paid for by the sponsor of the Australian Cricket Board, the Benson and Hedges company. Because of that, Greg Matthews got a bit of publicity. He came over to Western Australia and was photographed by the West Australian newspaper—and I will not hold up this page of the newspaper because I know from a ruling given the other day that that would be disorderly, but it is here for anyone to see. Greg Matthews appeared in a photograph in the West Australian newspaper with his captain, Mark Taylor, wearing a t-shirt which had `Resch's real beer' on the front; his cap also featured Resch's.

If it holds true that sporting personalities being sponsored by tobacco companies will encourage young people to get into the habit of smoking, I hold that the corollary is that the same argument can be used for alcohol. If we are to enact this legislation, which we are undoubtedly going to do some time this morning, we should enact similar legislation for alcohol. I believe—and we know this from personal experience—that alcohol is perhaps in the short term a greater danger than tobacco for young people growing up in our society.

I said that I would mention a few words about my friend who has been to see me a few times on this legislation: Mr Stephen D. Woodward from the Public Affairs Committee of the Australasian Cancer Society. I think Mr Woodward particularly should be here this morning to see the passage of this legislation because of the way he has progressed it. I commend him for the work that he has done over the years and for the agony which some of his successful actions have put me through. Stephen has thrown out a challenge to me in recent discussions in that next year on Quit Day he will attempt to get me to participate in that. I certainly wish him well.

One final matter I want to address is a fear of what some individuals will do with legislation such as this. Earlier this year a decision was taken to ban smoking in airport terminals. It was announced that the ban would come into effect from 1 July. Indeed, the signs went up and the ban did come into effect on 1 July. However, the regulations for that ban did not give authority to the ban until about 17 July. It concerns me that bureaucrats or individuals in government instrumentalities can take action when they do not have the power in law to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a parrot fashion decision anyway.

—I will take Senator Button's interjection for the record, but it goes even further than that. I have put this on the record before. At the Australian Airlines terminal at Sydney Airport, that ban has been taken outside the terminal building. We now have signs on the pavement outside the building stating that smoking is banned between the signs. I do not know whether they are going to fine people who smoke in those areas. I will probably be one of the first people that they do fine.

PARA.TAB: In Melbourne Airport, at the Ansett terminal, there is an alcove area where people enter and leave. Signs there say `No smoking'. That area is not in the air-conditioned part of the building but outside. I am sure that most honourable senators know Melbourne Airport well. They would know that the winds provide a filter so that smoke does not get into the building. I believe that some people are taking the ban too far. I am directly challenging that ban at Melbourne Airport. Whenever I get to Sydney Airport—I try to avoid that place, but not because Greg Matthews comes from there—I will also challenge the ban outside the terminal building.

I do have doubts about the impact of the Bill. If the Government were really serious about stopping young people—I agree with stopping young people from smoking—it would completely ban the production, distribution and the sale of cigarettes. I sincerely hope that we are successful with this legislation. Smoking is an obnoxious and very addictive habit. I am told it is harder to give up than heroin. I know it is hard to give up, but I have never tried heroin. I thank the Senate for its indulgence this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is usually at this time of the morning that I dust off my speech about the insanity of speaking in the early hours of the morning and its health effects on not only honourable senators but also on the staff, Hansard, et cetera. I will not go through the old litany because we have heard it all before. However, I am happy to be here this morning because the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill 1992 is probably one of the most significant pieces of legislation that this chamber will pass this year, if not over a number of years. When I came into this place as a neophyte a little over two years ago one of the first pieces of legislation I struck was what I thought was the most reasonable and—
—Moderate.

—And moderate pieces of legislation concerning the eradication of cigarette smoking. To my amazement, it was the Australian Democrats who were promoting this Bill. They were opposed by the Government and the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Senator Powell mentioned tonight that she thought the ghost of former Senator Peter Baume was in this chamber. I saw Senator Peter Baume at the airport last Friday. I would like to say that he is alive and well. His ghost will be heard, if it ever comes this way. I am sure that he will read the Hansard of tonight and take some comfort from it, because I recall that he and I and Senator Archer supported the Democrats on that occasion.

The reason this Bill is a piece of major legislation is that we have reached the stage in health care in this country where most of the things that affect health care are lifestyle provisions. Sanitation, water supplies, nutrition and vaccines were the major advances in the last 100 years that have produced changes. I do not believe that in our lifetime we will see a major disease such as cancer conquered as a whole, because we do not understand the complete cause of it. However, the lifestyle changes that have affected disease processes in our lifetime have been things such as the cessation of smoking and its relationship to coronary heart disease, emphysema and other diseases associated with it and the recognition that lack of exercise and obesity were major contributing factors.

I do not believe that we will see in our lifetimes the conquering of degenerative and cerebrovascular diseases, such as strokes, et cetera. So we are reaching a stage in this country where the only effective modification of lifestyle that we can bring about is the cessation of smoking.

Does cigarette smoking cause death? We still get specious articles sent to us by the tobacco lobbies and people purporting to be disinterested but dependent on the tobacco industry. Some sporting bodies have written to us in recent days. The answer is yes, it does cause death. That is a recent discovery in our lifetime. I recall when I started out in cancer research in 1963 that the first work proving the association between tobacco smoking and lung cancer was done by Sir Richard Doll in England in the 1960s. So that has been proved relatively recently, and everything has followed from the research done at that time. Many other forms of cancer are related to cigarette smoking. Ninety per cent of cancer of the mouth and 85 per cent of cancer of the larynx are related to cigarette smoking.

The next argument is that advertising does not really influence tobacco use. I wonder why the cigarette companies spend $100m a year on advertising. Is it just for the benefit of the community that they do so?

TALK.START.PARA: —Throwing it away.

—Senator Bell thinks that they are just throwing away their money. They might as well spend it there as spend it somewhere else. Advertising is obviously used to promote the consumption of cigarettes and tobacco products.

PARA.TAB: I was interested in the comments of Senator McKiernan, which were reinforced by Senator Bishop. They would be interested to know in turn that a study was done on the influence of peer groups by the US Government earlier this year. In interviews with over 9,965 teenagers, the study found that peer group pressure was far more important than sibling pressure—and that in turn was far more important than parent pressure.

The survey found that children whose friends smoked were far more likely to become smokers than those who hung out with non-smokers. Three per cent in a non-smoking crowd started smoking versus 50 per cent for those with smoking friends. Older brothers and sisters were more likely to be a bad influence than parents. Thirty per cent of adolescents reported currently smoking in homes where only older siblings smoked compared with 15 per cent of teenagers from homes where only their parents smoked.

I raise this point because the Public Health Service Center estimated that some 3.7 million US teenagers smoked but that 92 per cent of them said that they did not plan to be smoking in another year. When those people were checked a year later it was found that only 1.5 per cent of them managed to quit.

As Senator McKiernan said, smoking is a terrible addiction. I have the greatest sympathy for cigarette smokers. From my time of treating heroin addicts, I agree with the statement that it is easier to give up heroin than cigarette smoking. The only thing is that heroin addiction is more lethal than cigarette smoking.

The other argument used is that if tobacco is a legal product why cannot it be advertised. We are not allowed to advertise over 150 products that are legal. Interestingly enough, one of them is nicorette, to which Senator Faulkner referred previously. The reason nicorette is not allowed to be advertised is that it is an addictive drug. One can become addicted to it quite easily. But there are many other products. Cyanide is a lethal product that cannot be advertised. Valium and the anti-depressants are quite legal, but they are not permitted to be advertised. So it is a specious argument. Another argument is, `This is the thin edge of the wedge and we will be banning Mars bars next'. I recall that being said around the place. This legislation is not about banning Mars bars or any other product; it specifically relates to the advertising of cigarettes.

One other aspect which has not been mentioned is passive smoking. Inevitably, passive smoking has now been accepted in a legal sense and also in a medical sense as a causation of disease. There are many research projects which have demonstrated that, going to the foetus in utero being of a smaller birth weight and being affected by the mother's smoking.

Finally, I wish to refer to the fact that this legislation will not be the end of the process. It is not the last gasp, if I can use that phrase. There is a worldwide movement to control tobacco smoking. I refer particularly to the International Union Against Cancer Newsletter of September this year which notes that the ninth world conference on smoking and health will be held in Paris next year. It will be addressing a comprehensive tobacco control strategy; women and smoking; children and smoking; passive smoking; and the central and eastern European `Smokeout'. The newsletter has a report of a UICC tobacco control workshop in Moscow which found:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout Eastern Europe, more than one-third of all male deaths in middle age are now due to smoking, and the epidemic is still on the rise. The conference therefore calls for, as a first step, urgent action in Russia to:
1.Introduce (and enforce) a strict ban on all direct or indirect advertising or promotion of tobacco goods or trade marks.
2.Adopt (as a minimum) European Community standards for cigarette packet health warnings.
3.Adopt (as a minimum) European Community standards for maximum tar deliveries, but with delays to allow national tobacco manufacturers to comply with them . . .

There are a number of other provisions. This is a world movement. In many respects, Australia is leading the world in its recognition of the fact that cigarette smoking is one of the few areas where we can improve the cancer death rate by reducing the factors that influence people to smoke and by reducing cigarette smoking as a whole. I commend the Bill and congratulate the Parliament on its bipartisan support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator McKiernan, I took up smoking in my late teenage years because of peer pressure. I gave it up some 16 years ago because I decided I no longer wished to be a human chimney. I decided one day that I would give it up and that was the end of it. My grandmother was 90 years old when she died. She still played a mean game of poker and a splendid hand of bridge. She also enjoyed her cigarettes. In other words, it is a freedom. She chose to continue to smoke; I chose not to. That is what this whole debate is about—freedom.

PARA.TAB: When I last debated this matter in this chamber in 1990, I too listened to the arguments of Senator Herron whose views I respect. I disagree with him. I disagree with him not because I disagree with his conviction and his belief in what he is saying, but because he seems to me to put the argument for banning the product. But nobody is prepared to bite the bullet and say that, if this product is so bad, so wicked and so evil, it should be banned. Whilst it remains a legal and freely traded product, in my view it should be free to be advertised and people should exercise their freedom of choice—whether they choose to use it or not.

Senator Herron also said that the argument that this is the thin edge of the wedge is not one that is sustainable. It is. Already we have heard from Senator McKiernan that alcohol should go a similar way, and that is the way it will go. The world is full of people who believe that they can tell us how we can better live our lives. I say we can make that choice for ourselves. It may be tobacco tonight. It will be alcohol next. It will be snack foods after that, including Mars bars. It will then be armchairs because somebody will put up a splendid argument that the design of a chair on which one sits can seriously determine the back problems one may have and the amount of workers compensation claims one may finally cost the community.

There is always a justification for regulation. What I want to see is for those who say that this product is so bad that we cannot use it to in fact ban it. However, as I said, I have respect for those people who run the straight health line. I have no respect for those who run the second agenda. The second agenda goes like this: alcohol and tobacco, heroin, cocaine and marijuana are all as bad as one another; they are all terrible drugs.

Therefore, if one equates them and says the problem of tobacco and alcohol can be solved by regulation, then similarly one can solve the problem of cocaine, heroin and marijuana by similar regulation. In other words, the main agenda is to see the decriminalisation of illegal drugs. That is the second agenda run by many who say we should ban advertising of tobacco and then alcohol.

Because it is so late at night—or early in the morning depending on one's point of view—and because we have agreed to curtail our speeches, I went back to the speech I made almost two years ago to the day, on 11 December 1990, to the Broadcasting (Foreign Ownership) Amendment Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate it.

—I thank Senator Tate; that is exactly what I intend to do. I would like to have my speech incorporated in Hansard because I stand by the remarks I made on that occasion. I rise tonight because I want my remarks on the record. I do believe that this Bill is wrong and that the decision to ban sponsorship for sport is wrong. However, as I said, I want my remarks to be recorded so that people know where I stand. I seek leave to incorporate that speech.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this issue one of principle which simply comes down to a question of whether or not we are using censorship to try to enforce a point of view that a particular group within the society holds. I speak as one who gave up smoking some 16 years ago, but I am also one who will defend the right of another to have a cigarette. I believe that those people who want to convince others that they should either stop smoking or not ever take it up ought to rely on the strength and merit of their own argument, not try to enforce their point of view through the curtailment of the right to advertise what is a legal product.
