PARA.TAB: As I listened to Senator Herron's speech, it occurred to me that he was making a plea to ban the sale and use of tobacco, rather than directing his attention to the question of whether or not one is entitled to advertise what is a legal product. Senator Peter Baume had a word or two to say about what constitutes a legal product. I think he was talking about what limitations are placed upon the sale of a product-be it cigarettes, alcohol or a range of other products. It concerns me that there are always within our society some people who think they are better able to tell other people how they ought to live their lives rather than letting them make up their own minds for themselves.

This also applies to credit. Some people might say that they are entitled to make a judgment about how somebody ought to be able to use credit. I have heard that argument put forward on the same basis and with the same passion as the argument adopted by people who wish to curtail the advertising of cigarettes.

In many ways, one can look at the question of tobacco advertising as being the thin edge of the wedge. That same group of people who want to say what one can or cannot advertise in respect of tobacco also would very often like to introduce similar restrictions on alcohol advertising or, indeed, on confectionery advertising-and we have already seen a move from the consumer groups to put limitations upon the times when the makers of confectionery such as Lifesavers or Mars Bars are able to advertise their products.
Senator Collins—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I see Senator Collins has some sympathy with curtailing the intake of sugar. That is a decision for him to make, not for somebody else to impose. If we allow people to tell us how to live our lives, perhaps we will be told that the design of some armchairs is not conducive to good posture and that taxpayers' money will have to be used to rectify the condition of peoples' spines. This sort of argument can go on in a never ending way. As I said, the question is not about whether one should ban the sale and usage of tobacco. This is a debate about whether or not rules of censorship are to be placed upon the right of people to advertise products that are legal.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume also made the point that back in 1976, the then Government-of which, of course, I was not a part-passed legislation to limit the freedom to advertise.
Senator Peter Baume—Do you agree with the Senate's decision?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already made my position quite clear, I would have thought, Senator Baume. Indeed, I believe that, if a product is legal, one ought to be able to advertise it. However, the legislation is in place. I do not want to see, as Senator Michael Baume has said, an extension of the legislation to ban the televising of sport. This is what would result from the amendment which is before us today. This subject raises passions. The Australian Democrats, from the sound of their interjections, are really wanting to debate the question of prohibition of the product itself, not the question of the advertising of what is a legal product.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler—Have you read the amendment, Senator?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the amendment. However, I cannot help but think perhaps it is the thin edge of the wedge. It seems that because the prohibition case cannot be argued satisfactorily, a softer argument has been adopted. I do not believe that that course is open to anybody. The fundamental point is that it is a question of censorship, not a question of health.

—I wish to speak briefly to this matter because it is important that I do so. Before I arrived in this place I rejoiced in the success of Senator Powell's moves to restrict advertising in printed matter.

PARA.TAB: I did so because even before that time I had actively encouraged young people to gain the approval of their peers through activities not involving the use of advertised products such as tobacco which sought to suggest to young people that they could gain the approval of their peers by being induced to take up this habit. I actively encouraged young people to take up other activities, especially through sport.

I am especially pleased that basketball and hockey—the two sports especially enjoyed by my two young children at the moment—are both enjoying a boom in popularity which is in no part owed to the pariah of tobacco sponsorship. Both sports are entirely free of that insidious influence.

In the past I have also campaigned for the reduction of the participation of local governments in the marketing of tobacco products. While I was a member of the Hobart City Council I tried without success to prevent advertising on council property, mainly on sporting grounds. However, I was able to encourage the Council to realise the benefits of declaring the council buildings smoke free.

Since reaching this place I have continued to take opportunities to remove tobacco from the entrenched, habitual, insidious role that it has established in our society. I took undeserved credit when I brought forward a notice of motion against smoking in airport terminals and learnt a few hours later that such a ban had taken effect.

I must briefly take issue with Senator McKiernan because that ban was in fact a result of a consultative process between staff, administration and users of terminals. I suggest that Senator McKiernan read the Federal Airports Corporation annual report—which may be in his in-tray at this very moment—to find out the history of that particular action, which is not as he described it.

These sorts of measures are taken by people who recognise the benefits to be derived at the workplace by reducing the opportunity for compensation claims by affected workers, but also the increased productivity which derives from the simple matters of reduced cleaning costs, reduced accident rates and increased working times actually at the workplace, not to mention reduced fire risk and greatly improved worker comfort. That is all in addition to the acknowledged matter of reduced community health costs, which has been well aired tonight.

I rise merely to endorse the remarks of so many senators who have expressed the case for supporting this Bill. In particular, I acknowledge the excellent information that was provided by both Senator Faulkner and Senator Herron, particularly Senator Herron's contribution. I cannot disagree with him as Senator Bishop does. I do not believe it is a question of freedom; it is a question of considering what is appropriate. What we are doing is banning the advertising of cigarettes; we are not at the moment embarking upon a total ban of the product. A total ban may eventually be appropriate, as it has become appropriate with the banning of chewing tobacco. It became appropriate that that product be banned. At the moment, of course, it is not appropriate to attempt to ban smoking tobacco totally. Realistically, it would be impractical to attempt such a move. We are banning sponsorship and other advertisements, and that is what I support at the moment.

I wish to address quite quickly a question that was raised by a couple of speakers; that is, the question of peer group pressure. I suggest that it should not be dismissed in an offhand manner: `Oh, it is peer group pressure'. I suggest that we look at what peer group pressure is. It is a pressure applied especially to young people who are trying to conform to the actions of their friends and associates. We could ask why it is that peers smoke. I suggest that it is entirely associated with the concept of self-esteem and that those who are lacking in self-esteem are the subject of the advertising which preys on that problem. Many young people when they are seeking their own identity are seeking an opportunity to establish themselves in the eyes of their contemporaries. Tobacco advertising preys considerably on the doubts and the questions that are raised in the minds of adolescents. Essentially, the message provided by cigarette advertising is, `Get your self-esteem here in this picture. Associate yourself with these heroes'. The heroes, of course, have too often been those of the sporting field.

The sporting heroes of our past—the Cazalys, the Bradmans, the Oppermans, the Mockridges—and the more recent heroes of the Cawleys and the Curry-Kennys have reached the pinnacle of sporting prowess without the dubious benefits of tobacco sponsorship. The concept of sportsmanship that is held by such heroes owes little to the dubious benefits of tobacco sponsorship. It is possible to succeed in sport and to play good sport without tobacco sponsorship, and it is possible to assist young people in developing their sense of self-esteem and to be successful without associating this evil drug in any way with sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will be responsibly brief, but I do need to respond to the second reading debate on this particularly important Bill, the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill. I believe it is a significant event in the history of the Senate that we should be dealing with the Bill in such a way as to demonstrate solidarity on the issue. I will deal with the misgivings of some of the senators concerned in a moment.

PARA.TAB: Generally speaking, there has been widespread support for this measure around the chamber. I believe that it is because—as Senator Herron put it, drawing on his very considerable learning and practical experience in the field—when one looks at the scope for preventative medicine in our society, as a public health issue there is no doubt that tobacco is the major preventable cause of death and disease in Australia. Whether the figure of 18,000 Australians who died in 1990 before their time because they smoked is precisely correct, nevertheless, figures of those dimensions do require a parliament to respond. But how do we respond in a socially responsible manner?

Quite clearly, the idea of total prohibition of the product is beyond the pale and would simply lead to the same phenomenon as we saw with the banning of the legal sale of alcohol in the United States in the 1930s. One would simply see the marketplace supplied by unscrupulous profiteers. As a society, we would be strengthening the hands of those engaged in organised crime in Australia. That particular option is not realistically open to us because the use of tobacco in our society is a legacy of centuries. It is not to be equated, as Senator Bishop feared, with the more recent phenomenon of marijuana, heroin, cocaine use and so on. It is not something to be equated with the total prohibition of those products.

We are talking about a legacy of many centuries. We are the inheritors of that legacy. And because of its widespread cultural acceptance until now, total prohibition is out of the question. But there is no doubt that we are right, as a parliament, to take this latest initiative to deal with the sponsorship and advertising of tobacco products.

I may also, of course, deal with the argument that because it is legal to sell and trade in this product, it should be legal to advertise it. Quite clearly, it is not legal to advertise all products which are legally able to be sold. For example, insulin comes to mind. It is not legal to sell tobacco products to minors. Therefore, if one keeps the analogy going, it should not be legal to advertise to minors. If in forbidding that one also, incidentally, does not enable advertising to adults, that is bad luck for the adults. So I do not find much weight in the arguments that are put in that regard.

This is the latest in a series of initiatives taken by the Government and parliament to reduce tobacco consumption in Australia. One thinks of the ban on smoking in Commonwealth buildings; the ban on tobacco advertising in the print media to extend the established broadcast media ban; the ban on smoking during airline flights and so on. Removing what one might call the last vestiges of tobacco advertising is an important move which is prompted mainly by our concern about children and newcomers to the particular product who take it up as a pastime which becomes an addiction very quickly.

As the second reading speech states, although advertising may not directly cause children to smoke, it reinforces other influences such as peer and social pressures which cause people to smoke. It went on to say that tobacco advertising supports and reinforces pressures to take up smoking and increases the difficulties encountered in quitting. I do not think enough emphasis has been put on that latter element. It may be enough to say that the advertising of tobacco products ought to be halted because obviously such advertising runs counter to, or dilutes, the health education messages about the ill-effects of tobacco. That in itself might be sufficient reason.

Certainly, we do not need to be absolutist or cast the tobacco lobby in the role of demons in this matter. We just need to be prudent and cautious. I believe that the Parliament is taking a prudent and cautious line in regard to the whole question of tobacco advertising in this Bill.

The question of the linking of tobacco advertising to sport and other cultural events is particularly insidious, linking as it does an unhealthy product with a healthy activity. For example, in Tasmania one has a very good example of a different approach, where Stephen Hawkins, the gold medallist rower, has been recruited as a drug offensive ambassador. He has gone around 33 schools in Tasmania and talked to the youngsters about the evils of smoking from the point of view of a premier sportsman.

Stephen Hawkins has achieved gold medal status and says to the youngsters, `I would not have achieved this status had I taken up smoking'. Senator Newman would know what a tremendous idol and hero he is amongst young people in Tasmania and how effective he has been in spreading that message. That sort of activity is to be commended and will do a lot—perhaps more than we can do—to persuade young people not to take up this habit.

To the extent that the Bill does establish bans on tobacco advertising, honourable senators will know that it provides for a phasing in over the period 1 July 1993 to 31 September 1995. There are further extensions in relation to certain contracts, but basically there is a phasing in. This is not a totally draconian measure which operates from the time when the legislation is passed by the Parliament. I believe that that is an important matter which modifies the otherwise untoward effect on people with legitimate expectations under contracts that they have in relation to the displaying of the names of tobacco products where sponsorship exists in relation to a particular sport or cultural event.

I wish to deal with only one matter raised by an Opposition senator. Senator Campbell raised the very fair point about point of sale advertising. I simply wish to make it clear that in those States where in fact point of sale advertising is provided for under the State laws or regulations those laws remain in place totally unaffected by this Bill. There will be no overriding of them by the paramount force of what this Parliament is doing tonight; they will remain in place. It is only in those States or Territories—Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory—where there are no such laws or regulations in place that we will provide a regulation which will be very broad in its scope and which will be the subject of extensive consultation with the industry. In fact, I met in my office with representatives of the retail tobacco traders from all around Australia only last week. I gave them the assurance that they would be involved in the actual drafting of the parameters of that regulation. I am sure they will take up that invitation.

Finally, I believe that those honourable senators who found difficulty in supporting the Bill should recognise that the way in which our party system works—the Westminster system—is actually the great strength of our democracy. It means that after vigorous and democratic debate within our respective party rooms a decision which is taken is then a decision which is supported by all of us in this chamber. That is a strength which means that we cannot be picked off one by one, as in the United States congressional system where we would be the prey of every lobby group with its money and its political power. I believe that we ought to take some consolation from the strength of our democracy in this matter as we withstand some of the very heavy lobbying that has taken place.

The passage of this legislation is amongst the most important health initiatives that have been taken by this Parliament since I entered Parliament some 14 years ago. We are making a major contribution towards reducing illness and premature mortality amongst Australians not only of this generation but certainly in generations to come. For that reason, I think that this early morning will be seen as a most significant one in the history of public health and preventative health strategies in Australia. I wholeheartedly commend this Bill to the Senate for the second reading.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 10 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many general medical practitioners were investigated by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) in 1990-91 and 1991-92 for: (a) alleged overservicing; and/or (b) alleged initiation of excessive pathology services.
(2) How many of those practitioners were subsequently: (a) visited by a medical advisor from the HIC; and (b) referred to a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry.

(3) How many of those practitioners raised their treatment of: (a) Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME)/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome patients; and (b) AIDS sufferers, as an explanation for the alleged overservicing or alleged initiation of excessive pathology services.

(4) Does the HIC have any specific measure, standard or profile of level of treatment, for example visits or pathology referrals, which takes into account the specific needs of medical practitioners treating: (a) ME/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome patients; and (b) AIDS sufferers.

(5) Does the HIC or the Medical Services Committee of Inquiry have any specific guidelines for conducting investigations where the treatment of: (a) ME/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome; (b) AIDS; and (c) any other specific conditions or illness, is raised as an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In 1990-91 medical advisers from the HIC interviewed 166 practitioners for possible overservicing and 224 practitioners for possible initiation of excessive pathology services. In 1991-92, 426 were interviewed for possible overservicing and 650 for possible excessive pathology services.

(3) Only estimates are available of the number of practitioners who have used ME/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) or AIDS as a reason for their servicing profile. To obtain precise figures would require an unreasonable diversion of resources.

In the two years the HIC's medical advisers interviewed some 50 practitioners who attributed their servicing profile to the treatment of patients with ME/CFS and approximately five practitioners who treated a high number of AIDS patients.

In 1990-91 no practitioner appearing before a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry referred to either condition as an explanation for his/her servicing profile. In 1991-92, two raised ME/CFS and one practitioner raised the treatment of patients with AIDS as explanation of their servicing profile.

(4) The HIC is not responsible for determining appropriate standards or levels of treatment of any condition, including ME/CFS or AIDS. The HIC, in assessing possible excessive servicing, relies on a high level of professional input and takes into account the continually changing nature of acceptable medical practices and the needs of the patient. There is still disagreement in the medical profession, however, about the necessary medical investigation and management of ME/CFS.

(5) The HIC has no specific guidelines for conducting investigations where practitioners are treating patients with ME/CFS, AIDS or any other condition or illness. The HIC's Medicare claims database is analysed with assistance from actively practising and highly regarded consultants from all medical specialities to identify patterns of medical practice which may not be acceptable.

Medical Services Committees of Inquiry have no specific guidelines for investigating any matters before them. The committees are independent from the HIC and each comprises five actively practising medical practitioners. The committees form a peer review process which affords practitioners who appear before them procedural fairness and natural justice.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does Australia have any formal or informal provisions for the registration, monitoring, regulation and review of foreign government intelligence operations in Australia; if so, what are the details of these provisions; if not, will any steps be taken to implement a process which effectively deals with the registration, monitoring, regulation and review of foreign government intelligence operations in Australia.
(2) If a process to deal with the registration, monitoring, regulation and review of foreign government intelligence operations is not going to be implemented, what are the reasons for this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In accordance with the practice of successive Commonwealth Governments, I do not propose to comment on foreign government intelligence operations in Australia in those cases where the activity has been declared by the foreign government and approved by the Australian Government. To do so would harm Australia's relations with those governments and their intelligence organisations.

Any unapproved activity by a foreign government in Australia which would be prejudicial to the security of Australia, as defined in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979, would be investigated by ASIO.
